<s>  how's * that * for a collision of acting styles ? 
<s>  for those of us who weren't yet born when the 1960's rock 'n' rolled around , monterey pop affords an affectionate glimpse of the music that influenced our parents to be hippies . 
<s>  from otis redding to jimi hendrix , janis joplin to the mamas and the papas , and jefferson airplane to the who , this documentary is jam-packed with contagious energy . 
<s>  but i give fair warning that i will reveal the ending , which does not do the rest of the film the justice it deserves . 
<s>  shot in 1969 at an outdoor concert that precluded woodstock , the film defies the stereotype of the general population at the time . 
<s>  sure , some have painted their faces and smoke joints , but d . a . 
<s>  pennebaker ( the war room , moon over broadway ) surprisingly chooses to show a broad spectrum of the audience . 
<s>  no matter who is watching , it all comes back to the talented musicians that stir your soul . 
<s>  the excitement starts before the music even begins . 
<s>  a young girl is cleaning thousands of seats and when asked why by an interviewer , she replies that she feels lucky to do so . 
<s>  there are moments of organized craziness as john phillips , leader of the mamas and the papas and one of the concert organizers , tries to get in touch with dionne warwick . 
<s>  and when one band is tuning up , a member remarks , " finally , a decent sound system ! " 
<s>  you can tell just by watching these first few moments that this show isn't about vanity , it's about playing the music you love to those who have an appreciation for it , a two-way street . 
<s>  this interaction between audience and performer continues throughout the film and becomes infectious to the audience . 
<s>  it's impossible to tear your eyes away from janis joplin as she belts out her ballad about love being a ball and chain . 
<s>  and while the lyrics to " wild thing " may not be all that complicated , watching jimi hendrix mime having sex with his guitar is as captivating as otis redding singing about love . 
<s>  even if you don't recognize every band you see on stage , you can imagine being as enthralled by their work as the public sitting in those seats . 
<s>  the only drawback to the film is the ending , which unfortunately i must reveal . 
<s>  all the other bands , big names then and still today , got approximately 7 to 10 minutes of screen time . 
<s>  in contrast , the last band on camera , a wholly forgettable one , gets an entire 18 minutes of screen time . 
<s>  for a film that's only 78 minutes long , that's too large of a chunk , especially when previous acts are much more stimulating . 
<s>  all in all , monterey pop is a precious , rare look at a time period that still holds sway over us . 
<s>  the variety of music , as well as the beautifully shot performances , are easy to become immersed in . 
<s>  if there was ever any question as to why most of these bands were so popular , this is quickly dispelled . 
<s>  it's almost depressing to think that music this moving doesn't get made much anymore . 
<s>  instead we're stuck with * nsync , the backstreet boys , and jennifer lopez , all of whom should have stuck with modeling . 
<s>  the most common ( and in many cases the only ) complaint against francis ford coppola's 1972 masterpiece the godfather is glamorising of mafia , which is presented as an institution guided by ancient tradition and virtues like honour , loyalty and solidarity more suitable for some gentler , kinder ages . 
<s>  martin scorsese , another italoamerican moviemaker , confronted that perspective with his own , more down-to-earth vision of mafia in 1973 mean streets , movie that dealt with lower echelons of organised crime . 
<s>  unfortunately for scorsese , his film was unspectacular and too artsy to compete with coppola's influence on mafia portrayals in the movies . 
<s>  seventeen years later scorsese returned to mean streets of new york with another film that dealt with darker side of american organised crime . 
<s>  this film was goodfellas , epic black comedy which is today considered as one of the best and most influential films of 1990s . 
<s>  goodfellas owes some of its initial success and popularity to the fact that it was based on the true story , told in best-seller book wiseguy by nicholas pileggi ( who would co-write the screenplay for the film ) . 
<s>  the book , as well as the film , chronicled thirty years in the life of henry hill ( played by ray liotta ) , irish-italian criminal from new york . 
<s>  at the age of 13 he gets recruited in the criminal organisation of paulie cicero ( played by paul sorvino ) , local mob boss , and gradually climbs up the ladder starting with small errands . 
<s>  after couple of years , together with his best childhood friend tommy de vito ( played by joe pesci ) , he joins the crew of expert thieves led by jimmy conway ( played by robert de niro ) . 
<s>  three of them spend years as best friends and associates , gathering enormous wealth from their criminal enterprises that would culminate with one of the most spectacular robberies in american history . 
<s>  wealth , influence and privileges of men connected with mafia are enough for henry hill to seduce his future wife karen ( played by lorraine bracco ) , who would afterwards remain loyal to her husband despite infidelities , domestic abuse , arrests and would even be accomplice to his own private drug dealing business . 
<s>  but the perfect world of " wiseguys " gradually begins to fall apart - tommy's unpredictable outbursts of homicidal violence , jimmy's reluctance to share his part of the loot with partners and , finally , henry's own drug habit would lead to his downfall and make him question his loyalty to the friends . 
<s>  goodfellas is an excellent example of a film that represents work of a film genius in his full glory . 
<s>  scorsese managed to create a vision which is effective and complete despite being full of contradictions that would ripped the film apart in the hands of less talented filmmaker . 
<s>  world depicted in this film is both ordinary and fascinating . 
<s>  scorsese spares no effort to show us all the violence , hypocrisy and inherent paranoia of organised crime , yet it manages to make it both seductive and funny . 
<s>  after being exposed to two and half hours of the film and three decades of criminal history ( based on some notorious real life events ) , the audience understands why the characters chose such dangerous life paths , trading the superficial and short-lasting glamour and prosperity of a criminal to the dullness and poverty of honest citizens . 
<s>  scorsese also manages to break viewer's moralistic inhibitions by showing truly revolting material - scenes that depict personal tragedies , broken homes , human depravity , violence , bloodshed and murder - in all their uncompromising reality , but in a manner that would make it amusing and funny to the audience . 
<s>  with the use of ironic soundtrack , manipulative shots , character's dialogue or narrator's commentary , goodfellas represents the new standards of black humour that would became very popular few years later during tarantino era . 
<s>  even if we don't pay attention to skills with which potentially disturbing material becomes eye pleasing and entertaining , we should admit that scorsese displays his talents of truly original and creative filmmaker . 
<s>  first , we might notice unusual structure of the plot - relatively minor subplot is used as movie's ironic prologue . 
<s>  then , instead of single narrator , scorsese switches to the second character as narrator in the middle of the film only to switch back to the original shortly afterwards . 
<s>  this multiple points of views , both in terms of narration and various subjective shots , only lengthens the ironic distance towards characters and their situation . 
<s>  same ironic distance comes with extremely effective choice of soundtrack . 
<s>  nostalgia for good old times is illustrated with easy-listening 1950s pop songs , while depression , paranoia and bad times find their expression in more neurotic rock songs of late 1960s and 1970s . 
<s>  but the soundtrack is most effective when it is used as ironic comment - almost pastoral , easy listening tunes make strong and very ironic contrast to the scenes of violence and bloodshed . 
<s>  however , thing most associated with this film is couple of continuos shots that feature characters moving through large rooms and interacting with dozens if not hundreds of people . 
<s>  such scenes , although they require very great skill and patience during their shootings , became very popular among other directors in 1990s . 
<s>  fragmentary character of the screenplay , which doesn't have straight plot and instead bases film on series of loosely connected vignettes , gives another interesting opportunity for scorsese . 
<s>  he uses this structure of film to experiment , and most successful of such experiments is hilarious " a day in life " segment near the end of the film . 
<s>  another essential element of goodfellas is large but superb collection of great acting talents . 
<s>  the most respectable among them is robert de niro , but his character , who happen to be most quiet and business-like member of criminal trio , gets overshadowed by two of his friends and colleagues . 
<s>  joe pesci deserved his " oscar " for supporting role of homicidal psychopath tommy , and his lines , including ad-libs , probably represent the most memorable element of the film . 
<s>  ray liotta , although equally talented , perhaps doesn't look as the best choice for narrator and nominal hero of the film . 
<s>  liotta's henry hill looks somewhat too hollywoodised and glamorous among this bunch of low-level street thugs . 
<s>  liotta , on the other hand , improves general impression by very realistic and menacing portrayal of drug addiction . 
<s>  lorraine bracco is , on the other hand , very effective and believable as karen hill , wife who gradually descends into same moral cesspool as her husband . 
<s>  paul sorvino is also very effective as patriarch mafioso , and among the supporting cast most memorable is chuck low as pestering small-time gangster who unknowingly digs his own grave . 
<s>  as a combination of clever sociological study , black humour and innovative filmmaking goodfellas became something only the truly great films could do - work of art and excellent popular entertainment in the same time . 
<s>  because of this achievement , and also because of the great influence on future filmmakers , this cinematic gem deserves its rightful place among the best films of 1990s . 
<s>   " the blair witch project " was perhaps one of a kind , a unique film that played completely on its own merit , managing to scare even the most experienced horror fans out of their senses . 
<s>  its success made a sequel inevitable , but this is not the sequel , i suspect , anyone much wanted . 
<s>  after the release of " the blair witch project " , tourists have practically invaded the small town of burkettsville , in order to get a glimpse of the blair witch . 
<s>  locals have turned this mass hysteria into a great business opportunity , selling twig-sculptures , stones and dirt like those in the movie , and the exasperated local sheriff patrols the woods with a bullhorn , shouting , " get out of these woods and go home ! 
<s>  there is no goddamned blair witch ! " . 
<s>  jeff ( ) is one of those people , who has used the sudden popularity of the small town to his advantage . 
<s>  after he got released from the mental institution , he created a mobile business that attracts thousands of customers through the internet . 
<s>  as the movie starts he is leading one of these groups into the woods , on the " blair witch hunt " . 
<s>  among the five strangers is stephen and his girlfriend , the pregnant tristen , who are writing a book on the hysteria caused by the film called " the blair witch : history or hysteria ? " , and kim , who dresses in black and has some psychic powers . 
<s>  the last member of the crew is erica , a young beautiful witch-wannabe , who constantly quotes from the wiccan lore , saying " the first rule of wicca is , do no harm , because whatever you do will come back to you threefold . " 
<s>  this strange group plunges into the woods , where they begin to argue about their different approaches to the experience . 
<s>  on the very first night that they decide to spend under the stars amidst the ruins of parr's abandoned house , strange things start happening . 
<s>  when they wake up their equipment is gone and only the tapes remain . 
<s>  after a while they discover strange markings on their bodies . 
<s>  they are somehow lost in time , as it loops uncontrollably back and forth . 
<s>  they are all haunted by hallucinations and horrible nightmares and soon they can not see the difference between dreams and reality . 
<s>  the only thing that they are sure of is that they have brought something or someone with them from the woods . . 
<s>  documentary director joe berlinger ( " paradice lost " ) helms " blair witch 2 " , leaving the creators of the first film ( dan myrick and ed sanches ) in the background . 
<s>  the opening scenes--the documentary showing the townspeople affected by the first film-- is a more promising approach , because instead of trying to cover similar ground , it goes outside the first film and makes its own stand . 
<s>  but soon the movie gets confused and sidetracked by its own story , that is never resolved and ends with a very anticlimaxic epilogue . 
<s>  in a way , this is a typical hollywood sequel . 
<s>  more money has been spent and more people have worked on a project that was doomed to fail . 
<s>  the horror and suspense of the original simply could not be repeated . 
<s>  of course in these situations , quantity is more important than quality and profit is more important than the artistical values . 
<s>  from its opening scenes when the camera gracefully panes over the bloody-red forest , with carter burwell's ( " being john malkovich " and " fargo " ) musical score in the background , you realize that with the exception of its title , this film has absolutely nothing to do with " the blair witch project " . 
<s>   " blair witch . . " 
<s>  was filmed by handheld videocameras and nfeatured acting that was mostly based on improvisation . 
<s>  in the sequel the technical aspect of the film is close to perfection , creating a completely different atmosphere . 
<s>  with its graceful cinematography , production design and flashy editing , the film has a very polished look , which is impossible to associate with the first installment . 
<s>  and though berlinger directs his film with an energy and pace that makes the adrenaline rush through the body a couple of times , he has obviously misunderstood the nature of his predecessor . 
<s>  the key is simplicity . 
<s>   " blair witch project " had a story which was incredibly simple . 
<s>  that allowed the audience to fill the gaps with our own imagination . 
<s>  the film was practically an empty screen , on which we projected our most frightening nightmares . 
<s>  the effect was incredibly powerful , lasting and entir e everyone , but in a different way . 
<s>   " book of shadows " feels incredibly controlled and restrict . 
<s>  here , very little is left to our imagination and the story is so complex and " clever " that the screenwriters are the first to get lost in it . 
<s>  there is is no book of shadows and no conclusion that we can be satisfied with . 
<s>  this is simply a less artistic film that doesn't have the talent and originality of its predecessor . 
<s>  it resorts to fancy cinematography and special effects to create the right effect and doesn't always succeed . 
<s>  but most importantly : it stands on its own ground and has almost no connection with the first movie , which doesn't allow it to destroy the original . 
<s>  in the end , i can't call it a bad effort . 
<s>  it's less artistic , not so scary and less original , but certainly not bad . 
<s>  it's simply different . 
<s>  in fact , if you haven't seen " the blair witch project " , you might like this film for what it is -- a cross between " the blair witch project " and the " scream " -films . 
<s>  the only element that remains constant and similar between the two films is the solid acting ( jeffrey donovan and tristine skyler should be mentioned ) and incredible sense of surrealism . 
<s>  but it's a common knowledge and experience that , with a few exceptions , every movie sequel is worse than the original and some are even not worth making . 
<s>  to me the story of " the blair witch project " seemed completed , but there are obviously no limits to commercial success that " the book of shadows " is certainly assured . 
<s>  and it's already time to look forward to " blair witch 3 " . 
<s>  seen may 31 , 1999 on home video ( rented ) . 
<s>  one of the best things about the movies is that they can make you really start to wonder and analyze things in your own , everyday life that you might not have thought much of otherwise . 
<s>  with some films it might be just a secondary issue , but with `dark city' what we get is nearly an entire film committed to philosophizing and theorizing about human memory and how it defines who we are , which is a poignant theme made through an absolutely beautifully-constructed film with the kind of story and setting that could only happen in a movie . 
<s>  there's an old role-playing computer game called `d ? ja v ? ' wherein the player takes on the role of a man who can't remember who he is , where he is and how he got there . 
<s>  the goal is to gather as many clues as possible to figure that out and along the way overcome a conflict . 
<s>  the premise to this film is not unlike that game , only this time we don't have control over the protagonist . 
<s>  we begin by meeting a seemingly ordinary man living in an extremely dark and dirty city ( actually , it's more than just the city , it's the whole reality ) that isn't just that neo-gothic look ( a la `batman , ' `blade runner , ' ) , but is so fully developed it's almost a different genre completely . 
<s>  later he will learn that his name is john murdoch ( sewell ) , but for now he has no idea what's going on other than the fact something is not right . 
<s>  the fact there's a dead body in the corner goes to enhance the feeling of paranoia and a mysterious , hurried call telling him to leave immediately is also very chilling . 
<s>  this opening scene alone goes a long way to define the setting of the film and its bizarre , horrific tone . 
<s>  the man doesn't know who he is nor where he's going and it's interesting to follow him since we the viewers have no idea either we can sympathize and identify with him . 
<s>  in fact , this is the way all stories begin since it's impossible to know the history of a character , their feelings , values , morals , etc . until after we've observed them for a while . 
<s>  but in this case , the total feeling of amnesia is an excellent tool towards characterization , developing the mood and outlining the story . 
<s>  eventually , some semblance of a plot begins to unfold as it appears that john is a serial killer wanted by the police . 
<s>  we met inspector frank bumstead ( hurt ) , a quiet , unemotional , soft-spoken deadpan man who appears to have been on the trail of the killer for some time . 
<s>  two other important characters are also introduced : dr . daniel p . schreber ( sutherland ) , a neurotic psychiatrist who claims to be john's doctor ; and emma murdoch ( connelly ) , a jazz singer dolled up to look like a caraciture right out of the old dick tracy serials or any given leading lady of the old film-noir movies . 
<s>  it was schreber who contacted john for reasons that are continually revealed throughout the course of the film . 
<s>  he also contacts emma , which further helps the film reveal what is seemingly a complex , mysterious back story . 
<s>  but absolutely nothing is as it appears to be in `dark city , ' which is what makes it so fascinating throughout its continual scenes of confusion and vertigo . 
<s>  everything the filmmakers want us to see has some significance - considering how intricate the detail is to every single shot , its lighting , art direction and overall production design , they don't seem to be able to afford any gratuities . 
<s>  however , that might also be what's keeping it from reaching its maximum potential . 
<s>  by continuing to follow john as he wanders around this strange place , so much unlike the real world we know , we come to realize that it's all a hoax . 
<s>  everyone in the city is the subject of an experiment being conducted by a race of aliens to understand what makes humans tick in their efforts to somehow save themselves from extinction . 
<s>  but , as the film's tagline says , `last night , one of us went off . ' 
<s>  for reasons that are never clearly explained , it appears that john possesses telekinetic powers to can do pretty much whatever his mind can conceive ( a process known as `tuning' ) . 
<s>  the aliens , which look like very old bald human men with pasty skin , also possess the power en masse and use it to change the city every night at midnight . 
<s>  at the same time all the humans fall asleep and after the changes are made , they awake and either continue where they left off or begin a new life they have no idea they did not have until then . 
<s>  this premise certainly is interesting and director and co-screenwriter alex proyas is able to keep the film consistently mysterious in this regard . 
<s>  he does provide some explanations such as that dr . schreber is an assistant to `the strangers' because he somehow could synthesize memory into chemical form . 
<s>  the aliens mix and match the memories of the city's population to see who will change and who will not . 
<s>  in the process this creates for a good deal of deep , thought-provoking philosophies that could be applied to the real world . 
<s>  however , where the film errs is by not playing up the idea of memory versus the human heart as to what makes a person who he or she is . 
<s>  the main characters are all closely intertwined within the seemingly complex murder mystery which never actually happened , yet when they start to go through some of the expected emotions it comes off as distant , static and cold ( mediocre performances by hurt and connelly don't help either ) . 
<s>  for example , john realizes emma is not and probably never was his wife so he does not feel an emotional bond to her , yet in some scenes crucial to the film's plot , we are expected to believe they do have a genuine love for each other , which is also part of the film's climax and ending . 
<s>  and that's what proyas seems to be inferring with the film , but never quite manages to convey in its fullest sense . 
<s>  ironically , this is what made his first film `the crow' work so well , which had a similar theme of struggling to find hope and the human spirit within a nearly identical , dark twisted world . 
<s>  with `dark city' the messenger seems to be mistaken for the message . 
<s>  still , the film is by no means bad and is consistently entertaining and enjoyable . 
<s>  there's a lot to like here , most notably the sheer visual look and style of it all which accounts for at least half the reasons the film is able to tell the story it does . 
<s>  the story as a whole is one of the most original to come out of hollywood in years . 
<s>  `dark city' is what the movies are all about - the escape from the real world . 
<s>  linda fiorentino disappeared off the radar after a deservedly heralded turn in the cable pic the last seduction , and her being cast as dogma's lead is nothing short of inexplicable . 
<s>  she's still in fine form as bethany , an abortion clinic worker who's lost her faith . 
<s>  one night , a visitor from heaven makes a fiery entrance in bethany's bedroom . 
<s>  he is metatron ( alan rickman ) , the voice of god , and he needs her help : she must stop two fallen angels from entering a new jersey church-the fate of the universe depends on it . 
<s>  god would do it him/herself , but he/she is . . . missing , having taken up human form somewhere on earth never to be heard from again . 
<s>  bethany is joined on her road trip to the garden state by the " prophets " jay ( jason mewes ) and silent bob ( kevin smith , doing double-duty ) , the slacker minstrels who have appeared in all of smith's films thus far . 
<s>  at some point , rock drops naked out of the sky as rufus , the undocumented ( and very black ) " thirteenth apostle " , and offers his assistance , as does divine stripper serendipity ( salma hayek ) . 
<s>  it's a wild ride . 
<s>  they're in pursuit of loki and bartleby ( damon and affleck , respectively-this is probably the sharpest either has ever been ) , who were banished from heaven to wisconsin and have discovered a dogmatic loophole that will enable their return . 
<s>  loki decides to wreak havoc along the way with the knowledge that his sins will be absolved at the pearly gates . 
<s>  at one point , he terrorizes a boardroom full of suits with an angry combination of words and bullets . 
<s>  it's a nasty , guiltily enjoyable little scene that asks , " how corrupt are you ? " . 
<s>  wings of desire this ain't . 
<s>  since debuting with clerks , smith has grown as a director , particularly in terms of working with actors . 
<s>   ( chris rock is this film's only weak link-between jokes , he's wooden . ) 
<s>  his no-frills visual style hasn't changed much over the years , though ( dogma's widescreen compositions at least have blockbuster affectations ) , nor has his writing-his characters still sit around delivering one caustic , hilarious speech after another . 
<s>  dogma chips away at big religious issues-namely , the hypocrisy that accompanies any organized system of beliefs-eloquently and articulately , but a few of the monologues sound too much like blatant exposition . 
<s>  as well , the verbal introduction of each new person seems to take forever . 
<s>  any movie with this much weighty talk would have a hard time maintaining momentum ( hurlyburly , anyone ? ) , and eventually dogma's pacing goes slack . 
<s>  a long diatribe from bartleby late in the game , in which he laments the destiny of celestial beings , comes at a point when we've heard enough . 
<s>  because his change of heart ( bartleby is initially the good cop to loki's bad ) drives the climax , said rant is given a great deal of screen time . 
<s>  sure , affleck deserved a big moment ( damon steals their scenes together prior ) , but it ultimately makes the film and us feel bloated . 
<s>  like tarantino , smith was a video-age sponge who became a sample-mad indie filmmaker . 
<s>  dogma pays welcome homage to an eclectic batch of movies , including indiana jones and the last crusade , with silent bob doing his best harrison ford , and weird science-a shit demon attacks our heroes ! 
<s>  smith also has a kitchen sink brand of humour : his dexterous maneuvering between the satirical ( a cardinal played by george carlin attempts to mount a publicity campaign with the slogan " catholicism wow ! " ) and the scatalogical ensures that no lover of comedy will leave dogma feeling malnourished . 
<s>  i bust ( ed ? ) a gut on several occasions . 
<s>  proceedings also get off on the right foot with the opening with the funniest disclaimer ever . 
<s>  it's a disclaimer unlikely to put protestors at ease , for to read it , one actually has to see dogma . 
<s>  the prerelease ballyhoo is in the tradition of the last temptation of christ's , martin scorsese's 1988 adaptation of nikos kazantzakis' controversial novel , in that it is not directly linked to the picture's content but to rumours and heresy . 
<s>  there's a famous anecdote about fletch director michael ritchie inviting picketers of the last temptation of christ into a screening on his dime , just so they could know for certain what they were rallying against . 
<s>   ( not one of them had watched it . ) 
<s>  every single person refused . 
<s>  smith and scorsese have a lot in common , and so do the two films in question , because both smith's bethany and scorsese's jesus are hollow shells without their faith . 
<s>  in fact , dogma's denouement ( which follows a thrilling showdown that's worth the wait ) is a catholic love-in , a veritable recruitment poster . 
<s>   ( i felt sentimental about a religion i don't belong to . 
<s>  now that's powerful filmmaking . ) smith is nothing if not sincere about his own devotion to god , and that spirituality shines through . 
<s>  it's enough to make me forgive dogma for its editorial sins . 
<s>  my religion is movies . 
<s>  when the catholic league beats on dogma for imaginary crimes against a doctrine , in a roundabout way they're attacking what i live for : freedom of expression through celluloid . 
<s>  i therefore feel that , although i'm no bible-thumper , i'm at least as qualified to criticize dogma as william donohue and his followers . 
<s>  you've heard all the hype . 
<s>  you've seen all their faces - natalie portman ( the professional ) as queen amidala , liam neeson ( schindler's list ) as qui-gon jinn , ewan mcgregor ( trainspotting ) as obi-wan kenobi , and jake lloyd ( jingle all the way ) as young anakin skywalker . 
<s>  if you've read any reviews , you've also probably heard that this movie fails to live up to the magic and humanity of the first trilogy . 
<s>  you also may have heard that this one's too kiddie-friendly , and doesn't have enough content for adults .

<s>  but there's something missing here , and it isn't budget or effects - it's everything money * can't * buy .

<s>  and obi-wan , although mcgregor makes him very endearing , has so little screen time that he's nothing but a robin to qui-gon jinn's batman . 
<s>  however , mcgregor does struggle manfully to infuse this surprisingly small supporting role with a spark of genuine insight and humanity , and he does a good job . 
<s>  he also absolutely nails alec guiness' ( obi-wan in episode 4 - 6 ) scottish accent , and that really makes his presence in the film more profound than it might have been otherwise . 
<s>  in fact , lucas seems to bank on that preexisting knowledge quite a bit , and that's one of the problems with this film . 
<s>  i would never call myself a " star wars " fan - especially not considering what it means to be a fanatic these days - but i've always enjoyed the films along with everyone else in america . 
<s>  however , if you are the one person in america who * hasn't * seen the films at all or even recently , or who doesn't bother to brush-up on the names of obscure characters , you may be hopelessly lost . 
<s>  for example , one of the film's main ( nefarious ) characters is senator palpatine . 
<s>  for those of you not recently steeped in " star wars " trivia , emperor palpatine is that scary hooded apparition who was darth vader's master in " return of the jedi " and " empire strikes back . " 
<s>  so , obviously , his appearance in " phantom menace " is meant to stir some echoes of his later role in the series , thus making his role here more meaningful . 
<s>  a lot of the movie is like that . 
<s>  r2-d2 and c-3po make token appearances , and it's obvious that lucas is banking on the audience's pre-existing fondness for them . . . 
<s>  because he doesn't do much to add to it in any way . 
<s>  same goes for jabba the hutt , who doesn't look as much mean here as he does corpulent and lazy . 
<s>  even * planets * make foreshadowing guest appearances in this film - tatooine ( the desert world where luke grew up ) , coruscant ( the cloud city from " empire strikes back " ) , and alderaan ( leia's home planet - which we never actually see - that gets blown up in " star wars " ) show up or are mentioned briefly in passing . 
<s>  what's the result of tying so many plot points and characters to future films ? 
<s>  the answer is that this one seems surprisingly empty . 
<s>  there's no meat - no substance - that makes you want to love the characters as they are , not as they will be . 
<s>  another problem is that there are actually * too many * alien characters in the film . 
<s>  i was distracted by the fact that two of the main evil characters - strange looking aliens who looked like gila monsters - had mouths that barely moved , making them look more like muppets than actual characters . 
<s>  and jar jar binks , a silly roger rabbitish amphibious character , is intended as comic relief , but what he really becomes is annoying - and fast . 
<s>  unlike chewbacca and c-3po , who got their humanity ( if you'll pardon the expression ) from their interactions with the human characters , jar jar is often left to interact mostly with others of his kind , at times making the movie seem like nothing more than a very expensive " teenage mutant ninja turtles . " 
<s>  furthermore , the dialogue is often stilted and corny , and sometimes downright infantile , thereby rendering some characters into nothing more than bystanders to the plot . 
<s>  oddly , this isn't just * my * judgment - lucas has said that he designed this film for kids . 
<s>  well , he's done a good job . 
<s>  the hero of this film , of course , is young anakin , but it was very hard for me to feel any kinship or identify with an eight-year-old boy . 
<s>  that's not jake lloyd's fault , though - he does a good job of being a cute kid , which is apparently all lucas asked of him . 
<s>  that's another mistake , of course , because the cute tyke becomes darth vader .

<s>   " his future is clouded . "

<s>  i would say no .

<s>  absolutely .

<s>  as african american detective vergil tibbs questions a suspected white murderer inside a jail cell , there is a wonderful , eye-catching shot which instantaneously presents the main message of the entire film . 
<s>  the shot has tibbs' face completely covered by the shadows of the prison bars . 
<s>  to see these bars blocking his face , we see how separated tibbs is from the rest of the characters in the film . 
<s>  as a black detective conducting an investigation in a southern town full of violent white bigots , no matter how innocent tibbs is , he is still seen by these bigots as a threat simply because of the color of his skin . 
<s>  the bars show that tibbs has not been given a fair chance to show exactly who he is , instead others have chosen him as different and dangerous . 
<s>  this one shot amazes me because it captures a whole theme in a matter of seconds . 
<s>  it perhaps may be the most powerful image i have seen in a film . 
<s>   " in the heat of the night " was the first and the best of the three films norman jewison directed concerning racism in america . 
<s>  jewison has a very keen style of displaying various cases of racism as he is neither pedantic nor overly sentimental . 
<s>  in these three films he does an excellent job creating very detailed equal analyses of characters from the abused to the abusers . 
<s>  he is also not afraid to tell the absolute truth about how corrupt society was in the past and is in the present . 
<s>  preceding the very original " a soldier's story " and the recently released " the hurricane , " " in the heat of the night contains some classic lines and some very memorable characters . 
<s>  the film , which won best picture in 1967 focuses on vergil tibbs , played superbly by sidney poitier as a fearless african american police officer from philadelphia who refuses to give up on an investigation in a white town where is he not wanted . 
<s>  tibbs is a man who rarely loses his temper and that is worth mentioning because he is constantly facing abuse from those around him . 
<s>  as a hero who is not afraid to face off against five men with chains , tibbs is the perfect protagonist . 
<s>  poitier also gives an excellent , noteworthy voice to his character . 
<s>  never nervous and always commanding , his speech patterns are very manipulative as they range from stentorian to soothing . 
<s>  however , unlike " the hurricane " where denzel washington dominated over the rest of the cast , poitier shares the spotlight with rod steiger , who won best actor for his excellent performance . 
<s>  as a sheriff who helps tibbs and warns him of the dangers around him , steiger shows a great amount of skill in his role . 
<s>  he starts off as racist and blind as the other townspeople . 
<s>  he would refer to tibbs as " boy " and would always suspiciously keep an eye on him . 
<s>  as the film progresses though , there is a very gradual change in the sheriff . 
<s>  he begins to see the hardships tibbs faces and he sees the foolishness of his own neighbors . 
<s>  what i really enjoyed about steiger's character was that he did not completely abandon his friends or connect with tibbs at the end of the film . 
<s>  he still could not refer to tibbs as mister tibbs or officer tibbs but rather settled for virgil . 
<s>  instead , it was apparent that he was eventually going to see the world differently in the future . 
<s>  most movies would have a character reversing all of his beliefs and influences in a matter of minutes . 
<s>  this action would not have been realistic at all since it is nearly impossible for someone to believe something one day and believe something else the next day . 
<s>  jewison's determination to make this film as realistic as possible is very obvious here and also very appropriate . 
<s>   " in the heat of the night " shows the difference between the north and the south or a major city and a small town in the united states during the 1960's . 
<s>  it displays this perfectly . 
<s>  however , the actual investigation , although it is not the main focus of the film , lacks interest . 
<s>  it seemed rushed especially towards the end as if jewison had given his message about racism and did not feel like giving a credible explanation involving the murder victim . 
<s>  there were way too many characters added during the last fifteen minutes and some of the scenes during this time period were inane ( police officer sam being a suspect was not needed ) . 
<s>  also , it is given that tibbs is a vigilant homicide detective who is the best at what he does , but some of his discoveries came out of nowhere and how he found out some of the important case details towards the end were never answered . 
<s>  the rushed ending was the only mistake of this otherwise memorable jewison classic . 
<s>   ( a congratulations has to be given to actor scott wilson . 
<s>  he managed to be in the two best movies of 1967 , " in the heat of the night " and the even better " in cold blood . " ) 
<s>  in wonder boys michael douglas plays an aged writer \ professor with such lived-in naturalism that i believe it may be his best performance . 
<s>  ever since wall street , douglas has spent the greater part of his career playing variations on the shark in a suit gordon gecko character he personified in the mid-80's . 
<s>  in those performances he tended to exaggerate the vehemence of cutthroat businessmen , with much frothing at the mouth while projecting all his bad intentions to the world . 
<s>  you'd think such a man would keep his evil wrapped tightly underneath a good-natured veneer , but from gordon gecko to nicholas van orton , douglas played the role straight and out in the open . 
<s>  in wonder boys his performance isn't showy or a tour de force , it's simple yet truthful . 
<s>  he embodies grady , a craggy old writer with a predilection for pot and pink bathrobes . 
<s>  grady instructs a writers workshop while working tirelessly on a follow up to the novel that put him on the map . 
<s>  when we first encounter this curmudgeon in the midst of his workshop , we hear his sardonic narration on the soundtrack as students bombard one of their own with unfair criticisms . 
<s>  grady points out , in his narration , that they only do so out of jealousy . 
<s>  their target is the very writerly named james leer ( played by the always understated tobey maguire ) , a student full of potential and one whom grady develops a mild affection for . 
<s>  leer is the kind of youth who seems to mechanically block out emotions . 
<s>  he speaks in an intellectualized monotone with just a hint of dry wit around the edges . 
<s>  he's portentous and gloomy , as if modeling himself after the great depressed writers , though his act is a little too calculated . 
<s>  he reminds me of the self-imposed outcast film director , jim jarmusch ( dead man , ghost dog ) . 
<s>  whenever i happen to catch jarmusch in an interview i see the man speaking in a toneless manner ( the monotonous drawl supposedly masking depth or contempt for his interviewer ) , exclusively dressed in black , and with his spiked hair dyed snow white . 
<s>  leer is similar , a guy who equates quirks with depth . 
<s>  tobey maguire fits well in the role . 
<s>  with his round , sweet-eerie face he resembles bud cort from harold and maude . 
<s>  but unlike cort , maguire is easier to warm up to ; he's a messed up kid reaching for artistic credibility . 
<s>  katie holmes plays hannah , a beautiful , talented writing student just itching to get in grady's pants . 
<s>  this is a plot line i had trouble with . 
<s>  douglas , in his old age , is beginning to resemble jerry springer , a man who has actually paid for sex on numerous documented occasions . 
<s>  at first i found it extremely difficult to believe that someone as beautiful as hannah would desire grady ( maybe it's because i'm jealous , and wish holmes was throwing herself at me , after all i may just be a lowly internet critic but at least i still have all my teeth ) , then i think of douglas's real life companion , the breathtaking catherine zeta jones . 
<s>  seeing those two together looks a lot like a kidnapping . 
<s>  suddenly my mind has shifted from the task at hand ( that being reviewing this completely wonderful movie ) and i'm pontificating on why the hell jones would desire douglas . 
<s>  there is a movie in there somewhere . 
<s>  grady , rather chivalrously if you ask me , resists the charms of hannah for sara gaskell ( a droll frances mcdormand ) , who is his age , but also married to another professor . 
<s>  okay , maybe not so chivalrous . 
<s>  there is a great line in the film spoken by douglas about sara where he says , " she was a junkie for the printed word . 
<s>  lucky for me i manufactured her drug of choice " . 
<s>  robert downy j . r plays a bisexual editor who makes his entrance with a towering transvestite on his arm . 
<s>  downy has mastered the gleefully dry hyper articulate wit of many a hipster intellectual . 
<s>  he's arrogant but completely likeable in his utter arrogance . 
<s>  the actor is perfectly cast here , and remains a joyous movie presence somewhere between a typical tom hanksian comic leading man and edgy character actor . 
<s>  i wish wonder boys had more of him . 
<s>  searching for a plot among the elements of wonder boys would be pointless , for it meanders through its running time , but that's part of its charm . 
<s>  and maybe i'm a bit biased towards the film because it takes place in a haven of literary academia , a place i'm greatly fond of , and a place rarely explored in american cinema . 
<s>  everyone has a sub-genre ( be it war films , westerns , dance movies ) that they happen to be privy to . 
<s>  i'm privy to films about literary types i . e . 
<s>  those individuals enthralled by the written word , and if you are not so inclined it may be wise to knock my above grade down about half a notch . 
<s>  the direction by curtis hanson is more akin to a european film with its leisurely pace and situations that grow from the characters , rather than generic mapped out story points . 
<s>  sometimes the dialogue is too clever , but that's a problem i wish i found with films more often . 
<s>  another minor quibble is that early on the film seems a bit too introverted , like its characters , but as the story progresses it begins to open up . 
<s>  for me wonder boys works as subtle drama because of its insight into artistic types , and as a low-key comedy for its chuckle-worthy throwaway gags . 
<s>  the gags are like those in the great robert altman ( m * a * s * h , the long goodbye ) movies , where jokes exist as asides on the fringes , like jokes in life often do . 
<s>  the broader comedy such as the killing of a blind dog , and incessant smoking of marijuana isn't ineffective but not nearly as memorable as the little things . 
<s>  curtis hanson , who before his last film , la confidential , toiled about with exploitation fare like losin' it ( an early tom cruise sex comedy ) and the hand the rocks the cradle , has graduated to more meaningful films . 
<s>  he directs wonder boys in an appropriately dour style , the comedy coming from the false gloom his characters put up . 
<s>  the morose crooning of leonard cohen would seem an odd song for the background of any party , but in a wonder boys party , it fits . 
<s>  the film is like a piece of literature put up on the big screen . 
<s>  it's the cinematic equivalent to a good read , novelistic in its approach with themes rarely found in american movies . 
<s>  many will find it slight , but i found much to savor among its subtleties .

<s>  critique : there's a place in our world for " stupid comedies " . 
<s>  films which don't pretend to take themselves seriously , are based on idiotic premises and filled with dumb jokes . 
<s>  there's also a time for them and many would argue that this difficult period of our history , might be an ideal circumstance during which to " relax " by watching something so completely frivolous . 
<s>  well , if you're in the mood for some seriously mindless entertainment , ben stiller and his cast of many have assembled one of the more original dumb comedies in some time . 
<s>  of course , comedies as such are usually very subjective and i could see how some will see this film simply as stupid and unfunny , while others will grant them the " stupid " , but consider it funny instead . 
<s>  i personally enjoyed it for the most part , cracked up loudly during a couple of specific sequences and loved the derek zoolander character and the unrestrained whipping they released upon the fashion industry .

<s>  it was also nice to see several real-life models with small roles in the movie , not taking themselves too seriously . 
<s>  and if you're the type of person who likes celebrity cameos in films , well , don't look any further because dozens of famous faces show up here including vince vaughn , billy zane , winona ryder , christian slater , david duchovny , natalie portman and many , many others .

<s>  unzipped is a cinematic portrait of isaac mizrahi , an artist whose palette is fabric . 
<s>  ostensibly , the film is a documentary , but use of that term requires stretching its meaning . 
<s>  many scenes appear staged , and a great deal of cutting-and-pasting has been done in the editing room . 
<s>  the cinema verite effect is a conceit -- genuine spontaneity is at a premium , and everyone is aware of and playing to the camera ( especially would-be actresses like cindy crawford ) . 
<s>  director douglas keeve ( who was mizrahi's lover at the time ) freely admits that he " couldn't care less about the truth " but was more interested in capturing " the spirit and love in isaac and in fashion . " 
<s>  despite violating nearly every rule of " legitimate " documentary film making , however , unzipped is a remarkably enjoyable piece of entertainment . 
<s>  while it sheds only a little light on the behind-the-scenes world of the fashion industry , it presents a fascinating , if incomplete , picture of designer mizrahi . 
<s>  this man is the perfect subject for this kind of study -- he's funny , energetic , and eminently quotable . 
<s>  he has unusual views on just about everything , from fashion ( " it's about women not wanting to look like cows " ) to mary tyler moore ( " between her and jackie kennedy , they shaped this country " ) to style ( " it's almost impossible to have style nowadays without the right dogs " ) . 
<s>  unzipped also gives a glimpse into the creative process by which mizrahi turns an idea into a dress . 
<s>  it's almost certainly different that anyone would imagine . 
<s>  the designer draws on a variety of sources for his look , including nanook of the north and old bette davis movies , then enlists the aid of a ouija board to help form the collection .

<s>  good will hunting has all three .

<s>  if there's one thing in common about all of hollywood's major studios , it's that their productions are moving toward mainstream more and more . 
<s>  although twentieth century fox and new line cinema have spawned subsidiaries which specialize in independant or controversial motion pictures ( fox searchlight and fine line respectively ) , it's obvious there's no significant movement underway to promote inventive ideas at the theater . 
<s>  so when a movie like gary ross' pleasantville comes along , wrapped in a blanket of innovative ideas and served up on a platter of fine production , it's a welcome change of pace for all who frequent the cineplexes . 
<s>  although the atmosphere and buzz about the movie are cheery and lighthearted , pleasantville should not be mistaken for a no-thought movie . 
<s>  quite the opposite is true , in fact , as director ross skillfully brings a narrative with intense and intelligent undertones to the screen . 
<s>  the story , both about the joys of living life to the fullest as well as the social ills of segregation , captures the essence of statement-making in the cinema . 
<s>  not in recent memory has a movie carried such weight of theme into widescale distribution , and even if mass audiences fail to see the ingenuity of ross' work , it is still a testament that his picture was considered worthy enough . 
<s>  kudos to both he and his production staff for putting together this fine picture . 
<s>  it stars tobey maguire and reese witherspoon as two nineties teenagers who , through quite a bit of luck , find themselves zapped into a fifties sitcom named " pleasantville . " 
<s>  maguire , as the reserved bud parker , is perfect for the pseudo-world ; but the rebellious mary sue ( witherspoon ) is not at all made for the father-knows-best times . 
<s>  it's not long before she sets the town of pleasantville on end , and begins to teach the townspeople - in a quite unlikely way - what life is * really * like . 
<s>  soon hues of color creep into the black and white world , and while some embrace the change in the passion of realism , others fear the strangeness . 
<s>  at one end is a soda shop owner-turned-painter named mr . johnson ( jeff daniels ) and at the other end is a close-minded mayor ( j . t . 
<s>  walsh ) and his chamber of commerce ; but the two sides are simply fronts for a clash of ideas that soon involves the entire town . 
<s>  fine performances are turned in all around . 
<s>  maguire and witherspoon are effective as the leads , but the true complements go out to jeff daniels and j . t . 
<s>  walsh ( in his latest and final posthumous performance ) . 
<s>  daniels brings an atmosphere of awe , inspiration , and hope to his character , whereas walsh simply drips of sinister closemindedness - almost to the point where you can sense gene hackman's envy . 
<s>  for daniels , it's his most commendable performance of the last three years - or more - and for walsh , it's a complementary exclamation point on a fine career . 
<s>  also of lesser note is the supporting role by joan allen , and in viewing the entire cast works well together from start to finish . 
<s>  there's not much to dislike about pleasantville , and its dynamic nature makes it the perfect movie for those who want serious as well as those who don't . 
<s>  what do you get when you slap together a movie based on a story by the legendary george lucas , directed by virtuoso director steven spielberg , and starring one of the biggest box-office stars in the world , harrison ford ? 
<s>  you get one hot-fudge-rockin' good time , that's what you get ! ! ! 
<s>  plot : professor/archeologist indiana jones sets out to find the long-lost mystical ark of the covenant before the nazis get their grubby fingers hands on it . 
<s>  adventures , snakes , romance and mucho action ensues . 
<s>  critique : astounding movie packed with non-stop action , stunts galore , an interesting story line , great one-liners , a solid cast , a catchy musical score , and all the fun and adventure that you could squeeze into a two-hour thrill ride . 
<s>  if you don't enjoy this film , then you just don't like action movies , period ! 
<s>  if you're young , you'll enjoy its humor , its cool action sequences and its gross-out factor at times . 
<s>  if you're a little older , you'll appreciate the interesting plot line , the romance , and yes , the mountains of adventure . 
<s>  watching this movie made me feel like a kid again , dreaming and fantasizing about fighting the bad guys , travelling to different countries , making the impossible , possible ! 
<s>  harrison ford is perfect as the every-man with the brains of a scientist and the brawn of an outdoors adventurer , and spielberg manages to achieve the ideal balance of action , fun , adventure and humor .

<s>  little known facts about this film and its stars : this picture was nominated for eight 1981 oscar nominations , including best picture . 
<s>  it lost that award to chariots of fire , but did manage to win for best art direction , best special effects , best film editing and best sound . 
<s>  actor tom selleck was originally cast as indiana jones , but was committed to his hit tv show , " magnum p . i . " . 
<s>  in filming the well of souls sequence , the producers scoured every pet shop in london and the south of england for every snake they could lay their hands on . 
<s>  hence there are snakes that are identifiable from many different geographical areas . 
<s>  however , once all the snakes were on set , it became clear that there were not nearly enough of them , so spielberg had several hoses cut into lengths , and these were used as well . 
<s>  looking closely , you can tell which are the real snakes and which are not . 
<s>  an early draft of the script had indy travelling to shanghai to recover a piece of the staff of ra . 
<s>  during his escape from the museum where it was housed , he sheltered from machine gun fire behind a giant rolling gong . 
<s>  also in the same script , indy and marion flee the chaos caused by the opening of the ark in a wild mine-cart chase sequence . 
<s>  both of these scenes were cut from the script , but ended up in 1984's indiana jones and the temple of doom . 
<s>  this film begins with a shot of a peak in the jungle which is reminiscent of the paramount pictures logo . 
<s>  the same type of opening is present in its sequels . 
<s>  jock's airplane at the beginning of the film has the registration number " ob-cpo " . 
<s>  this is a reference to obi-wan and c-3po from george lucas' star wars ( 9 . 5/10 ) . 
<s>  also , the hieroglyphics in the well of souls include engravings of r2-d2 and c-3po . 
<s>  they can be seen on a post to the right of indy and sallah as they remove the ark . 
<s>  the script originally included a long fight between a swordsman and indiana with his whip . 
<s>  as legend has it , actor harrison ford was suffering diarrhea at the time , and asked if the scene could be shortened . 
<s>  spielberg said the only way he could shorten it was if indy pulled out his gun and just shot the guy . 
<s>  the entire crew laughed and that's how it was filmed . 
<s>  when indy first falls in the well of souls and is face to face with the cobra , you can see the snake's reflection on the glass dividing it and harrison ford , also some fingerprints and stuff like that . 
<s>  when indy is dragging along the ground , hanging onto the nazi soldier's truck with the ark inside , you can see the pad that he's being dragged on .

<s>  tings don't run we . ' 
<s>  -sound advice from capone ( paul campbell ) to his squaddie ( or partner ) , floyd ( winston bell ) . 
<s>  jamaican film , shot entirely on video , featuring a standard cop movie plot mixed with a dash of john woo-styled brotherhood morals ( and a little gunplay ) . 
<s>  capone , a tough as nails super cop , gets a transfer back to his hometown of kingston after successfully taking down some gangsters that have broken into his home ( while he was with his lady ) and killed his partner in front of him . 
<s>  when he arrives , he discovers that the ghetto where he grew up has gotten worse , thanks mainly to the crime boss wonie ( jamaican film veteran carl bradshaw ) , so named because his left hand has been amputated and replaced by a grasping hook ) . 
<s>  capone discovers that wonie has been smuggling guns inside shipments of charity supplies for the area churches and , much to his disappointment , also finds out his childhood friend ratty ( mark danvers ) has been helping him . 
<s>  torn between doing his job and protecting his best friend , capone must make some hard decisions in order to make things right again . 
<s>  directed deftly by first time jamaican filmmaker chris browne ( assistant director for such american films as how stella got her groove back and instinct ) , one hardly notices the film was shot on video after a while . 
<s>  shots are handled so efficiently that they quickly take on the nuances of the aforementioned john woo films , although the action isn't as hyperkinetic as most of woo's films are . 
<s>  the action scenes are handled with a kind of flair though , and eventually begin to take on a life of their own ( beyond the hong kong films that they are obviously patterned after ) . 
<s>  the make-up effects are particularly good in these scenes as well , with flawless squib work on display from the effects team . 
<s>  the cast is superb and listening to their dialogue , spoken with thick jamaican accents ( half of which have to be subtitled because of their extensive use of slang ) , just adds to the interest . 
<s>  paul campbell , as the `loose cannon' capone , essays his role perfectly , displaying the right amount of menace and compassion at the right times . 
<s>  mark danvers evokes sympathy as ratty , the part-time gun smuggler who is also trying to help the community by building football fields and organizing block parties to bring people together . 
<s>  unfortunately , carl bradshaw is given the least to do and his character as the crime boss seems ineffective ( largely because his underlings seem to run all over him ) , but then again , that could be the way his character was intended to be portrayed . 
<s>  the music in the film is composed of all reggae songs , and the soundtrack was produced by grammy award winning artists , sly and robbie ( who have worked with the likes of the rolling stones , maxi priest , bob dylan , james brown , grace jones , herbie hancock , bootsy collins , and carly simon among others ) . 
<s>  the end credit song , `we run tings' , by the group red dragon , is pretty decent and carries on the theme of the movie established early on by the quote that opens this review . 
<s>  oddly enough , desmond ballentine ( who plays the character deportee ) is well known as a pioneer in the realm of `gangsta' reggae as the performer ninjaman , and he doesn't contribute a single song to the film ( that i could see ) , which is virtually unheard of here in the us . 
<s>  at the time of this writing , third world cop has been put into limited theatrical release in the us , coming off of a six-month box-office breaking run in jamaica , where it holds the position as highest grossing film of all time ( bringing in $21 million in jamaica , which is roughly $500 , 000 us ) . 
<s>  palm pictures ( the company that released the offbeat , but entertaining six-string samurai ) is the company releasing the film and considering that their main focus is the dvd market , i can imagine that a disc will be available once the film has left theaters . 
<s>  chris blackwell , founder of palm pictures , was also involved in the production of another jamaican box-office smash in 1981 entitled countryman , so i'd say he has a pretty good track record . 
<s>  overall , third world cop is a pretty entertaining homage to the films of john woo , ringo lam , tsui hark , and many other action films by directors from hong kong .

<s>  at first glance , it appears that the home alone movies are brainless slapstick intended for those with minds of 8-year olds .

<s>  but home alone actually has a lot going for it , and the cartoon slapstick doesn't get in the way .

<s>  four adults and eleven kids are spending the night together before heading to the airport en masse . 
<s>  the littlest kid , kevin , is the victim of the older kids' cruelty . 
<s>  kevin's patience runs out when he learns that his plain-cheese pizza has already been eaten , and he's going to have to starve . 
<s>  he attacks his big bully brother buzz , who had been teasing him . 
<s>  the fight disrupts the already-chaotic dinner , spilling milk and soft drinks all over the table , a few cousins , and an uncle . 
<s>  the knee-jerk reaction is for everyone to blame kevin .

<s>  in a surprisingly plausible setup , kevin is mistakenly accounted for , and the family heads off without him . 
<s>  it's interesting that , in a subtle way , his parents never noticed him missing because of their deliberate desire to separate themselves from their children . 
<s>  first they delegate the headcount to an older sibling , and second , they put all the kids in coach while they fly first class . 
<s>  they're two-thirds of the way across the atlantic before they realize they are missing a child . 
<s>  meanwhile , kevin believes that somehow his wish has come true . 
<s>  he's finally rid of his family !

<s>  he also starts to miss his family , not just for their company , but for the security they bring . 
<s>  the furnace in the basement is a scary monster , the old man next door is a snow-shovel murderer , and two crooks are trying to break into his house . 
<s>  macaulay culkin is cute but he isn't much of an actor . 
<s>  still , we can see that kevin's character grows , thanks to some good direction and editing .

<s>  they talk about their fears and kevin learns that age alone does not make you less afraid . 
<s>  finally , in the last 20 minutes , kevin confronts his last fear - the bandits , head on ( literally ) . 
<s>  this last act is full of violent comedic slapstick , and after the movie's genuine dramatic setup , it is dessert . 
<s>  it's a lot of fun , and it doesn't overwhelm the rest of the movie . 
<s>  on the whole , home alone is a great holiday movie .

<s>  but it does have its flaws .

<s>  the biggest problem is that during the cartoony coda , the villains threaten kevin's life about five times .

<s>  coppola's most notable--and effective--contribution to the tried-and-true grisham formula is a sense of humor about itself , which largely comes in the presence of danny devito ( as rudy's unlicensed co-counsel ) and golden globe nominee jon voight ( as the insurance company's hotshot attorney ) . 
<s>  the inclusion of the battered wife subplot feels rather superfluous , but danes is as superb as always . 
<s>  then , of course , there is damon , who nicely juggles the weighty ( the insurance case , the spousal abuse ) and the humorous ( rudy's often comical naivete ) requirements of his role without missing a beat . 
<s>  as good as he is in the rainmaker , damon showcases the depth of his talent in good will hunting , directed by gus van sant and written by actor ben affleck and damon himself . 
<s>  damon plays the title character , will hunting , a troubled young construction worker/janitor at mit who also happens to be a supergenius . 
<s>  in an attempt to steer this brilliant young mind in the right direction , an mit math professor ( stellan skarsgard ) taps his old college friend , community college psychologist sean mcguire ( robin williams ) , to counsel the abrasive , standoffish will and try to help him come to terms with his turbulent life . 
<s>  good will hunting is the touchy-feely enterprise its plot synopsis suggests , but to simply dismiss it as that would be to discount the true emotional chords affleck and damon's intelligent script touches . 
<s>  even though no one ( and , if so , _very_ few people ) can directly relate to will's burden of superhuman intelligence , the insecurities he suffers are universal . 
<s>  the material is brought to life by the terrific ensemble of actors . 
<s>  williams delivers a nice dramatic turn ; affleck , a hot up-and-coming actor himself ( chasing amy ) , turns up in a warm and charming performance as will's best friend ; and the ever-appealing minnie driver shines as will's harvard-schooled love interest . 
<s>  the clear standout in the cast , though , is damon , who bravely does not soften will's prickly nature but has such a natural ease with the audience that it is hard _not_ to care for him . 
<s>  so many names come and go with the fluctuations of the hollywood hype machine , but based on his impressive work in john grisham's the rainmaker and especially good will hunting , it is a safe bet that matt damon is one name we will be hearing a lot more of in the years to come . 
<s>  synopsis : leonard shelby ( pearce ) is a former insurance investigator on the trail of the man who killed his wife . 
<s>  leonard has only a few clues to the murderer's identity ; to make matters worse , he suffers from a condition which inhibits the creation of short-term memories , meaning that leonard is always forgetting what happened just minutes earlier . 
<s>  because of this , leonard is forced to rely on notes he leaves for himself . 
<s>   " memento " traces the investigation back in time from its apparent culmination . 
<s>  review : " memento " is the sort of movie i wish i'd written ; i can think of no higher praise than that . 
<s>  i am envious that nolan has concocted such a brilliant , involved , original movie as this . 
<s>  an instant film noir classic , " memento " is virtually flawless . 
<s>  the script is unlike any i have ever seen -- a notable achievement in these days of recycled hollywood homogeneity . 
<s>  although the idea of starting at the " conclusion " of the plotline and then moving backward in time to the " start " is not entirely new , never before have i witnessed it executed with such flair and coherence . 
<s>   " memento " is endlessly exciting and inventive , a rare story which keeps the viewers guessing during the film itself , and mulling over its connotations long after leaving the theatre . 
<s>  and it is not merely an exercise in cerebrality ; there is plenty of action and an unexpected dose of humour to keep the proceedings lively . 
<s>  nolan's direction is equally effective , never losing its crispness and clarity despite " memento " 's challenging gimmick . 
<s>  and to top everything off , all the performances rise to the occasion . 
<s>  pierce is terrific as the troubled leonard ; moss shows great range as enigmatic natalie ; and pantoliano's teddy achieves a splendidly affable yet sinister quality . 
<s>   " memento " may be the year's best screenplay , and is certainly amongst the top theatrical attractions of 2001 . 
<s>  earth is a harsh , unconsoling drama about the time when india gained independence from britain and the ensuing turmoil that engulfed the subcontinent . 
<s>  people who supposedly loved the same land and the same god found themselves in bitter conflict , as the country divided into factions fighting in the streets : indian and pakistani ; muslim , hindu , sikh , parsee . 
<s>  the story takes place in lahore , which was indian before partition , and pakistani afterward , regardless of what its citizens might call themselves . 
<s>  the action is seen through the eyes of lenny ( maaia sethna ) , a young parsee girl , but it is really about her nanny , shanta . 
<s>  shanta has a small circle of male admirers . 
<s>  two of the men are suitors : hasan ( rahul khanna ) , a hindu , and dil navaz ( aamir khan ) , a muslim . 
<s>  the others--sikh , hindu , muslim--are older ; some are married ; but all appreciate shanta , who is played by the stirringly beautiful nandita das . 
<s>   ( she also starred in deepa mehta's previous film , fire , the first part of a thematic trilogy which will conclude with water . ) 
<s>  in an early scene , the men are sitting in a park talking with shanta and lenny ; political tension in the country is growing as the day of independence nears . 
<s>  one of the men remarks , jokingly , that their little group is probably one of the last places in the city where the different religions can still get along . 
<s>  he is wrong : the men make barbed little comments to each other , spoken like jokes , but with an undercurrent of fanaticism . 
<s>  the tenor of these exchanges grows darker and more bitter as the movie progresses . 
<s>  it is easy to perceive , in these squabbles , the trajectory which ends in mass violence and slaughter . 
<s>  the group around shanta represents , in a sense , a united india , and shanta herself the ideal motherland--one which all love , which inspires hindu , muslim , and sikh to live peacably together . 
<s>  but the circle around shanta is sundered , as is the state . 
<s>  a sikh is persecuted , hides , then flees . 
<s>  another man is murdered . 
<s>  the group of friends will not meet again . 
<s>  the movie is rife with images of breakage and destruction : a plate shattered on the floor , a stuffed toy torn apart by an upset child , and , most brutally , when the tension escalates into violence , a man is held down , tied between two cars , and ripped in half by the opposing movement of the vehicles . 
<s>  it is a visceral and effective metaphor for a country which is being destroyed just as painfully . 
<s>  the crux of earth's plot is the transformation undergone by dil navaz . 
<s>  his sisters are killed in brutal fashion , by hindus , because they are muslim . 
<s>  dil navaz seeks solace from shanta , and asks in desperation that she marry him . 
<s>  but she loves hasan , and tenderly refuses dil navaz's offer . 
<s>  the combination of familial anguish and romantic rejection twists inside him , and it is easy to see how he is seduced by the growing mob mentality : the muslim cause gives him a motive to vent his anger and hate . 
<s>  despite the things he later does , it is to the credit of earth that it does not simply denounce dil navaz and those like him , but shows how circumstances can make decent enough men do monstrous things . 
<s>  the conclusion--the consequence of dil navaz's transformation--is rather abrupt . 
<s>  the story earth tells does not end . 
<s>  it just stops . 
<s>  it is an appropriate finish : giving us closure would have imparted , at least on an aesthetic level , a sense of resolution , of satisfaction . 
<s>  but there was no resolution for india and pakistan--they have been at war , on a small or large scale , for decades . 
<s>  since the personal dramas in earth mirror the political struggles of a nation , it is only right that those dramas should have no terminus . 
<s>  there is no healing to be had , no closure , on any level ( despite the needless , tacked-on ending , with voice-over narration from lenny as an adult , framing the story ) . 
<s>  earth is , in some ways , an unexceptional movie . 
<s>  it does not reinvent the wheel , following instead the standard pattern of historical dramas . 
<s>  but deepa mehta's directon is assured , and the issues she addresses run deep . 
<s>  earth does for india what movies like zhang yimou's to live and tian zhuangzhuang's the blue kite did for china : they show us the agonies endured by unremarkable people who had the bad luck to be caught up and smashed in the crucible of history . 
<s>  such films strike me as inherently valuable , even when flawed . 
<s>  they may be biased or inaccurate , but they bear the weight of human hardship , and this confers on them a nobility and gravity which other , more inventive films , often lack . 
<s>  it is notable that all three movies were banned in their native countries : the events shown may have happened decades ago , but they still touch a nerve . 
<s>  the issues tackled in earth have a particular urgency in light of the nuclear test bombings that took place last year . 
<s>  in the near future , india and pakistan may launch nuclear missiles at each other . 
<s>  at the time of the tests i had some understanding of the reasons why this might happen ; after seeing earth , i have a much , much better understanding . 
<s>  up until about a year ago , john travolta's career consisted of those " look who's talking " movies ( notice how they never called them look who's talented ) and the 1991 bomb shout ( which was bad enough to make most people scream ) .

<s>  the disney studios has its formula for annual , full-length animated features down so pat that it's hard to remember which one you're watching at any given moment .

<s>  however , after about an hour everything comes together and the formula , like it or not , clicks .
