<s>  the computer-animated comedy " shrek " is designed to be enjoyed on different levels by different groups . 
<s>  for children , it offers imaginative visuals , appealing new characters mixed with a host of familiar faces , loads of action and a barrage of big laughs ( including numerous gags related to body functions and yucky substances , apparently a requisite in contemporary family films ) . 
<s>  for adults , it's a fractured fairy tale packed with rude jokes that will sail over the heads of the kids . 
<s>  all in all , " shrek " is a snappy ride , although there are a couple of points i found disturbing . 
<s>  but first the basics . 
<s>  based very loosely on a 1990 children's story , " shrek " follows several momentous days in the life of the title character , a rotund green ogre voiced by mike myers in that pleasant scottish accent he is so fond of using . 
<s>  shrek is a grumpy fellow living a solitary life deep in the swamp , until a local nobleman disturbs his peace . 
<s>  petty tyrant lord farquaad ( take away the " awk " in the middle and you have the basis of a string of impolite one-liners ) owns the land on which shrek resides . 
<s>  he proceeds to turn the ogre's yard into an ellis island for storybook characters when he banishes the fanciful beings from his castle . 
<s>  as a result , shrek finds himself surrounded by legends like the three blind mice , pinocchio , the big bad wolf , the seven dwarfs , and the three bears , to name but a few . 
<s>  an enraged shrek storms to the castle , only to find farquaad ( john lithgow ) ready to bargain . 
<s>  lord obnoxious wants to become king and the magic mirror from " snow white " has shown him the way . 
<s>  all he has to do is rescue a damsel in distress and make her his wife . 
<s>  the mirror unveils three choices in a presentation straight out of " the dating game " ( when snow white is shown , the cheeky announcer purrs , " even though she lives with seven men , she's not easy ! " ) 
<s>  farquaad selects the lovely princess fiona ( cameron diaz ) and offers shrek a deal : if the ogre snatches fiona from the dragon-protected , lava moat-filled castle in which she is held captive and brings her to the throne , the lord will allow the fairy tale pests to move back on his grounds . 
<s>  shrek reluctantly agrees and sets off on his quest , accompanied by a motor-mouthed donkey ( eddie murphy ) determined to make the green grump his best friend . 
<s>  they finally hook up with the princess , only to learn she is not the helpless maiden they expected to meet . 
<s>  for the matter , the dragon offers a few surprises as well . 
<s>  the movie references a great many other flicks , from " babe " ( " that'll do , donkey . 
<s>  that'll do " ) to " the graduate . " 
<s>  but the lion's share of the jokes come at the expense of the wonderful world of disney . 
<s>  the public-domain characters made into icons in various disney films take their hits ? pinocchio is referred to as a " possessed toy " and when shrek spies a sleeping snow white in his cabin , he bellows , " get that dead broad off the table ! " 
<s>   ? but the biggest slams come when shrek visits farquaad's royal domicile , which closely resembles a certain magic kingdom , from its souvenir stands and queue lines to a display of animatronic figures that sing the palace rules in a relentlessly peppy tune that sounds a lot like " it's a small world . " 
<s>  which brings me to disturbing point number one . 
<s>  i laughed at all the disney swipes , but found the mentality behind them a bit sad . 
<s>  the acrimony between dreamworks honcho jeff katzenberg and disney big wheel michael eisner is well known . 
<s>  for years the two companies have tried to sabotage each other's film and video releases by issuing similar competing productions on the same day . 
<s>  and now we have katzenberg using an entire movie to attack his former employer . 
<s>  here's a suggestion for the two boys : grow up ! 
<s>  put the past behind you ! 
<s>  there's room in the sandbox for both of you and if you farquaads can't play nice , then go to your rooms ! 
<s>  the other area i found troubling came in the portrayal of lord farquaad . 
<s>  beyond all the irreverence , " shrek " actually has a message : people should learn to look beyond physical appearances , because true beauty lies within . 
<s>  it's a lovely notion , but the film betrays its own moral by incessantly taking cheap shots at farquaad's diminutive stature . 
<s>  do we really need a family film reinforcing the idea that mocking short people is acceptable ? 
<s>  the pompous , selfish behavior of farquaad is enough to make him a target for zingers . 
<s>  adding short jokes is simply mean . 
<s>  still , " shrek " is a rollicking good time . 
<s>  the computer animation is mostly impressive ( although several key characters look like animated rubber squeeze toys and the human movements are often jerky ) , the voice work is strong ( particularly from eddie murphy ) , the laughs come fast and furious , and the moral , tainted though it may be , is a good one . 
<s>  to trot out a clich ? , " shrek " is fun for all ages . 
<s>  parents , though , should remind their young ones during the ride home that taunting others because they are short , tall , skinny , fat , etc . is a bad thing . 
<s>  after watching the first ten minutes of this japanese film , you will never eat a bowl of ramen the same way again . 
<s>  there is a scene where an old man is teaching a young one how to eat the soupy bowl of noodles , as a master would teach an eager apprentice . 
<s>   " you caress the noodles with the chopsticks , " he says , " then put the roast pork on the side of the bowl and apologize to it by saying , 'see you soon . ' " 
<s>  of course , it's meant to be a parody , but there is an earnestness underneath the silliness that makes you take it with a certain degree of sobriety . 
<s>  you begin to appreciate the food as not merely something you eat , not something you like , not something you enjoy , but rather something you experience . 
<s>  experiencing it is a process which engages all of the senses , fulfilling each one on its own terms and weaving them so that the total is a pleasure that is more than the sum of its parts . 
<s>  trust me , you really want to go find a noodle shop at this point . 
<s>  juzo itami's tampopo brings the same sense of the serious parody of food to the forefront by making the story follow the pattern of an american western , set in modern day japan . 
<s>  a stranger , goro ( tsutomu yamazaki ) , comes into town and finds tampopo ( nobuko miyamoto ) , the proprietor of a small , hole-in-the-wall noodle shop , trying to fend off the insults of the local strongman , pisken ( rikiya yasuoka ) . 
<s>  goro , to defend the honor of this woman and her noodles , gets into a fight with the ringleader and his henchmen , emerging bloodied , but victorious . 
<s>  goro finds that tampopo's ambition is to have a shop that people would flock to from far away , just to eat a bowl of her ramen . 
<s>  the problem is , her fare is something less than popular , and less than appetizing . 
<s>  however , goro agrees to help tampopo in her quest , and in the process they seek the wisdom of an elderly noodle expert , enlist the aid of a wealthy patron , and make friends with the former enemy . 
<s>  this film is filled with many little scenes which are absolute gems . 
<s>  take , for example , when tampopo tries to buy the recipe for a delicious soup from another shop owner . 
<s>  the price is too high , but the owner of the store next door will secretly sell it to her for a more affordable sum . 
<s>  tampopo meets him at his store late at night , and he leads her to a back room . 
<s>  she protests , thinking that perhaps this man has ulterior motives , but he insists . 
<s>  just when she is about to bolt for the exit , he shows her a small gap in the wall adjoining his store with the noodle shop next door . 
<s>  she peers through and takes notes as she watches the cook make the soup for the next day , her face filled with a joy that can be felt by the audience . 
<s>  this scene , while comical , is very effective at filling the viewer with a sense of trepidation , then of relief and discovery . 
<s>  there's also an interesting scene where goro introduces tampopo and her son to a bunch of street people who , despite their economic trappings , are all gourmets and master sommeliers . 
<s>  we even watch as one of them sneaks into the kitchen of a restaurant and expertly prepares a french omelet . 
<s>  the scene is meant to bring a laugh , but it also says that no matter whether people are rich or poor , food is something which everyone has in common , and the enjoyment of food is an experience shared by all . 
<s>  there are also a number of unrelated vignettes appearing throughout the film , which help to illustrate and accentuate the role of food in people's lives . 
<s>  a particularly effective one involves a wife and mother being tended to in her home by a doctor . 
<s>  surrounded by her children , she is obviously in her last hours of life . 
<s>  her husband comes home , and seeing her worsened condition , demands that she get up and make dinner . 
<s>  the viewer knows the husband's intention is not to be mean ; he is desperate for the normalcy of which he and his family has obviously been deprived , and the wife making dinner is an essential part of this . 
<s>  in a near miracle , the wife drags herself to the kitchen and prepares a quick meal , then brings it to her awaiting family . 
<s>  as the family eats , she looks on them and smiles . 
<s>  preparing food for her family is a joy and a comfort to her , and for a brief moment , she too enjoys the normalcy . 
<s>  then she falls over , dead . 
<s>  for a moment , the family is stunned , but then the father yells at the children , " keep eating ! 
<s>  this is the last meal your mother ever made ! " 
<s>  crying as they do so , the family finishes the meal . 
<s>  the scene is comical , awkward , moving , and beautiful . 
<s>  by including the vignettes , itami ran the risk of creating a disjointed film , but surprisingly , they do not interrupt the pacing of the main storyline . 
<s>  instead , they even help contribute to the idea that tampopo's goal of being able to serve exceptional food is worthy and even noble . 
<s>  because the film parodies a western , the construction of the plot is fairly predictable , but is still enjoyable as we watch the familiar way in which the " good guys " come together for the final showdown . 
<s>  in this case , the showdown is against the ramen . 
<s>  if they eat tampopo's ramen , soup and all , tampopo knows she has succeeded . 
<s>  it's pretty obvious what the outcome will be , but when a film changes your whole perspective on something you consume every day of your life , you can afford to cut it a little slack . 
<s>  there's an old saying that states something about leaving the best for last . 
<s>  george lucas certainly followed that adage when crafting the original star wars trilogy . 
<s>  return of the jedi , the final installment of the series , is easily the most innovative , action-packed , and entertaining of the three films . 
<s>  the dark , eerie atmosphere that oozed from every frame of the empire strikes back is gone . 
<s>  instead , for return of the jedi , we have good triumphing decisively over evil , a resolution to a love triangle , and walking teddy bears . 
<s>  even darth vader doesn't seem very intimidating this time around . 
<s>  with the arrival of the emperor ( an apparition-like creature played by ian mcdiarmid ) , vader has turned into somewhat of a henchman . 
<s>  return of the jedi picks up at an unspecified time after the conclusion of the empire strikes back . 
<s>  luke skywalker ( mark hamill ) , princess leia ( carrie fisher ) , lando calrissian , ( billy dee williams ) , chewbacca ( peter mayhew ) , c3p0 ( anthony daniels ) and r2-d2 ( kenny baker ) are on a rescue mission to luke's home planet of tatooine . 
<s>  their goal : to save han solo ( harrison ford ) from the clutches of the intergalactic gangster jabba the hutt . 
<s>  it is at jabba's home , a creepy-looking stone fortress guarded by hog-nosed beasts , that most of the added special effects come into play . 
<s>  from a hysterical scene involving a music group to the dreaded beast outside jabba's sand barge , the effects are top notch . 
<s>  as soon as han is freed from his cryo-freeze and rescued from the clutches of the evil jabba the hutt , it's back to outer space , where the rebel alliance is about to face the empire's newest threat : a second , more powerful death star , that , if activated , could spell doom for anyone who stands against the emperor . 
<s>  so , while the fleet prepares for the final battle , luke and company travel to the forest moon of endor to knock out the shield that defends the death star against all attacks . 
<s>  there , they are befriended by the ewoks , the teddy bear-like native race , and luke , fearing that his presence is endangering the group , turns himself over to vader . 
<s>  return of the jedi has some interesting elements .

<s>  from a technical point-of-view , the space battles are amazing , easily hindering anything depicted in the previous films . 
<s>  not only are there many , many more ships , but their speed and range of movement have been dramatically improved . 
<s>  on one level , return of the jedi is almost worth watching for the special effects . 
<s>  in the special edition , even more ships are added , making the final space battle incredibly fun to watch . 
<s>  the acting in return of the jedi is stronger than in the previous films . 
<s>  by now ( or then - 1983 ) , mark hamill , harrison ford , and carrie fisher have all matured in their on-screen personas . 
<s>  the chemistry amongst the trio is terrific . 
<s>  as in empire , billy dee williams gives us another human hero to root for . 
<s>  newcomer ian mcdiarmid plays the emperor as a suitably creepy , cunning , and evil creature , although he's not as imposing as vader was in star wars . 
<s>  although it was great fun watching star wars and the empire strikes back on the big screen , return of the jedi generates a greater sense of enjoyment . 
<s>  with the spectacular , new special effects , the adorable ewoks , the sinister jabba the hutt , the evil emperor , the same old millenium falcon , darth vader's incredible betrayal , the destruction of the new death star , and the always lovable yoda , return of the jedi concludes one of the greatest trilogies ever made with a huge bang . 
<s>  congratulations to george lucas , whose innovative mind entertains us now and will continue to entertain generations to come .

<s>  why do so many children's films treat their target audience with utter contempt ? 
<s>  too many of those who write or direct for children's movies assume that the kids just can't handle serious , thoughtful discussions on meaningful issues . 
<s>   " the iron giant , " which was directed and co-written by brad bird , late of such animated series as " the simpsons " and " king of the hill , " assumes that not only can children handle such discussions , but that they can do so while being entertained at the same time . 
<s>   " the iron giant " holds absolutely no contempt for the young people in the audience , making it a film that's enjoyable for both children and adults alike . 
<s>  hogarth hughes ( voice of eli marienthal ) is a spirited young lad who lives with his hard-working single mother , annie ( jennifer aniston ) , in a small town in maine . 
<s>  after staying up late and watching scary movies on a night his mother is away , hogarth treks out into the forest to investigate what has stolen his antenna and ruined his tv reception . 
<s>  he comes across a giant robot ( vin diesel ) from space that eats metal for food . 
<s>  after saving the robot , nicknamed the iron giant , from electric shock , hogarth befriends the creature and takes him in as a pet of sorts . 
<s>  because of damage he suffered upon landing , the giant has forgotten what his original mission was , so he just follows hogarth around like a lost puppy . 
<s>  realizing he can't just keep the giant in a barn all the time , and that the giant needs food , he takes him to a junkyard owned by dean ( harry connick jr . ) , an eccentric artist who assembles sculptures out of scrap iron in his spare time . 
<s>  it soon becomes apparent that dean and hogarth can't keep the giant a secret forever , because a government spook named kent mansley ( christopher mcdonald ) has been brought in to investigate mysterious sightings in the surrounding forest area and considers the giant a threat to national security . 
<s>  he suspects hogarth knows something about the giant , and takes up residence in hogarth's house as a lodger . 
<s>  meanwhile , the giant begins to exhibit ominous behavior that suggests he was built to be a weapon of some kind . 
<s>   " the iron giant " is exactly what family films ought to be , because it doesn' t talk down to its audience . 
<s>  the story is simple , very simple , about an alien being that drops out of the sky and befriends a young boy . 
<s>  it's very similar to the spielberg classic " e . t . , ' and such comparisons are actually deserved in the case of " the iron giant . " 
<s>  the film holds many of the better elements of spielberg's film , such as the ability to be sentimental without turning sappy . 
<s>  the film delivers several serious messages , the most important of which is one's ability to choose one's own fate . 
<s>  hogarth teaches the giant to go against his programming and become what he wants to be : a hero . 
<s>  the final sequence is touching and appropriate , though i won't give it away , i will say that very few will be disappointed . 
<s>  the animation , while not up to disney standards ( what could be , after " tarzan " ? ) , is good enough to make you forget you're watching a cartoon . 
<s>  the giant is computer-animated , while the human characters are all hand-drawn the old-fashioned way . 
<s>  the characters' faces are done quite well , drawn realistically enough to make the personalities credible , but the features are exaggerated so as to allow for the cartoonish expressions that provide for comic relief . 
<s>  fine voice work is turned in by young eli marienthal as hogarth , and jennifer aniston is surprisingly convincing as his waitress mother . 
<s>  harry connick jr . does a nice characterization as dean , and i really enjoyed the voice work of john mahoney ( of tv's " frasier " ) as an army general called in by agent mansley . 
<s>  unlike several cartoon features , each character is actually a developed personality , rather than a stereotype , and is actually integral to the plot , rather than being a superfluous comic-relief sidekick ( a clich ? disney still hasn't ditched ) . 
<s>  dean , for example , could have been a stereotypical beatnik ( his character profile seems to suggest that ) , but he is presented as a character with real emotions , thoughts , and motivations . 
<s>  even the heavy , agent mansley , is not a villain who does bad things simply because he wants to , but out of his own fear and paranoia . 
<s>  a lesser animated feature would have drawn up paper-thin stereotypes and figure the kids won't mind , but " the iron giant " has clearly put a little work into making the characters real , and it pays off . 
<s>  the film isn't only around to deliver heavy-handed messages , though . 
<s>  it's also very funny , and the humor is of the kind that both children and adults will enjoy . 
<s>  the scenes in which hogarth teaches the giant to do certain things , such as dive into a pool , are handled well , and director brad bird clearly has a sense of comic timing , having worked on " the simpsons " for many years . 
<s>  a sequence where hogarth and mansley attempt to " outlast " one another by trying to stay awake is very nicely timed , and also extremely clever . 
<s>  the film even takes some jabs at america's nuclear paranoia during the early stages of the cold war , satirizing the lame safety films shown to grade school students that tell them to " duck and cover " in the event of a nuclear attack . 
<s>   " the iron giant " has much more of a satirical edge to it than most family films , and the edgy humor is actually quite refreshing . 
<s>  instead of seeing people get bonked on the head , we get well-timed , clever gags that seem to have required some imagination to come up with . 
<s>  when you get right down to it , " the iron giant " is no more than the story of a boy and his robot . 
<s>  the story is so straightforward , so quaint , that it ultimately becomes charming . 
<s>  though i enjoy the complex plotting of film noir as much as the next person , when it comes to family entertainment , simple is the way to go . 
<s>  it's akin to one of those bedtime stories your father told that had you hanging on his every word , but it's not the story that sets the film above others of its kind , but rather the elements that go into the story , namely real characters and thoughtful dialogue , which " the iron giant " has in spades . 
<s>  susan granger's review of " the closet " ( miramax films ) 
<s>  in this hilarious french farce , a shy , boring accountant ( daniel auteil ) named francois pignon discovers he's going to be fired from his job at a condom factory . 
<s>  lonely and distraught , he contemplates suicide . 
<s>  but then he runs into belone ( michel aumont ) , an elderly homosexual neighbor , who suggests a " sex discrimination " lawsuit to intimidate management . 
<s>  as evidence , belone concocts provocative photographs of pignon locked in a leather-clad embrace with another man and mails them anonymously to pignon's boss . 
<s>  when the racy snapshots start circulating around the factory , not only does pignon get his job back but he suddenly finds himself the focus of attention as an openly gay man . 
<s>  his lusty supervisor ( michele laroque ) is so intrigued that she wonders if , perhaps , she could change his sexual preferences . 
<s>  even his ex-wife ( alexandra vandernoot ) and indifferent teenage son ( stanislas crevillen ) drop their disdain . 
<s>  but not everyone is enchanted . 
<s>  a mucho macho co-worker felix ( gerard depardieu ) , a self-righteous homophobe , is stunned and repulsed when he's forced by the pr director ( thierry lhermite ) to grovel and court pignon's friendship or risk losing his own job . 
<s>  writer/director francis verber artfully milks the farcical comedy as he dissects the hypocrisy of political correctness , veering off-track only occasionally into pedophilia . 
<s>  daniel auteuil ( " the widow of saint-pierre " ) is delightful - particularly with a blown-up condom perched on his head , riding on a float in a gay pride parade - and gerard depardieu delivers one of his most restrained , and effective , performances . 
<s>  on the granger movie gauge of 1 to 10 , " the closet " is a frankly sexual , adult 8 . 
<s>  it's so clever , in fact , that hollywood is already planning to re-make it in english , like " la cage aux folles . " 
<s>  roman emperor marcus aurelius ( richard harris ) chooses his trusted general maximus ( russell crowe ) as his successor . 
<s>  however the emperor's evil son commodus ( joaquin phoenix ) murders his father before the announcement can be made , and maximus ( as well as his family ) is sentenced to be executed . 
<s>  maximus is able to escape his executioners , but is later captured and sold as a slave to proximo ( oliver reed ) . 
<s>  proximo is looking for gladiators to earn himself money ( he being a former gladiator himself ) , and maximus reluctantly uses his skills to prove himself a powerful gladiator . 
<s>  when emperor commodus announces that new games will be held in the colisseum , proximo takes his gladiators there to do battle . 
<s>  maximus sees this as his chance to exact revenge on commodus . 
<s>  gladiator begins with a great battle sequence between the roman army and germania , and actually is able to maintain interest during the now required " 40 minutes of exposition after a kick ass opening sequence " style of moviemaking . 
<s>  the only downfall of the opening sequence is the editing style used . . .

<s>  but he should have it now .

<s>  oliver reed died during the filming of gladiator , and it's a huge loss to the acting world . 
<s>  i've always been fascinated with reed . . . 
<s>  he's one of those very talented performers who once had a fine career but ended up in direct to video junk during his twilight years . 
<s>  it's ironic that this film probably would have gotten him back into real movies again , as he gives a fun and sincere performance . 
<s>  the film is dedicated to him , and he will surely be missed .

<s>  ingredients : starving artist lusting after a beautiful woman from his childhood 
<s>  synopsis : great expectations ( 1998 ) is a modernized version of a charles dickens novel . 
<s>  in the original charles dickens classic an orphan boy named pip learns about life through his friendship with an escaped convict , his relationship with a bitter old lady named miss havisham , and his hopeless lifetime infatuation with havisham's snobbish adopted daughter , estella . 
<s>  the gist of the story is that an anonymous benefactor sends pip to london for pip to become an upper class " gentleman . " 
<s>  pip leaves for london with " great expectations " to be groomed into a gentleman so that he can one day be classy enough to marry estella . 
<s>  but life has a way of complicating things . 
<s>  pip becomes an arrogant s . o . b . 
<s>  until he learns just who his secret benefactor is . 
<s>  in this new 1998 version of great expectations a poor florida lad named finn ( ethan hawke ) with a talent for drawing has an early memory of helping an escaped convict ( robert de niro ) . 
<s>  but soon the focus of finn's life becomes romance , as he develops a lifelong infatuation with estella ( gwyneth paltrow ) , an upper crust girl with some psychological and emotional issues due to being raised in a dysfunctional environment . 
<s>  estella was raised in wealth by ms . dinsmoor ( anne bancroft ) , an eccentric , aged and embittered , man-hating single aunt whose groom left her abandoned at the altar on the day of her marriage . 
<s>  this causes estella to 'fear the daylight' of relationships , but finn thinks it's just a case of snobbery . 
<s>  when finn becomes a young man , an anonymous benefactor sets finn up in new york with the connections and publicity to be groomed into a famous artist . 
<s>  finn leaves florida with " great expectations " to be a successful artist so that some day he might become classy enough to marry the snobbish estella . 
<s>  what will happen to all of finn's " great expectations ? " 
<s>  opinion : if you're looking for a romance with a happy ending , look no further ; you've found one here . 
<s>  ethan hawke is romantic lead . 
<s>   ( he romanced winona ryder in reality bites . 
<s>  he romanced julie delpy in before sunrise . 
<s>  he romanced uma thurman in gattaca . 
<s>  now in great expectations he gets to chase gwyneth paltrow , a rail-thin blonde . ) 
<s>  hawke plays a lovestruck , earnest and unchanged finn throughout the film . 
<s>  meanwhile paltrow portrays estella as alternating between infuriating tease and ice princess ; estella's whole purpose is to get men to fall in love and then hurt them rather than become intimate . 
<s>  anne bancroft goes a little overboard as the deranged and pessimistic ms . dinsmoor , while robert de niro carries off the convict part suitably . 
<s>  the difference between the classic dickens novel and this 1998 adaptation is that the dickens novel is ripe with deep and timeless themes about class struggle and love , whereas great expectations ( 1998 ) is more artsy , less complicated story about a 1990s artist dealing with a lifetime tease . 
<s>  you've seen this moment before , recently : a particularly troubled character senses danger of the paranormal kind when the room temperature inexplicably plummets to below freezing . 
<s>  the difference is that when it happens to lili taylor's nell in the haunting , we don't care . 
<s>  the hero of the sixth sense , a young boy named cole , is a rich creation , and we wish nothing more than for the ghosts who haunt him to take a hike . 
<s>  the seasons have changed since an ex-patient shot jaded child psychologist malcolm crowe ( willis ) in the comfort of his own bedroom . 
<s>  desperate to get his career back on track , even at the expense of his crumbling marriage ( to williams , of rushmore ) , malcolm councils the deeply troubled cole ( osment ) . 
<s>  the preteen displays all the quirks of malcolm's would-be killer : scars on his body ; antisocial behaviour ; and the reluctance to reveal a big secret . 
<s>  only after cole is locked in a closet by some bullies ( and hospitalized as a result ) does he divulge to malcolm , in a spine-tingling scene , that he sees dead people walking among us , all the time . 
<s>  malcolm assumes , and given his profession , reasonably so , that cole is schizophrenic , not psychic , but the sincerity in cole's anguished confession prevents the doctor from taking drastic measures . 
<s>  he will instead pursue the supernatural angle , becoming a kind of surrogate father to cole ( who lives with his single mother , lynn ( collette ) ) in the process . 
<s>  the sixth sense has more in common with ghost than poltergeist . 
<s>   ( though shyamalan does , somewhat unforgiveably , crib the self-rearranging kitchen business from the latter . ) 
<s>  it's far more heartwarming than frightening , and the film would be none the worse for wear without its few pulp shocks . 
<s>  cole attracts the dead for reasons unknown , but they're not out to harm him , really-they just want to be heard , even if it means scaring the bejesus out of the innocent gradeschooler . 
<s>  perhaps the apparitions seem more ghastly to us , at first , than they really are because we're looking at the situation through the eyes of an eight-year-old . 
<s>  that's right : willis , for the first time in years , gives up the spotlight to his costar . 
<s>  we appreciate malcolm's domestic dilemma , but we identify with cole , recalling our fears of the bogeyman or the closet monster or the thing under the bed . 
<s>  both actors deliver immensely likable performances , and their dynamic is manifest . 
<s>  willis convinces us that he's a doctor , something he was unable to do as a horndog shrink in the overheated color of night . 
<s>  osment is phenomenal , a true professional who resists mugging for the camera like some child stars with too much experience in television commercials do . 
<s>  the sixth sense ( atmospherically shot by the silence of the lambs' cinematographer , tak fujimoto ) is actually a drama-its spooky , effective ad campaign is misleading . 
<s>  only because i was expecting something different did i notice-rather , feel-the movie's running time , which is just shy of two hours . 
<s>  the story unfurls slowly but engrossingly ; its unexpected finish is definitely worth the wait . 
<s>  i'm not sure said big twist ending is bulletproof , but i admired its audacity . 
<s>  hollywood has really done the whole dracula thing to death ( no pun intended - honest ) . 
<s>  it's a shame , too , because the good count was probably the most frightening out the old b-movie monsters . 
<s>  i mean , come on . 
<s>  are people really going to get that scared over a big green guy named frankenstein that moves at a speed of five miles per hour ? 
<s>  hell no . 
<s>  and not only was the idea of a vampire frightening as hell , but it also carried with it a kind of sensual feeling as well , not commonly associated with horror films . 
<s>  and not only has the idea been done too many times , but with the possible exception of from dusk 'till dawn , has not been done very well lately , either . 
<s>  this is precisely why it was so much fun for me watching the original nosferatu . 
<s>  i got to go back to the times when making movies ( even horror movies ) was considered an art form , and not just done to make cash like nowadays . 
<s>  and that is exactly what this film is ; art . 
<s>  i've been a horror fan since i was eight years old , and to this day i have not seen any horror film cover the intellectual ground that this film covers . 
<s>  let me backtrack a minute . 
<s>  when i say " intellectual ground " , i don't mean that nosferatu tackles philosophical questions or anything like that , i just mean that in order for the film to work the way it was intended to , a little bit of thinking is involved . 
<s>  with most modern slasher movies like friday the 13th and what-not , you can just simply sit back in your chair and be frightened by the gore that is shown . 
<s>  those movies could have been made by a fifth grader with a good makeup kit ; movies like this require the viewer to actually pay attention and ponder what is happening on the screen . 
<s>  you see , this movie has barely any violence in it and even less blood or gore . 
<s>  this is a thinking man's slasher flick . 
<s>  the " nosferatu " of the title is orlock ( max shreck ) , a strange , hermit-like count that , as the film opens , is looking for a new home to buy . 
<s>  he employs the help of hutter ( gustav von wangenhein ) , a real estate salesman ( or something to that effect ) who has a nice home and even a fiancee named ellen ( greta schroeder ) . 
<s>  upon orders from his boss , hutter treks to the transylvanian mountains to visit orlock's castle and speak to him about his new home ( which just happens to be right next door to hutter's ) . 
<s>  the next morning , he wakes up to find teeth marks on his neck . . . not 
<s>  really a good sign . 
<s>  he then discovers through some reading that the count is a " nosferatu " , or vampire , one of the undead that feeds off the blood of living humans . 
<s>  but by the time he pieces this together , he is too late ; orlock has already embarked to hutter's hometown via boat . 
<s>  will hutter reach his destination in time to save his fiancee from the deadly clutches of count orlock ? 
<s>  the character of orlock is , of course , dracula . 
<s>  the only only reason his name was changed was because this was an unauthorized account of bram strocker's novel . 
<s>  just thought that was an interesting little side note . . . 
<s>  probably the only way you will get to see this fine film is by purchasing a copy of arrow entertainment's digitally restored cut , now available in stores . 
<s>  however , this version is quite different than maunau's original masterpiece . 
<s>  the movie is now sporting a new soundtrack by band type o-negative and color tinting , much like the 1984 version of lang's metropolis . 
<s>  now , i really appreciate what arrow entertainment is trying to do here , bringing a classic like this to the attention of a wider audience that might have otherwise just skipped this one . 
<s>  but alas , i like watching movies the way they were originally intended to be seen . 
<s>  but that's just my bag ; you may like the newer , more " modern " version better . 
<s>  either way , i suggest investing your money in a copy . 
<s>  if you like what they have done with it , pop it in the vcr and enjoy . 
<s>  if you're like me , just do what i'll do during future viewings ; turn the color all the way down on your television , hit mute , turn on some bach or mozart or whatever , dim the lights and prepare to view what is truly one of the greatest films ever made . 
<s>  stendhal's syndrome : a condition where , in the presence of art , a person becomes engulfed in a painting and hallucinates and may afterwards suffer symptoms such as depression , suicidal behaviour and personality disorder . 
<s>  grim stuff , to be sure , but the subject of a remarkable film from italy's master of the horror thriller dario argento . 
<s>  boasting an unforgettable soundtrack from the grandfather of film music ennio morricone , the stendhal syndrome is a quite magnificent return to form for argento . 
<s>  it follows his disappointing american debut trauma ( 1992 ) , the patchy opera ( 1987 ) and several mediocre films he produced for young italian director michele soavi in the late 1980's . 
<s>  based on the novel by graziella magherini , the film stars argento's daughter asia as young roman police inspector anna manni in pursuit of a brutal rapist-killer . 
<s>  visiting florence to follow up several leads , she is lured by the killer alfredo ( thomas kretschmann ) to an art gallery , a favourite haunt where he hopes to identify exactly who is on his tail . 
<s>  at the gallery anna is overwhelmed by a painting and faints . 
<s>  posing as a bystander , alfredo briefly comes to her aid and having now identified his pursuer , a strange game of cat and mouse begins . 
<s>  a gripping story evolves , and a coherent one , too , which may surprise those familiar with argento's often lumpy narratives . 
<s>  the stendhal syndrome is not a simple cop-hunting-killer scenario . 
<s>  it is a disturbing and often compelling study of the central character's psychological disintegration . 
<s>  the script explores its psycho-sexual themes with intelligence and candour , perhaps too much so for more sensitive viewers . 
<s>  but as dark as its themes are , the stendhal syndrome emerges as one of the most artful and effective european thrillers of the last ten years . 
<s>  argento is once again working in his native italy , and he fully exploits the opportunities to use art and architecture for both symbolic statements and as departure points for several brilliant hallucinogenic sequences . 
<s>  effects whiz sergio stivaletti serves his director well here , and the cinematography by giuseppe rotunno is consistently excellent . 
<s>  the film's opening 20 minutes segues between hallucination , flashback and real-time with tremendous style . 
<s>  proof that , at his most inspired , argento remains one of the world's most exhilarating filmmakers . 
<s>  the cast is generally good , though marred at times by dubbing into english that renders speech all but emotionless . 
<s>  asia argento's performance is by turns risky , awkward and fascinating . 
<s>  it's a difficult role , and given her relative inexperience on screen she deserves applause for her efforts . 
<s>  thomas kretschmann is chillingly effective as alfredo , and marco leonardi ( of cinema paradiso , and possibly the most gorgeous looking man in italy ) does okay as anna's work colleague and increasingly confused love interest . 
<s>  but perhaps the stendhal syndrome's single most striking element is ennio morricone's soundtrack . 
<s>  active since the 1960's , morricone has scored over 100 films in his career and this must rate as one of his finest efforts . 
<s>  it's mostly a variation on the one theme : a slow circular melody for strings and wordless female vocal possessed with an extraordinary , haunting beauty that lingers long afterwards . 
<s>  it's been three decades since argento and morricone worked together . 
<s>  this is a long welcome reunion . 
<s>  if the film has a fault , it is that the last half hour drags a little and the film doesn't quite reach a completely satisfying climax . 
<s>  but by the closing scenes , the stendhal syndrome has already offered us enough to qualify as one of the very best films of dario argento's career . 
<s>   * note : see the uncut print from japanese laserdisc if you can . 
<s>  dubs of this version are available from various video dealers on the world wide web . 
<s>  close your eyes for a moment , if you will , and imagine the sound of stephen rea's gaelic brogue , silky smooth and irish like a pint of guinness . 
<s>  a lackadaisical , naughty little schoolboy voice that flirts and gambols . 
<s>  an acerbic , sing-song metered voice that evokes the startling imagery and language of anthony burgess' " a clockwork orange . " 
<s>  a voice that deliciously conjures scenes both porcine and puerile , like those out of " delicatessen , " or " the tin drum . " 
<s>  imagine all of that , and you'll get a good sense of what you can expect from " the butcher boy . " 
<s>  imagine that and more . 
<s>  neil jordan's latest film " stars " rea in more ways than one . 
<s>  rea , the accomplished irish actor most notable from his star turn in jordan's " the crying game , " contributes a restrained and managed performance as da brady , a small town drunk in an unnamed irish community in the 1960s . 
<s>  but it's his wall-to-wall narration as the butcher boy of the title , da brady's son , francis , that makes rea's " performance " worth watching , worth listening to . 
<s>  and that's only half the fun . 
<s>  playing the young francie brady is newcomer eamonn owens and he is , without a doubt , a revelation . 
<s>  for as much as rea's voiceover permeates almost every scene of " the butcher boy , " owens commands virtually every frame . 
<s>  it's impossible to take your eyes off him . 
<s>  with his crop of carrot-colored hair , ruddy complexion , and overall grubby appearance , francie brady is an unlikely hero , refusing to be done in by his alcoholic , trumpet-playing father , his depressive , suicidal mother , or the neighboring , bespectacled monster known as mrs . nugent ( fiona shaw ) . 
<s>  in fact , everything was ok until " the nugent " came to town . 
<s>  now , she poses as much a threat to the safety and security of town bully francie and his best pal joe ( alan boyle ) as the looming commie menace ( " the butcher boy " is set at a time when the fear of nuclear obliteration is first and foremost in the minds of many ) . 
<s>   " pigs ! " screams mrs . nugent at the brady menagerie . 
<s>   " you're all pigs ! " 
<s>  it's the start of many a related image . 
<s>  after ma brady is shipped off to the " garage " for psychiatric observation and da brady downs one bottle of whiskey too many , francie finally loses grip of his fantasy world of cowboys and indians , the lone ranger , and other comicbook characters . 
<s>  squealing like a stuck pig , francie does " the likes o' that " on the nugent's living room floor , and is himself whisked away to a very catholic remand home for " boney arsed bogmen , " where his ever fertile imagination--and clever chicanery--runneth over . 
<s>  director jordan's vivid treatment of pat mccabe's nightmare novel produces a sometimes disturbing , dark comedy littered with surreal touches ( such as sin ? ad o'connor playing the virgin mary ) . 
<s>  it's not as outlandish as the trailers make out ; instead , this remarkable film focuses on the effects external influences have on the friendship between two boys ( schoolboy chums in real life ) , allowing us to empathize with their plight in the presence of extraordinary behavior . 
<s>  it's bleak and it's black but it's fundamentally very funny . 
<s>  rea talks us through it , beautifully , and owens drags us though it , admirably , and , in tandem with jordan's sure hand , theirs are contributions to make " the butcher boy " a film worth savoring . 
<s>  zero effect gets its title from the main character , daryl zero ( bill pullman ) , although we don't understand what it truly means until the very last line of dialogue in the film . 
<s>  zero is a private investigator , perhaps the best private investigator who ever lived ( at least he'd like to think so ) . 
<s>  however , he's a socially inept being , and eccentric in every possible way -- this fact certainly makes his talents as a private eye even more bewildering than they already are . 
<s>  zero's accomplice is steve arlo ( ben stiller ) , a " normal " guy who does the business side of the job -- he's the one who actually speaks to clients and explains zero's greatness as an investigator . 
<s>  the opening scene has steve explaining the many virtues of zero's talents to soon-to-be client gregory stark ( ryan o'neal ) . 
<s>  it turns out that stark has lost a key to a safe deposit box , and is now being blackmailed for something that he apparently knows nothing about . 
<s>  zero takes the case , and the plot thickens . 
<s>  his path leads to a young , pretty paramedic named gloria sullivan ( kim dickens ) . 
<s>  despite her luminous and seemingly-harmless presence , she turns out to be the one blackmailing stark . 
<s>  through his investigations , zero learns why , but not without developing feelings for gloria -- feelings that , because of his reclusive behavior , are new and confusing to him . 
<s>  i have no particular affinity towards the mystery genre of film . 
<s>  i can idly enjoy movies about private investigators , and , every once in a while , a film like chinatown comes a long that blows me away ( actually , no private eye film has ever reached chinatown's greatness ) . 
<s>  zero effect , which is jake kasdan's first effort as writer/director , is a film about a private investigator that succeeds in all attempts : it's an original , funny , and completely involving motion picture . 
<s>  with so many cliches available to this genre , i find it amazing that kasdan avoided all of them . 
<s>  but he didn't just successfully avoid flaws : he has created a great film here , one that had me interested and fascinated from the first shot to the final moment . 
<s>  take , for starters , the great cast of characters . 
<s>  pullman is terrific as zero , showing a comic flair that i really haven't seen from him since spaceballs . 
<s>  zero is the kind of guy who seems at ease switching personalities so frequently as he does here ; the fact that he's an almost exaggeratedly twisted , emotionally unstable man outside of his profession is not at all difficult to believe . 
<s>  pullman's performance is much more layered than it might seem at first glance , and the occasional voice-over as he's going through the motions of his job are insightful and often hilarious . 
<s>  ben stiller is also a very funny individual ; he's the kind of comedian who makes normal lines sound funny . 
<s>   " i'll shoot you , " he says to stark at one point . 
<s>   " i have a gun , and everything . " 
<s>  his character is also well-drawn , with an interesting subplot involving his girlfriend ( angela featherstone ) who is not happy with the extensive amounts of time he must spend away from her due to the unpredictability of his job . 
<s>  o'neal also gives his character a bit of depth ; and kim dickens , last seen ( and underused ) in mercury rising , gets a chance to show us her talent here , giving gloria the realism this kind of character really needs . 
<s>  i find zero effect to be an immensely funny and witty film . 
<s>  kasdan's humor is of the best kind -- soft spoken , and mostly dialogue-driven ( though there are some great visual jokes ) . 
<s>  it's the kind of humor that's funny even after you've seen it five or six times . 
<s>  there's one scene in which zero talks about how detached he is , an how that makes him such a great detective . 
<s>  what we see during this narration are various shots of him sitting on a bed , or standing motionlessly , with his hair destroyed and an utterly blank look painted on his unshaven face , his eyes pointing to something off camera , but obviously to nothing in particular . 
<s>  i can't convey to you how funny this is , but what makes it great film making is that it has a point -- scenes like this are frequent , and they provide solid characterization of zero . 
<s>  as a side note , i don't consider myself an average viewer when it comes to comedy ( not to sound elitist ) -- i find things funny that many do not , and vice versa . 
<s>  there was a clump of people near me in the theater laughing uproariously through this film , and the rest of the theater was relatively silent through most of it . 
<s>  i have a feeling the humor here won't appeal to everyone , but there's certainly enough story and character development to keep anyone's interest . 
<s>  jake kasdan , son of writer/director lawrence kasdan , is only 22 years old . 
<s>  i found this out after seeing the film , and i can't remember ever being so impressed with a film maker . 
<s>  his direction is stylish without being pretentious , and his writing is mature , full , and developed . 
<s>  zero effect is the kind of film that i'll buy for my collection -- smart , original films like this are rare as it is , but this one actually has a heart and a soul . 
<s>  at the end of the film , i was involved in the characters , and i was satisfied with the outcome . 
<s>  and , with kasdan's undeniable talent at such a young age , all i can do is hope to see a lot more from him in the future . 
<s>  the long kiss goodnight ( r ) meryl streep tried it and failed . 
<s>  even pamela anderson lee made an attempt but fell flat on her well-bared assets . 
<s>  however , geena davis could very well become the first bankable american female action star with the long kiss goodnight , a preposterous but incredibly fun action thriller directed by her husband , renny harlin . 
<s>  davis plays samantha caine , a mousy suburban school teacher and mother whose memories only go back eight years . 
<s>  with the help of ethically questionable private detective mitch hennessey ( samuel l . jackson ) , she slowly remembers--and reclaims--her past as charly baltimore , tough-as-nails cia operative . 
<s>  needless to say , with the reappearance of samantha/charly comes the appearance of an assortment of no-goodniks out to erase more than her memory . 
<s>  shane black netted a cool $4 mil for his script ; i'm not so sure if his prose is truly deserving of such a hefty price tag , but for what it's worth , it delivers the goods . 
<s>  like black's previous work , such as lethal weapon and the last boy scout , the script juggles some impressive action scenes with funny , quirky dialogue .

<s>  but there's no argument that the more unbelievable sequences are original and entertaining as hell : who can resist the sight of davis tossing her daughter from a hole in her house into the nearby treehouse or chasing after a car . . .

<s>  as good as he is , the one who should benefit the most from this project is davis , who shows much promise as an action heroine . 
<s>  what makes her so effective and why she should succeed where streep and lee failed is that she doesn't take herself too seriously .

<s>  inspired by the short story the legend of sleepy hollow by washington irving . 
<s>  directed by tim burton . 
<s>  starring johnny depp , christina ricci , and casper van dien .

<s>  synopsis : investigator ichabod crane journeys to 1799 sleepy hollow to investigate a series of murders involving decapitation . 
<s>  townspeople believe the spirit of a dead german mercenary is threatening them . 
<s>  cute blonde katrina and a listless orphan help crane solve the mystery . 
<s>  comments : tim burton has directed a number of entertaining and groundbreaking films over the years . 
<s>  batman , of course , is perhaps his best-known film and led to a string of less successful sequels . 
<s>  he's done biographical work ( on the director ed wood ) , children's movies ( nightmare before christmas ) , and a homage to alien invasion movies ( mars attacks ! ) . 
<s>  sleepy hollow , his newest feature which fans have been anticipating for a while , shares the similar dark and atmospheric style of his earlier work and counts among his better movies . 
<s>  sleepy hollow quite obviously draws its inspiration from the old period horror films of the 1950s and 1960s , especially hammer studios' reworkings of dracula and frankenstein , and american international's series of movies based on the works of edgar allan poe . 
<s>  christopher lee , in fact , star of many hammer productions over the years , appears at the beginning of sleepy hollow as a judge who sends ichabod crane out to investigate the murders . 
<s>  the movie also borrows from the universal monster movies of the 1930s . 
<s>  one of the climatic scenes involves a windmill and obviously takes its cue from frankenstein . 
<s>  i mention these allusions for a reason . 
<s>  seasoned horror film fans , including myself , will smile at their inclusion in this film . 
<s>  with the recent disappointments in theatrically released horror movies , especially the blair witch project ( the most overblown turkey of the decade ) , we needed a film like this . 
<s>  not only does it have a sense of history , but burton's skillful use of setting and mood make this an entertaining exercise in horror . 
<s>  the film's eerie landscapes and foggy towns , indeed , overshadow the actors and the plot as the most noteworthy aspect of the movie . 
<s>  johnny depp , a veteran tim burton actor who has appeared both in ed wood and edward scissorhands , plays ichabod crane , who has apparently changed occupations from irving's original story and is now an investigator . 
<s>  depp is adequate in his role . 
<s>  no more ; no less . 
<s>  equally adequate is christina ricci , who plays the love interest in the film . 
<s>  she's a good witch too . 
<s>  how cute . 
<s>  one of the few weak parts of sleepy hollow is the wooden and cliched dialogue between the main characters . 
<s>  the two actors , however , carry the movie well enough , but the supporting cast is what makes this movie shine . 
<s>  veteran actors such as jeffrey jones and michael gough ( who played the butler alfred in all four recent batman flicks ) are terrific as the aging townsfolk involved in the conspiracy which depp uncovers . 
<s>  while i do not wish to reveal crucial plot points , i can say that the storyline becomes quite confusing . 
<s>  you have to pay attention . 
<s>  andrew kevin walker wrote the screenplay . 
<s>  he's the one who also wrote 8 mm and seven . 
<s>  walker is quickly becoming one of the premiere suspense writers in hollywood , and sleepy hollow certainly doesn't hurt his growing reputation . 
<s>  as one might imagine from a gentleman like walker , sleepy hollow is quite graphic . 
<s>  there's a lot of blood and a lot of beheadings . 
<s>  this is definately not a flick to take the young kids to . 
<s>  a lady in front of us took her two young sons to see it and spent about 25 - 30 minutes covering the youngest's eyes with her hand . 
<s>  he was obviously upset by the movie's intense violence . 
<s>  if you're looking for a good scare , however , sleepy hollow is definately recommended . 
<s>  mpaa : not rated ( though i feel it would likely be pg , for martial-arts violence . ) 
<s>  with three movies already ( re ) released theatrically in america , and at least three more on their way , jackie chan is one of the newest " hot properties " in action adventure stardom , and it's just about time . 
<s>  for over twenty-five years , jackie's been starring in martial arts and action movies in hong kong , thrilling audiences with both an incredible grasp of acrobatics and martial arts and a wonderful sense of comedy . 
<s>   " drunken master " has the distinction of being the first jackie chan movie to " make it big " --this is the movie that supposedly set jackie up for big stardom in hong kong . 
<s>  i'm not entirely sure why , exactly . 
<s>  in many ways , " drunken master " is similar to most of jackie's other early films , such as " fearless hyena " i and ii , " master with cracked fingers " , " half a loaf of kung fu " , " spiritual kung fu " , and others . 
<s>  in fact , looking at all these early films together , one gets the impression that they were stamped out , cookie-cutter style , at a rate of four to six per year , all using the same casts and telling very similar stories . 
<s>  to be honest , i think that early jackie chan movies are something of an acquired taste . 
<s>  they're quite different from action movies as we know them in america . 
<s>  these films tend to be set in the chinese countryside in an indeterminate period sometime in the distant past , with fairly slow plots that often meander far afield and sometimes seem to exist only for the intention of stringing comedy and fight scenes together . 
<s>   " drunken master " , though its plot is tighter than some , is no exception . 
<s>   ( as an aside , " drunken master " was the first jackie chan movie i ever saw , and i saw it the way it was meant to be seen . . . in 
<s>  a movie theater in seattle , as part of an asian film festival . 
<s>  at the time , i didn't really think it was anything special . . . but 
<s>  after having seen more films like it , it's kind of grown on me . ) 
<s>   " drunken master " 's storyline is very similar to that of other early jackie chan movies , such as " fearless hyena " i and ii and " master with cracked fingers " --slacker martial arts student is taught the martial arts by a harsh-seeming master , and has a big fight with an evil bad guy in the end ( a formula that has been " adapted , " to put it kindly , by american films such as karate kid ) . 
<s>  more specifically , jackie chan plays the part of wong fei-hong , aka " naughty panther , " a fun-loving , practical-joking kung fu student who is too good at kung fu for his own good , but not _quite_ good enough . 
<s>  after embarrassing his instructor's assistant by beating him roundly , then beating up a bully in a marketplace , wong fei-hong tries to hit on a pretty girl , but discovers that she , and her mother , can hit back , better than he can . . . and 
<s>  is further chagrinned to discover that the two women are his cousin and aunt , respectively . 
<s>  his father , wong kei-ying , is unhappy about this , and is further annoyed when the father and brother of the bully show up to sue for damages . 
<s>  kei-ying soon institutes a harsh regimen of punishment , which fei-hong does not like at all . 
<s>  while escaping from this punishment , fei-hong meets up with a drunken old man , who proceeds to thrash him soundly , then take him on as a student and thrash him some more . 
<s>  this turns out to be su hua-chi , a legendary master of drunken-style kung fu . 
<s>  he assigns fei-hong a series of bizarre tasks , such as filling jugs with water while hanging upside down from a frame , cracking walnuts with his hands , and other such exercises , that seem like more pointless cruelty but are actually strengthening him up . 
<s>  then , when he's ready , he teaches him the seven styles of drunken kung fu . 
<s>  unfortunately , the lazy fei-hong only practices six of them . . . 
<s>   " drunken master " features some wonderful martial arts sequences , with jackie winning some fights and losing others . 
<s>  it's been said before , but i'll say it again--these fights don't just _happen_ , they're as carefully choreographed as any ballet performance , and it shows . 
<s>  in his fights , jackie often makes use of objects found in his environment-- benches , jugs , cups , bowls , fruits and vegetables--often in new and surprising ways . 
<s>  the fight scenes , particularly those toward the end of the film , are unparallelled in most american films . 
<s>  whether jackie wins or loses , it's really something to see . . . and 
<s>  it's often as funny as anything , too . 
<s>  and funny is the other thing jackie chan is very , very good at . 
<s>  there's very little that's new in this movie--jackie winning fights , jackie getting beaten badly by a master , jackie going through punishment or training . . . these 
<s>  schticks have all been seen before , in any one of several dozen similar jackie movies from the seventies and early eighties . 
<s>  but they're still hilarious as ever . 
<s>  likewise , jackie has a _great_ supporting cast , many of whom were also in other early jackie films , and they're often the source of plenty of hilarity on their own . 
<s>  the really big thing about " drunken master " , though , that inspired several copycats ( including a couple starring jackie himself ) and a sequel fifteen years later , was the drunken-style kung fu . 
<s>  i'm not certain whether or not this is actually a genuine style of kung fu , but the principle behind it is to imitate the wobbly movements of a drunkard to lull the enemy into a false sense of security . . . and 
<s>  it apparently helps if you're drunk while you're doing it . 
<s>  genuine or not , i have to admit , there's just something incredibly fun about watching a fellow who looks utterly sloshed wading into a group of startled opponents and making mincemeat out of them before they even realize what's going on . 
<s>  come to think of it , perhaps this element is what accounts for this film's success over any of the other jackie films . . . it's 
<s>  not just martial arts , it's the kind of martial arts that makes you stop and go , " whoa . . . " 
<s>  on the negative side , the cinematography in this film is nothing special , the film stock is rather primitive , the plot is often rather slow , and the subtitles are sometimes extremely hard to read against the background . 
<s>   " gone with the wind " , this isn't . 
<s>  still , if you like martial arts films , or like what you've seen so far of jackie chan and want to see more , give it a shot . 
<s>  it's much more " real " than chuck norris or jean-claude van damme . 
<s>  you might very well like it . 
<s>  another interesting thing about " drunken master " has to do with its video availability in the us . 
<s>   " drunken master " is the only early jackie chan movie that i know of that you can find in its original , letterboxed , hong kong subtitled form , commercially available on vhs ( from magnum video , in a gold box , for about $10 ) . 
<s>  there are plenty of other early jackie films around , but these are typically either in dubbed , pan-and-scanned form or else import tapes priced for rental instead of purchase . 
<s>  thankfully , " drunken master " , at least , is available in the aspect ratio in which it was meant to be seen , at a very affordable price . 
<s>  if you like " drunken master " , take a look at the numerous other early jackie chan films that are out there ( even the dubbed ones aren't really _too_ bad . . . if 
<s>  nothing else , you can enjoy the martial arts choreography while making fun of the dialogue ) . 
<s>  i particularly recommend " spiritual kung fu " , " half a loaf of kung fu " , the " fearless hyena " movies , and " snake & crane arts of shaolin " . 
<s>  also , the mostly-unrelated-storywise sequel , " drunken master ii " , will hit theaters in american release sometime later this year ( though what its american-release title will be is still uncertain ) and comes _highly_ recommended by this reviewer . 
<s>  also , for a rather different interpretation of the character wong fei-hong ( who is in fact a popular figure from chinese folklore ) , i've been told to suggest the " once upon a time in china " series starring jet li ( though i haven't personally seen any of them yet ) . 
<s>  if you choose to watch " drunken master " , i really hope you enjoy it , and i hope it starts to open your eyes to the wonderful world of asian cinema that's out there . 
<s>  all in all , i give this film an . 
<s>  well , i know that stallone is 50 years old now , but in daylight he doesn't look it ! 
<s>  daylight is a great disaster movie . 
<s>  if you've seen cliffhanger , you'll know stallone's character already . 
<s>  a guy with a bad past , but is in the right place at the wrong time . 
<s>  a tunnel connecting new york and new jersey has both sides collapses when a group of robbers collide with a truck carrying * very * flammable toxic waste . 
<s>  a dozen or so people survive the collapses and the incinerating fireball ( and what a fire ball it was ! ) 
<s>  stallone , a former emergency medical service man , is chauffeuring a rich couple around , when they reach the outside of the tunnel , before the explosion . 
<s>  then , 30 minutes into the movie , boom ! 
<s>  >from here on , the plot takes a back seat , and we are treated to some of the best camera work and action staged . 
<s>  most all the action is plausible and will hold you at the edge of your seat . 
<s>  there are a few melodramatic parts here , but , they tend to work out well . 
<s>  there is no general antagonist in this film , but the action and suspense makes you forget all about that . 
<s>  daylight is a great film , i saw a non-matinee showing of it , and i thought it was worth every penny . 
<s>  the characterizations are mostly flat , one dimesional , but they have enough in them to get you to care for some of the characters . 
<s>  rob cohen ( dragonheart ) does a great job with this film . 
<s>  logical time travel movies are a near-impossibility . 
<s>  considering that the skeptic's best argument against the possibility of time travel is the idea of altered realities , writing a script that deals with this problem is an imposing task . 
<s>  occasionally , we get a film that does manage it . 
<s>  terry gilliam's " 12 monkeys " was one such film . 
<s>  but more frequently , we get films that don't much deal with it at all . 
<s>  there is one question to ask in this case : does the film have other virtues that override the existing logical inconsistencies ? 
<s>  the " terminator " films made up for them with exciting action , " back to the future " did it with an entertaining story , and the new film " frequency " pulls off the trick with a strong package of its own . 
<s>  is " frequency " filled with plot holes ? 
<s>  yes . 
<s>  does it matter ? 
<s>  not really . 
<s>  the film opens in october of 1969 . 
<s>  firefighter frank sullivan ( dennis quaid ) puts his life on the line every time he suits up for his job , then goes home to his loving wife julia ( elizabeth mitchell ) and son johnny ( daniel henson ) . 
<s>  the double-pronged story flashes forward to 1999 , where johnny ( now jim caviezel ) is all grown up and working as a police detective . 
<s>  a strange occurrence -- the appearance of aurora borealis over new york city -- allows father and son to communicate through the same ham radio frank used in '69 and that john has found in the present day . 
<s>  though both are initially skeptical of the idea , john eventually takes this opportunity to warn his father against his impending death in a warehouse fire , and he succeeds in saving frank from certain doom . 
<s>  now flooded with memories of a full life with his father alive , john is initially overjoyed , until he discovers that the changes to the timeline have been disastrous : a serial killer that would have died has instead lived to kill seven more women . 
<s>  frank and john now must work together to set things right , with john using the information he has gathered in the future to instruct frank on what to do in the past . 
<s>  the premise of " frequency " is unusual , and requires getting over one very important mental hurdle to fully accept : john and frank are the only ones conscious of how the timeline has been changed as a result of their actions . 
<s>  this isn't explained ; you just have to go with it . 
<s>  when frank doesn't die in a fire , john is the only one who remembers it differently , while everyone else remembers it the new way . 
<s>  the concept also runs into problems concerning just how synchronous the two realities -- 1969 and 1999 -- are to each other . 
<s>  sometimes frank's changing the past results in something happening right away in john's world , and sometimes john gets the changes ahead of time . 
<s>  now , the filmmakers might have perfectly good explanations for this , and i could probably come up with something fairly convoluted ( but nevertheless logical ) if i thought about it hard enough ( for example , the reason john gets advance information of the serial killer's murders was because the change had already happened in frank's world , and john is only witnessing the * projection * of that change ) , but explanations aren't really the point . 
<s>  when " frequency " gets cooking , it's a riveting little thriller , even if it is confusing . 
<s>  what matters to a film like this is if the plot makes sense in the moment , and " frequency " works as long as it keeps moving . 
<s>  the film manages to be engaging despite the logical confusion . 
<s>  director gregory hoblit and screenwriter toby emmerich structure " frequency " as good hollywood entertainment , establishing decent , likable characters , making us care for them , and setting up a goal to be reached and a conflict to be resolved . 
<s>  i liked many of the creative touches : the split screens , allowing us to see how the universe is being affected in both realities , and the greater framework of baseball to drive the action forward . 
<s>  it actually uses the 1969 mets-orioles world series ( the one that featured the amazin' mets ) to great effect -- frank uses john's advance knowledge of the series outcome to convince his friends to believe him . 
<s>   ( admittedly , this device may only be of interest to a baseball fan like myself . ) 
<s>  i even liked the final scene , which features frank and john both fighting the same man simultaneously in different time periods . 
<s>  some may find this scene blindingly confusing , as the reality shifts start coming fast and furious , but it does make sense if you think about it ( and give the script a lot of leeway ) , and let's face it : it's a darn cool way to end the film . 
<s>  there are enough surprises and plot twists in " frequency " to keep you on your toes , and as a result the movie avoids growing stagnant . 
<s>  the other major thing to appreciate about " frequency " is the handling of the father-son relationship . 
<s>  quaid and caviezel carry off their parts easily ; it's a rock-solid job from both actors . 
<s>  the relationship is instantly credible because they find the human truth behind the high concept : how would one react to being able to communicate with a dead relative , or with a future descendant ? 
<s>  watching the exchanges between frank and john will give you a pretty good idea of how to answer that question . 
<s>  the credibility of the human relationship is absolutely crucial to the rest of the film ; if we don't believe in the characters , we don't care about the outcome of the thriller plot . 
<s>  here , we do care , because we like the lead actors . 
<s>  i also liked some of the supporting cast members . 
<s>  elizabeth mitchell gets stuck with two thankless roles , playing julia the doting wife * and * mother , but still performs admirably . 
<s>  andre braugher , late of the television show " homicide : life on the street , " gives a nice supporting turn as frank's best friend and future colleague of john . 
<s>  he has a lovely scene in a diner in which he tries to explain the situation to julia while frank's world series predictions come true before his very eyes . 
<s>  braugher strikes the perfect facial expression here , simultaneously dismayed and amused . 
<s>  perhaps the only thing i didn't like about " frequency " is the overly sentimental coda , during which the camera's focus goes a little too soft and the baseball theme gets carried overboard . 
<s>  but that's only because the film had already earned a poignancy without resorting to cheap tactics . 
<s>  i freely acknowledge that " frequency " may best work as a " guy " movie , since it focuses on the very male-oriented idea of father-son relationships ( echoes of " field of dreams " can be easily heard ) , but the underlying concept is universally applicable . 
<s>  who wouldn't want to speak with a long-dead parent ? 
<s>  or see how their children turn out ? 
<s>   " tell me about your life , son " -- excuse me while i mist up . 
<s>  and don't call me a sissy . 
<s>  blade is the movie that shows that wesley snipes really can live up to his potential as one of hollywood's premier leading men . 
<s>  blade is based on the comic book character of the same name and has that comic book kind of feel to it . 
<s>  it is a very stylish movie and for the most part that style works very well . 
<s>  although , at a few points i thought i was watching a music video as opposed to a movie . 
<s>  the ideas behind blade are good , as is the basic plot of the story . 
<s>  but at times , things seem to get a bit muddled , and the writers appear to want to do too many things at once . 
<s>  that really doesn't take away from the story too much , but it does hurt it a little bit . 
<s>  blade ( snipes ) is half man , half vampire . 
<s>  his mother was bitten by a vampire when she was pregnant with him and as a result he has many of the classic traits of a vampire . 
<s>  including a thirst for human blood that must be kept under control by a special serum which quenches his blood lust . 
<s>  blade has spent his life hunting down and killing vampires as a sort of revenge for the fact that one of their kind killed his mother . 
<s>  but this isn't as easy as it seems , because the vampires in blade's world are more sophisticated than the ones that you find in most films . 
<s>  the government and other authorities know of the existence of vampires , but they let them feast of the population at large because they are taking bribes from the vampires . 
<s>  where do vampires get money ? 
<s>  well , in blade , they run multinational companies in order to finance their vampire organizations . 
<s>  i personally thought that this whole secret corporate world run by vampires to be a very clever idea , and a great addition to the movie . 
<s>  blade runs up against the evil deacon frost ( stephen dorff ) a maverick in the vampire community . 
<s>  he isn't content to live among humans , and is convinced that the vampire race is the superior one and he means to insure its superiority . 
<s>  he has managed to translate the ancient vampire scrolls that tell of the method of making him an all-powerful vampire -- rendering him virtually unstoppable . 
<s>  it's up to blade to see that this doesn't transpire . 
<s>  admittedly , blade is style over substance through and through . 
<s>  the story is a relatively forgettable one , but it is fun none the less . 
<s>  the acting in blade is just about what you would expect from a movie of this type . 
<s>  this isn't a film that is going to win accolades for its performances , and the actors know this . 
<s>  the movie is played for fun and nobody seems to think otherwise . 
<s>  it's a popcorn movie , and no one involved has any illusions otherwise . 
<s>  blade's production values are as slick as any that you will find in your typical summer blockbuster . 
<s>  the combat sequences between blade and his vampire targets are incredibly well done . 
<s>  although , the mtv-style cuts did get on my nerves after a while during long sequences . 
<s>  blade is a fun movie with an interesting take on the vampire genre . 
<s>  this is not the movie for those of you who like your vampires in tuxedos and living in coffins in the basement of some gothic castle . 
<s>  what blade excels at is bringing the classic lore of the vampire into the next century with a fresh outlook on life . 
<s>  very cool . 
<s>  the truman show ( paramount pictures ) running time : 1 hour 42 minutes starring jim carrey and ed harris directed by peter weir after a long wait , jim carrey's dramatic debut finally makes it to the big screen . 
<s>  in case you've been asleep for the last few months , the plot centres on truman burbank ( carrey ) who leads an seemingly idyllic life in the beautiful town of seahaven . 
<s>  his life seems so perfect , however , because it's controlled by christoff ( harris ) creator of the truman show , the program burbank is unwittingly the hero of . 
<s>  that's right , burbank's life is being broadcast live to the american public , and seahaven and all it's inhabitants are inclosed in a massive sound stage . 
<s>  the film takes the jerry springer format one step too far . . . 
<s>  with an idea so different , it would be easy for the director and screenwriter to dumb it down and appeal to the lowest common denominator . 
<s>  luckily , the film remains sensible enough to appeal to all ages , yet never seems to be a dumb carrey movie . 
<s>  talking of carrey , he's perfect in this movie , enjoying the best role in his career . 
<s>  his character is a re-inforced stanley ipkiss from the mask ( 1994 ) and is completely suited to carrey's persona . 
<s>  he occasionally falls into ace ventura mode , shrieking and being silly , but generally the audience is watching subdued carrey . 
<s>  he's not completely dramatic like the film promises , however . 
<s>  ed harris brings an extreme intensity to christoff , the megalomaniac creator of the show . 
<s>  quiet and well spoken , he burns an image into the viewer . 
<s>  unfortunately , he's barely in the film , and for the first hour dosen't appear at all ! 
<s>  also disappointing is natascha mcelhone's character sylvia . 
<s>  she plays the role well , but her character is sadly underwritten and is pushed to the sidelines just when the audience is used to her . 
<s>  the supporting cast is excellent , and the town of seahaven looks delightfully perfect , so perfect it's creepy . 
<s>  the philip glass soundtrack is also superb , and is used to great effect during the film . 
<s>  peter weir keeps the film going , clearly having fun . 
<s>  the film is far more upbeat than his previous films dead poets society and green card . 
<s>  although it is slightly slow to begin with , about half an hour into film the pace really picks up , and when christoff is introduced fully the film is on a roll . 
<s>  sadly , though , the film is practically over when the film is in full steam . 
<s>  also , concerning the ending , it is slightly too ambiguous , which was disappointing . 
<s>  the screenwriter , andrew niccol , who bought us gattaca ( 1997 ) delivers an entertaining script , and manages to keep the plot in trim . 
<s>  while christoff's plans to keep truman in do get increasingly silly , they never go over the line , which would have been easy for niccol to do . 
<s>  also , there's some funny gags involving product placement and the people who watch the show . 
<s>  overall , the truman show is excellent entertainment . 
<s>  certainly different from the usual crap hollywood produces , it should be viewed by everyone . 
<s>  it offers something to every member of the audience , and you would almost certainly not come out disappointed .
