<s>  review : a dog of flanders is the story of an adorable little boy named nello and his trials and tribulations in 19th century flanders . 
<s>  living with his grandfather jehan ( jack warden ) in poverty , nello finds happiness in his life in spite of difficult times ( they are renting a spare one-room cottage , and the greedy , malevolent landlord who owns it threatens to throw them `out of the house' if they don't pay the rent ) . 
<s>  nello also has a rather creative talent for drawing some of the most beautiful pictures that i have ever seen , in either a movie or in real life . 
<s>   ( his hero is peter paul rubens , the great flemish painter of the 17th century . ) 
<s>  not that these are the only things that make nello's life happy , however . 
<s>  he has a dog of flanders , whom he names patrasche , who is a heroic rin-tin-tin of the 19th century , whom he rescues from his cruel , unkind master . 
<s>  in addition , he even has a best friend ( and future sweetheart ) in the lovely , wealthy aloise , whose father strongly disapproves of her hanging out with `lower-class' nello . 
<s>   ( he thinks he's not good enough for her , and he would hate the idea of the two kids marrying . ) 
<s>  but then , he was a poor guy himself before he married ( as mentioned later on in the film ) . 
<s>  one day , nello encounters a mysterious , yet kindhearted artist named michel la grande ( played wonderfully by jon voight ) , who tells the boy to keep drawing from his heart , and that perhaps one day he might land a career in being an artist . 
<s>  and every christmas , there is a contest on which is the most beautiful painting of the year ; the winner getting a lot of money . 
<s>  eager to save his home ( and his aging , dying grandfather ) , nello willingly decides to become an artist , asking aloise to pose for him . 
<s>  one night , the two travel to a circus , where they have their fortune told ? one of the film's most delightful scenes ? that great happiness is destined for them . 
<s>  she gives the kids a ring , whom nello places on aloise's hand . 
<s>   ; ) afterwards , the two kids have a rollickingly good time dancing around in front of circus performers . 
<s>  unfortunately , things are not all `la-dee-dah' in this tale . 
<s>  aloise's father finally becomes so angry with nello that he forbids him to ever see aloise again . 
<s>  bad enough that they can't see each other ( although we know nello and aloise , don't we ? ) , but that's only the start of nello's troubles . 
<s>  aloise's farm is burned down , and nello is wrongfully accused ( by the landord of his cottage ) for starting the fire in order to take revenge on being forbidden to see aloise . 
<s>  this decreases nello's reputation around the town , save aloise and her parents , and a kindly miller , william , who is very sweet to nello every time he drops by . 
<s>  matters get much worse for nello when his grandfather dies , and he has to pay for his funeral . 
<s>  but then things really get nasty when the landlord exiles nello from his own home ( for not paying his rental ) ? permanetly . 
<s>  this means that nello and patrasche have to starve and walk out in the cold , freezing wind . 
<s>  worst of all , the painting that he has desperately been working on during all this time , `the portrait of the princess' , fails to win the prize at the festival . 
<s>  now nello and patrasche are really depressed , and close to freezing to death . 
<s>  will nello be able to find any happiness in his life ? 
<s>  will patrasche save the day ? 
<s>  will nello make the fateful trip to join his mother and grandfather in paradise ? 
<s>  a dog of flanders is a delightful , heartwarming family film that is sure to entertain kids of all ages . 
<s>  even older ones who consider themselves too `sophisticated' for kiddie fare will be surprised to hear that this film is for grown-ups , too . 
<s>  there have been other movies of this ilk ( boy and dog ) , and while this one falls into that category , it is mostly a story about overcoming difficulties and finding a good home for yourself . 
<s>  move over ? or rather , roll over ? old yeller , this dog of flanders is a heartwarming delight . 
<s>  the cinematography , courtesy of walther van den ende is beautiful , and really adds to the powerful drama of the film . 
<s>  it also gives a feel of being in flanders ( the whole film was respectably shot in flanders ) . 
<s>  the music from richard friedman is also remarkable ; an evocative , poignant score that recaptures music from the 19th century . 
<s>  the opening song over the credits is very beautiful ( i hope the soundtrack is available ! ) , and there's a brief excerpt of `cheer up , charlie' from willy wonka and the chocolate factory ( sung by aloise , to nello , in another delightful scene ) . 
<s>  the cast is first-rate : jesse james and jeremy james kissner , who play nello , are some of the most endearing , adorable young stars i have ever seen in my whole life ( so are the girls who play aloise , madyline sweeten as the younger , and farren monet as the older ) . 
<s>  not that they are the only good stars , however . 
<s>  jack warden is ideal as jehan , eliciting just the right amount of humor and compassion required for the character . 
<s>   ( the scenes involving him and nello are heartwarming , touching ones . ) 
<s>  also , bruce mcgill is charming as the kindly miller william . 
<s>  he's another one of my favorite characters in the film . 
<s>  but jon voight , as i mentioned before , is the perfect choice for michel . 
<s>  he brings a mysterious , yet gentle performance that makes us all feel good again when he reassures insecure nello that he * can * win the contest . 
<s>  but what makes this film fun to watch is how well-defined the characters are , and the pace of the story ( best of all , it has a happy ending ? though i will * not * give it away ; sorry ) is strong and powerful enough for us to identify with the characters . 
<s>  for the first time since the beginning of 1999 , there comes a film which doesn't rely on popular formula stuff , such as big-budget special effects , commercial rock soundtracks , or any of that stuff . 
<s>  this one relies on telling a fully character-oriented story , with just the right amount of heart , humor , and drama . 
<s>  that , to me , is what makes a dog of flanders all the more delightful . 
<s>  eleanor o'sullivan of `the home news & tribune' noticed this , and was kind and generous enough to welcome it : `for want of a better word , a glow surrounds a dog of flanders . 
<s>  its heart is in the right place and it engages you . 
<s>  you can guess where the film is going because this is well-traveled territory , but with pros like voight and appealing young performers like kissner , an often-told story is well worth a revisit . ' 
<s>  in addition , there were a couple of other enthusiasts , such as chicago-sun times and the washington post ( you should read their reviews ; they're really positive ) . 
<s>  other critics , however , were not so kind . 
<s>  stephen holden of `the new york times' had more than a share of beatings to lay upon a dog of flanders via pen writing . 
<s>  he found the film to be a `sea of sugary bromides' and condemned mr . voight's character as `hopelessly wooden ? adopts an accent even more indeterminate than the one he came up with for anaconda . ' 
<s>  in addition , `entertainment weekly' slam-dunked the film , condemning it as `the worst family film of the year . ' 
<s>  there have been so many other bad reviews like this , too . 
<s>  my suggestion : disregard the critics . 
<s>  they just have a big problem with touching family films , and one should never pay attention to them . 
<s>  this dog of flanders may only be a little `family' movie ( it probably won't be a big hit in the style of titanic , but then again no other film has been since then ) , but that is not a bad thing in and of itself . 
<s>  this is a story that is sure to warm your heart , and that is what really matters about a dog of flanders . 
<s>  it is also one of the better family films around this year . 
<s>  none of the other films i have seen this year ( though they were good ) have been so low-key and touching . 
<s>  if you're looking for family-style entertainment , look no further than this charming boy-and-dog yarn . 
<s>  go see it while you still can , for as i mentioned , it might not be a big bow-wow at the box office for a long time . 
<s>  see it while you can . 
<s>  there is really no need to compare a multi-million dollar blockbuster such as star wars : episode i ? the phantom menace or tarzan , or even the iron giant with a tender , sweet little family movie . 
<s>  do film critics have morals ? 
<s>  are there any unwritten laws an ethical movie critic would or should follow ? 
<s>  naturally we don't want to go into a film with any preconceived notions , which is pretty tough but something we all have to accomplish . 
<s>  secondly , and along the same line , we can't prejudge a film because of it's stars , director , etc . the difference ? 
<s>  well , in the first one , we'd go into a film thinking it's going to be dumb or it's going to be good , and that would affect our viewing ( that movie sounds and looks dumb , so i'm not expecting much ) . 
<s>  on the second hand , we're simply assuming it will be bad or good because of a personal " grudge " against the film company ( it's made by disney ? 
<s>  oh , it's just a merchandising ploy then ) , the actors ( jim carrey's in it ? 
<s>  it's gonna stink ! ) , or the director ( who ? 
<s>  can't be that good ) . 
<s>  this is more of a biased viewpoint as opposed to a first impression viewpoint . 
<s>  make sense ? 
<s>  ok , but what about comparing ? 
<s>  isn't that kind of along the same lines ? 
<s>  when we compare a certain actor or director or even composer's credibility in one film to another they were involved in , is that really fair ? 
<s>  sure , in sequels you can expect and accept comparisons a lot more , but what about jackie brown , for example ? 
<s>  is it fair for me to take the review and turn it into a comparison of pulp fiction , just because quentin tarantino directed and wrote the screenplay for both ? 
<s>  i think it is , and i'll tell you why . 
<s>  a good critic should be able to view the film from the " average joe ( or jane ) " viewpoint , while still taking into account the artistic integrity behind the film . 
<s>  sometimes that can be tough . 
<s>   " the acting was superb , but i was bored " or " i loved it ! ! 
<s>  it was sooooo cheezy ! " 
<s>  might be used to describe a film . 
<s>  these are contradictions , and a critic has to weigh both sides and come to a suitable balanced critique . 
<s>  but which is more important ? 
<s>  and which is better ? 
<s>  an extremely well shot and acted film that is boring , or a really amateurish film that you wanna go back to again and again ? 
<s>  getting back to the point , my philosophy on comparing films being fair works because we're reflecting what the public wants to know anyway . 
<s>  every average person out there who's interested in this film is likely to ask " how does it compare to pulp fiction ? " 
<s>  and so , as a critic , i'm already responsible to ask that same question . 
<s>  jackie brown stars pam grier , the " blaxploitation " heroine from the 1970's , who is likely to make a big comeback thanks to her role as the title character . 
<s>  tarantino's pulp fiction is in big part responsible for john travolta's sudden revival in the movie industry , and with talks of an oscar nomination , the same is likely to happen for grier . 
<s>   ( we've made it thru comparison #1 ! ) jackie is a 44-year-old airline stewardess who brings in extra cash , and probably her main revenue , by smuggling large sums of money into the united states for ordell robbie ( pulp fiction's samuel l . jackson and comparison #2 ) . 
<s>  ordell is in the illegal firearms business and has enlisted the aid of louis gara ( robert de niro ) , a bank robber who just got out of prison after serving four years , to help him accomplish a scheme worth a half- million dollars . 
<s>  trouble arises when jackie is stopped by atf agent ray nicolet ( michael keaton ) and taken into custody for possession of narcotics , as well as having more money than is allowed in an airport without being claimed . 
<s>  naturally this proves an obstacle to ordell's plans and , not as friendly intended as we'd hope , he posts jackie's bail after she is put behind bars . 
<s>  the thing is , ordell is in this for no one more than himself , and as we learn from his previous actions , he's willing to kill anyone who stands in the way . 
<s>  jackie finds herself in a tight squeeze . 
<s>  ordell won't think twice about taking her out if she fails to help him as she's always done , yet at the same time , a compromise with the authorities would be in order if evidence against ordell was provided . 
<s>  it comes down to a simple question : would jackie rather face ordell or prison ? 
<s>  what ensues is a rich and intriguing example of storytelling as we question who jackie is really out to help : the law , ordell , or maybe just herself . 
<s>  coming into play is another 70's veteran , robert forster as jackie's bail bondsmen max cherry . 
<s>  max's obvious fondness for jackie will become a major benefactor in her fight to beat both sides of the system , and forster plays him with subtle charm that adds depth to unbrewed romance . 
<s>  also involved is ordell's " surfer girl " girlfriend melanie ( bridget fonda ) , a ditzy sun- bleached babe who spends her time watching tv with a bong in hand . 
<s>  fonda does the best she can with an essentially thin role , but there's nothing more to her , and therefore , she becomes a tossable addition to an otherwise flourishing bouquet of characters . 
<s>  de niro is also wasted in his role as a quiet nobody crook out to score a few bucks for himself . 
<s>  de niro is a brilliant actor , but a character who hardly ever speaks doesn't need a de niro to play him . 
<s>  compared to pulp fiction ( comparison #3 ) , the characters in jackie brown and very thin and replaceable . 
<s>  in pulp fiction , even the small , seemingly irrelevant characters were wonderful , complete , and lifelike , whereas jackie brown has such common figures that it wouldn't have suffered much with a lesser talented cast , the exception being grier . 
<s>  tarantino wrote this script with grier specifically in mind , so to say that she is made for this role is a reversed truth . 
<s>  sadly , grier too could have received a bit more attention , especially when the story is all about her newly-jarred perception of life . 
<s>  jackson teams up with tarantino again , but the chemical reaction isn't as awesome as the first time . 
<s>  jules was the rambling , bible-quoting hitman in pulp fiction , and jackson is the only person who could have pulled it off . 
<s>  and although jackson is really , really good in jackie brown , i don't think he's quite as irreplaceable . 
<s>  in fact , maybe a new face would have been better . 
<s>  jackson could've remained tarantino's jules , and a new guy could have become ordell , forever to remain so in our memories . 
<s>  sadly , these characters are too much the same , except ordell just isn't as impressive , and putting this in the hands of jackson once again is only going to deter from our fond recollections of jules . 
<s>  another problem is that ordell is way too focused on in the beginning . 
<s>  this is grier's film , so why spend so long getting to know a man who will become more of a supporting character as the film progresses ? 
<s>  it not only makes the movie feel a little too slanted , but it makes for a slow beginning because we have to take longer getting to the meat of the story . 
<s>  it is likely that those pouring into the theater to see this film are going to be those anxious to partake of tarantino's quirky dialogue and eccentric directing style , and not so much those interested in seeing a silver screen adaption of elmore leonard's novel " rum punch " . 
<s>  for those movie-goers , don't expect another pulp fiction and you'll be satisfied , for the script oozes with the familiar brash qualities that has made tarantino an icon of 90's film- making . 
<s>  the directing has toned down a bit , however , yet we're still reminded that this is tarantino's movie thanks to odd split-screen story-telling devices and scenes being replayed multiple times from different viewpoints . 
<s>  so getting back to the question that i began with , this isn't pulp fiction at all . 
<s>  it's good , but it isn't anything that made pulp fiction such a revolutionary effort in the first place . 
<s>  this is a more conservative tarantino , but not one that won't satiate true fans . 
<s>  if you can realize that this isn't going to knock your socks off , then you'll be happy to at least let it massage your feet . 
<s>  after all , we all know how much tarantino loves that particular part of the human anatomy . 
<s>  synopsis : retiring detective jerry black ( nicholson ) becomes involved in the case of a murdered girl , and promises her parents that he will find the killer . 
<s>  he purchases a gas station on a route he believes the killer takes , and there befriends lori ( wright penn ) and her young daughter . 
<s>  as jerry and lori fall in love , can he do what must be done to fulfill his pledge ? 
<s>  review : at first , " the pledge " appears to be just another standard , if well-executed , crime drama . 
<s>  it is anything but ; in its final hour , it turns the corner and becomes a riveting , terrifying study of its lead character , jerry black . 
<s>  penn pays attention to all the trappings of the serial killer genre , but they are just window dressing . 
<s>  his interest here , unequivocally , is jerry , a man so haunted by his pledge that it consumes the entirety of the his existence . 
<s>  at first , we see this only in small hints ; some of his habits change , for instance , and he suddenly takes up smoking in a big way . 
<s>  but then , when jerry buys the gas station and befriends lori , the true extent of his mania draws horrifyingly into focus . 
<s>  nicholson is fantastic , portraying black with rare subtlety and animus ; jerry's gradual descent into obsession is like a car wreck , a thing horrible to look at but impossible to turn away from . 
<s>  penn coaxes good supporting performances from much of the rest of his cast , too . 
<s>  only eckhart disappoints as jerry's replacement , stan ; he never seems entirely convincing , too much a tool of the plot . 
<s>  penn's direction is astounding , each frame looking as though it is parched -- of water , perhaps , or of sanity . 
<s>  it all builds up to a shattering , devastating climax which lingers uncomfortably in the mind long after the house lights have come up . 
<s>  one never quite knows what one is going to get with a mamet film . 
<s>  his american buffalo is a set-bound piece that has very little plot . 
<s>  sometimes he will tell a story that really moves . 
<s>  heist is mamet doing his most entertaining work . 
<s>  unlike his the spanish prisoner , there are no lapses in credibility . 
<s>  heist is probably the best mamet thriller since house of games . 
<s>  it is the kind of plot with which you are never sure who will double-cross whom , and frequently it is mamet double-crossing the viewer . 
<s>  watching the film's team getting around security the viewer is frequently asking himself either " what the heck are they doing ? " 
<s>  or " why didn't anybody think of that before ? " 
<s>  appropriately enough heist opens with a very clever jewelry store job . 
<s>  it is so clever that one wonders if mamet really thinks up all these ideas himself or if he has help from professional magician and con expert ricky jay , now a regular actor in mamet films . 
<s>  this is a robbery that works like a well-oiled machine . 
<s>  there is just one problem and it is enough to get joe moore ( played by gene hackman ) filmed on a security camera . 
<s>  now joe has to get out of the business . 
<s>  it was coming time anyway . 
<s>  joe's team including bobby blane ( delroy lindo ) , fran moor ( rebecca pidgeon ) , and pinky pincus ( ricky jay ) is going to split up and go separate ways . 
<s>  but crime boss bergman ( danny devito ) is pulling the strings and he says that joe and his people have to manage one more robbery . 
<s>  and he has to take along a young kid , the short- fused jimmy silk ( sam rockwell ) . 
<s>  immediately it is obvious that there is more going on than meets the eye . 
<s>  much of what distinguishes heist is mamet's dialog . 
<s>  remarkably it serves a double purpose . 
<s>  the robbery team sounds at once very professional and at the same time it has mamet's special feel for dialog . 
<s>  hackman has lines like " everybody needs money . 
<s>  that's why they call it money . " 
<s>  mamet's timing is perfect in the direction but terrible in the production . 
<s>  the plot is coincidentally a lot like the plot of the recent the score , which is , in fact , a very similar story . 
<s>  both are good films , perhaps for some of the same reasons . 
<s>  but at least on a high level they are much the same story . 
<s>  the other problem with the timing of heist is that it involves airport security and clever ways to get around them . 
<s>  i saw the film at the toronto international film festival on september 12 , 2001 . 
<s>  that made the subject matter just a little too timely . 
<s>  my understanding is that the release will be delayed . 
<s>  my biggest problem with the film is that rebecca pidgeon's acting at times seems very poor . 
<s>  it is some kind of mamet trademark i do not understand to have women talk without inflection , as if they are just reading the words for the first time . 
<s>  it is an irritation and distracts us from what is otherwise a very good thriller . 
<s>  it is one i rate an 8 on the 0 to 10 scale and a high +2 on the -4 to +4 scale . 
<s>  'contact' shows why jodie foster is one of our best actresses . 
<s>  see contact with your family . 
<s>  it is a movie for all ages . 
<s>  --a review by stuart cracraft 
<s>  contact starring : jodie foster , matthew mcconaughey , john hurt director : robert zemeckis star 
<s>  after a predictable mit phillip morrison powers-of-10 zoom-out start ( which can be surprising to those not familiar with prof . morrison's work ) , contact picks up steam , gradually , building , by-the-end , an irresistable juggernaut and a very good movie that does not as is so often the case fall out-of-balance in terms of too much pandering to the technological " geek " side . 
<s>  by the end , the audience is left with what good science fiction is supposed to do : evoke a sense of wonder about the universe and evoke questions in your mind about what's out there . 
<s>  this movie does not let technology overshadow characterization and in this sense it is unusual amongst high-tech movies . 
<s>  however , except for jodie foster ( elie arroway ) and john hurt ( s . r . 
<s>  hadden ) , who are both actors of exceptional caliber , the supporting cast are not especially impressive . 
<s>  hurt certainly has had better roles ( stephen ward in scandal ) . 
<s>  this one , as the multi-billionare hadden , does not do his acting skills justice . 
<s>  this is clearly a foster movie by one of the great hollywood lights of our generation . 
<s>  foster's radiance has never been more strong than in the scene where she finally meets the vegans on their terms . 
<s>  early scenes take a long , long time to build up to this . 
<s>  the movie's pacing is very good and subtle . 
<s>  the panoramas of the radio dishes at arecibo and ceti in new mexico and puerto rico are beautiful . 
<s>  the politics of foster's character attempting to obtain funding for research at these places are trite and predictable however . 
<s>  one of the most entertaining , but very short scenes , is when foster is confronted by rob lowe , during a cabinet-level presidential meeting to discuss the alien invitation . 
<s>  there were real sparks in this scene between foster and lowe and it would behoove them to consider other vehicles in which this dynamism could be explored . 
<s>  it is the only scene in the movie in which there were tremendous dynamics between two characters . 
<s>  everything else was very one-sided ( e . g . 
<s>  foster ) . 
<s>  lowe can stand up to foster and it showed in that scene at the cabinet table . 
<s>  the core scene of the movie is set on a surrealistic beach on a far-away world in the starsystem of vega . 
<s>  it feels a lot like science fiction writer john varley's scenes in his book steel beach , where the female protagonists encounters an immensely superior intelligence , in one case a computer manufactured by mankind itself , and in foster's case , an illusion drawn from her memory . 
<s>  in another sense , this immensely moving scene evokes gene roddenberry's star trek pilot the cage , later the menagerie , when jeffrey hunter and susan oliver have their memories manipulated to create new worlds in which they live and encounter aliens . 
<s>  the concept is not new , by any sense , in the world of science fiction . 
<s>  but the beach scene , which is the centerpiece of the film , as is the whole film , is driven by foster . 
<s>  freed from her needs to direct by director zemecki , foster is able to let it all hang out in the characterization and the lead she provides to her supporting cast . 
<s>  as the movie gains speed , foster's acting intensifies and the audience really does experience it with her . 
<s>  it is certainly oscar-caliber acting , unquestionably . 
<s>  the supporting cast does well and zemeckis throws in some humor with some president clinton cameos , cleverly manipulated , george stephanopolus-style , to seem very forrest gump . 
<s>  in fact , zemeckis et . 
<s>  al . 
<s>  got in trouble for the usage of some of the footage seen in the movie , vis a vis clinton . 
<s>  but the audience i attended this movie with just had some good chuckles at clinton's walk-ons . 
<s>  the much-discussed tension between science and religion in this movie is not particularly insightful to those who have already gone through this course though it is helpful to those in the audience who have not . 
<s>  also , the near-final scene , in a senate judiciary hearing room is disappointing . 
<s>  contact is a fitting memorial to the memory of carl sagan , science popularizer , and sometime pedantic gadfly of the halls of academe . 
<s>  perhaps now , sagan can be said to be with his dragons of eden . 
<s>  like the wonderful 1990 drama , " awakenings , " starring robin williams and robert de niro , " at first sight , " directed by irwin winkler , is inspired by a true story documented by physicfirst sight , " directed by irwin winkler , is inspired by a true story documented by physician oliver sacks . 
<s>  since " awakenings " was so very good , and made my top ten list the year it was released , " at first sight " is not quite as strong since it is not directed with as sure a hand as penny marshall , but is still an intelligent and vibrantly-acted drama . 
<s>  the film begins as amy ( mira sorvino ) , a stressed-out new york architect , decides to take some time off and travel upstate to the country . 
<s>  at the hotel she is staying at , she makes a massage appointment and after a long , soothing session which ends with her crying as a release of emotions , she strikes up a conversation with the handsome masseur virgil ( val kilmer ) , only to find out later that he is actually blind . 
<s>  amy doesn't really care if he has a handicap or not , and begins to spend time with him more and more until they finally start to fall in love . 
<s>  once she has returned to new york , amy begins to research on virgil's certain type of retinal blindness , which he has had since three years of age , and out of a stroke of luck , comes into contact with a doctor ( bruce davison ) who believes he can repair virgil's sight , even though there have only been thirty similar cases in history . 
<s>  at first reluctant , virgil finally travels with amy to nyc and agrees to the surgery , much to the hesitance of his overbearing , but loving older sister ( kelly mcgillis ) . 
<s>  ultimately , the surgery is a success , but problems arise since virgil cannot relate to what he sees , since he has never visually seen anything before , only touched objects . 
<s>  he moves into amy's apartment and she is eager to stand by him , but virgil's maladjustment begins to put a strain on their relationship . 
<s>  on the basis of the overall story , " at first sight " is indeed a film that has been done many times before , and owes a great deal to its predecessor , " awakenings . " 
<s>  what will happen throughout the film can also be easily telegraphed in advance . 
<s>  however , what helps " at first sight " rise above this predictability is in the mature and intelligent relationship that develops between virgil and amy . 
<s>  usually , romantic pictures are of the shameless puppy-dog sort ( the recent tom hanks/meg ryan-starrer " you've got mail " immediately pops to mind ) , but with this film , i grew to care more about the characters and their plight . 
<s>  the film starts off noticably well as amy travels up north and first meets virgil . 
<s>  the massaging sequences were strangely erotic , maybe even more so than the later actual " love scenes , " and as their romantic involvement quickly developed , the film was both entertaining and sweet , and there was clearly a lot of chemistry between the two . 
<s>  these joyous moments early on balanced out well with the later scenes in which their relationship is seriously tested due to a contrast in the life styles that they have always known , with virgil completely used to being blind and having a comforting , peaceful life in the country to amy's eventful life in the " big city . " 
<s>  the other major compliment that must be given to the film are the nearly flawless performances across the board . 
<s>  val kilmer , usually cast in the " macho " type of role , was always believable as a blind person , and playing his character was probably a little more tricky than it appears . 
<s>  it was up to kilmer to not come off as someone to pity , but to sympathize with , and he pulled it off . 
<s>  mira sorvino , who made a spectacular debuting splash in 1995's hilarious woody allen comedy , " mighty aphrodite , " for which she won a well-deserved oscar as a kind-hearted , but ditzy hooker , is a standout here . 
<s>  although she has made some mediocre film choices since then ( 1997's " mimic , " 1998's " the replacement killers " ) , she always has managed to come out unscathed , and it is with " at first sight " that she finally has another juicy role to play . 
<s>  in a truthful climactic scene set in amy's apartment between she and virgil , sorvino proves to be one of the most gifted young actresses around today , and has a flare for both comedic and dramatic pieces . 
<s>  kelly mcgillis , who could have easily come off as the " bad , " one-dimensional sister , instead is also given an unexpectedly multifaceted character to play as a woman who may be overly protective but simply cares for her brother . 
<s>  finally , nathan lane , who is usually a little too over-the-top , is appropriately restrained as a vision therapist . 
<s>  the one misstep of " at first sight " is in its treatment of the medical procedure done on virgil . 
<s>  very little is ever said or discussed concerning it , and when the surgery occurs , it is so briefly glimpsed at that it is impossible to see what is being done to his eyes . 
<s>  perhaps the reason this aspect of the film was not more in-depth was that the makers were afraid it would gross out audiences , but i would personally take realism , even if it is graphic , any day over simply giving the explanation of the surgery the cold shoulder . 
<s>  in " awakenings , " the patients and illness were far more satisfyingly portrayed . 
<s>  because of how strong the screenplay , written by steve levitt , is in the way it deals with the main relationship , and because of the fabulous performances from kilmer and sorvino , the film's few problems can be swept over to the side . 
<s>  the adult way that the romance is depicted by director irwin winkler is , no doubt , in respect to the real-life couple that the film was inspired by , who are still together after many years ( even though the setting of the film was changed to new york ) . 
<s>  since january is usually the time of year that is known as the dumping ground from bad movies , " at first sight " comes as a refreshing and sophisticated change of pace . 
<s>  in the company of men made a splash at the sundance film festival because , in a year plagued by brothers mcmullen-style , earnestly shallow gen-x angst pictures , it seemed to be actually about something . 
<s>  it angered people , started arguments outside the theater , riled things up . 
<s>  it ignited a spark of excitement in what otherwise has been a disappointing year for independent film . 
<s>  having endured my share of the hype , i waited calmly for men to reach the hinterlands wherein i reside , and then checked in to see what all the fuss was about . 
<s>  does men live up to its press ? 
<s>  well , yes it does . 
<s>  and it may make you think twice before you consider dating anyone your office . 
<s>  for the uninitiated , newcomers aaron eckhart and matt malloy play chad and howard , two corporate drones who are dispatched by their nameless company to a remote branch office for a six week assignment . 
<s>  chad and howard are archetypes , examples of which you can no doubt find in your own place of business . 
<s>  chad is the blond golden boy , genetically engineered for success , the natural charmer who seems to glide effortlessly up the corporate ladder . 
<s>  howard is chad's boss , but he is weaker of will , the clumsy practitioner of office politics who has achieved his position through dogged persistence rather than raw talent . 
<s>  we first meet them awaiting their flight in a drab airport lounge . 
<s>  there chad suggests a scheme worthy of a shakespearean villain : he and howard will find a vulnerable single woman at the branch office , woo her simultaneously , win her love , and then dump her . 
<s>  the reason ? 
<s>  both men have recently been dumped themselves , and chad sees an easy route to revenge against the fairer sex . 
<s>   " it'll restore a little dignity to our lives , " he says . 
<s>  howard , helpless against the force of chad's will , agrees to the plan . 
<s>  they quickly spot their prey in the form of christine ( stacy edwards ) , a fragile deaf woman working as a temp . 
<s>  chad moves in for the kill , flashing his golden boy smile , plying christine with lunch , then flowers , then dinner . 
<s>  howard follows suit , though his efforts are in contrast ham-handed and desperate . 
<s>  flattered to have the attention of two eligible men , christine dates them both . 
<s>  you can guess which one she falls for . 
<s>  soon a tragic lovers' triangle develops : christine loves chad , chad loves himself , and howard loves christine on the grounds that , since she's handicapped and shy , she just might be wretched and lonely enough to settle for him . 
<s>  adult social interaction never really progresses beyond the level of junior high , does it ? 
<s>  in chad , writer/director labute and actor eckhart have created one of the most chilling monsters ever committed to film-hannibal lector may eat human flesh , but chad is an eater of souls . 
<s>  his evil is as subtle as a viper's , and as easy as his smile . 
<s>  we watch in stunned disbelief as he back-stabs coworkers , humiliates his subordinates , and works his deadly venom into christine's heart . 
<s>  his character would be a joke if he wasn't so chillingly real- all of us have worked with a chad , and some of us may be him . 
<s>  he's the guy who takes your job and then laughs at you for your weakness . 
<s>  if one of his co-workers should happen to go postal and walk into the office with a bag full of handguns , he had best have his escape route clearly in mind . 
<s>  politics is his game , and the modern cubicle-filled office is his playground . 
<s>  men wears the guise of a black comedy , but it functions best as allegory . 
<s>  the most controversial moment in the film happens when chad humiliates a black temp by asking him how badly he wants to succeed in the company , then forces him to prove it in a manner i won't describe . 
<s>  the scene is charged with racism and fraught with peril . 
<s>  could it happen in the real world ? 
<s>  probably not . 
<s>  taken as allegory , however , it is representative of the treatment of the meek by the powerful in all facets of society . 
<s>  maybe it's just the english major in me , but chad , in his motiveless cruelty towards christine and his careful manipulation of howard , can be seen as a symbol of unbridled capitalism , of greed without conscience . 
<s>  the entire film is a metaphor for social darwinism- only the strong will survive . 
<s>  the marvel of labute's multi-layered script is that it can disturb each member of its audience in an entirely different way . 
<s>  but does the film work as entertainment ? 
<s>  its darned funny in spots , particularly in the men's room scenes , which demonstrate the lengths to which guys will go to hold a conversation while engaged in the most basic of bodily functions . 
<s>  it works less well as drama , since by necessity the characters in an allegory tend to be flat ciphers . 
<s>  stacy edwards gives a measured dignity to christine , and succeeds in making us care for her , but by the end of the film we still know nothing about her . 
<s>  likewise , chad and howard are simply the sum of their actions . 
<s>  by the end of the film you'll feel as if you've met a genuine monster in chad ; perhaps we can also classify men as a horror film . 
<s>  certainly those expecting a conventional hollywood resolution to the story will walk away disappointed . 
<s>  but the picture is often mesmerizing , and the script is a work of fine craftsmanship , which makes it well worth your time . 
<s>  like all good films , it offers a myriad of parallels to the outside world . 
<s>  while watching chad in his moment of triumph , i couldn't help but think that bill gates must have felt the same sort of cold , merciless satisfaction when he finally stuck it to steve jobs . 
<s>  there may be a little bit of chad in all of us , but some of us have taken chad-ness to the level of art . 
<s>  the booming introduction music finishes , and the camera sweeps over red mountains . 
<s>  we see two figures looking over a barren , and very red landscape . 
<s>  they kiss , then walk on . 
<s>  one of the characters ( schwarzenegger ) slips , and falls . 
<s>  the glass on his mask cracks . 
<s>  his face scruches up , and his eye's begin to pop . . . . . 
<s>  then doug quaid , played by schwarzenegger , wakes up . 
<s>  it's all been a dream . 
<s>  he wakes up next to his beautiful wife , played by stone , and the film begins . . . 
<s>  total recall is a typical sci-fi film wrapped around an intresting ( if far fetched ) plot . 
<s>  quaid , who has never been to mars , keeps on having dreams of the planet , which has now been colanised . 
<s>  one day , while riding on a train , he's see's a ad for a company called 'rekall' , which implants memories of a holiday , instead of you actually going there yourself . 
<s>  quaid chooses the 'secret agent on mars' memory , and then the s * * * really hits the fan . 
<s>  the implant goes wrong , and quaid really thinks he is an agent on mars for about two minutes , until he goes back to normal and can't remember a thing . 
<s>  however , everyone he knows ( his workmates , his wife ) turn against him , saying how 'blabbed about mars' and 'blew his cover on the mission' a strange man , called richter , played by ironside , wants to kill him . 
<s>  quaid , now hopelessly confused , follows the advice given to him , by a 'friend' . 
<s>  he get's his ass to mars . 
<s>  mars is ruled by cohagen , played by cox , who charges people for air . 
<s>  against him are the rebels , who are mainly mutants . 
<s>  the rebel's need quaid to defeat cohagen , because quaid knows ( but can't remember yet ) about a reactor that produces air . 
<s>  eventually , quaid kills cohagen , turns on the reactor , saves the planet , and goes away with a beautiful girl , just like the guy at rekall promised him . 
<s>  throughout this plot , there is huge explosions , thousands of deaths ( and i mean a lot of death ) swearing , sex , and everything else that make's a good verhoeven ( director of basic instinct and starship troopers ) movie . 
<s>  naturally , there's some pretty imaginative deaths , with arms getting ripped off , someone getting drilled , and heads exploding . 
<s>  as you can tell , it's violent stuff . 
<s>  but it's done so stylishly , and of course arnie tones it down with a one liner , that's it excusable . 
<s>  the acting is variable . 
<s>  arnie , of course , is useless , but he goes has some good lines , and in the first twenty minutes , he even act's like a normal bloke , not like some action hero . 
<s>  stone , of course , is useless , making a pretty poor wife , and a pretty poor action hero . 
<s>  but , she does sex scenes alright . 
<s>  ticoton ( most recently seen in con air ) , again , is ok , doing some good action , but getting her emotions all wrong . 
<s>  one minute she hates quaid , the next she loves him , and she never gets this tranisition right . 
<s>  so , the good guys are awful . 
<s>  but , the bad guy's are excellent . 
<s>  cox is basically reprising robocop , but he's still great in this , and he delivers the best line in the whole film near the end . 
<s>  ironside is superbly evil , with an utterly emotionless face . 
<s>  the supporting cast are fine , and not even the comedy sidekick ( this time in the form of a taxi driver ) is annoying . 
<s>  one disappointing aspect , though , are the special effects . 
<s>  ilm and dreamquest do some good work ( such as a subway station scene ) but the model work is not so good . 
<s>  some of the model heads look appaling fake , and quatto is a major disappointment . 
<s>  another irritating thing is the product placement . 
<s>  there are a lot of plugs ( and a good mars today gag ) however , the sets look great , and the special effects at the end of the film aren't too bad either . 
<s>  there's also a good soundtrack running through , by jerry goldsmith ( the omen , poltergeist , star trek : the motion picture ) 
<s>  overall , then , total recall is a hugely violent , yet hugely enjoyable , action fest , with a reasonable plot thrown in there too , some great bad guys , and some imaganitive death . 
<s>  for a schwarzenegger movie , this is not bad at all . 
<s>  in fact , it's very good . 
<s>  jonathan demme's _beloved_ , based on the book toni morrison , is a study in skillful literary adaptation . 
<s>  on the one hand , the film manages to recreate key moments from the novel , evoking morrison's pragmatic narrative style without using her authorial voice . 
<s>  on the other hand , beloved omits the some of the finer details of the book , favoring an ambiguously defined back story upon which to build the story's main events . 
<s>  this choice is a smartly made one , for it creates an open space in which the story's wide range of emotions can gestate and grow . 
<s>  indeed , the impact of the film is so protracted that much of it cannot be felt until long after the end credits have rolled . 
<s>  _beloved_ takes place in the second half of the 19th century , during the so-called reconstruction era after the civil war . 
<s>  for newly-freed slaves , it is a time of confusion and turmoil . 
<s>  oprah winfrey is sethe , a slave who escaped a kentucky plantation and took her children to an ohio farmhouse , where she hoped the terror would end . 
<s>  what she did not know was that it would follow her there , and remain with her long after the physical threat had vanished . 
<s>  _beloved_ ultimately tells the story of sethe's search for forgiveness , one long-hampered by an unforgettable sin . 
<s>  the film starts off on a dreary day ten years after sethe's escape , as a violent , unseen energy rocks her dilapidated farmhouse . 
<s>  invisible hands terrorize her family , flinging objects across rooms , shaking tables , rattling floorboards . 
<s>  sethe's sons run away , perhaps for good , leaving sethe and her daughter denver to fend for themselves . 
<s>  demme's matter-of-fact handling of this supernatural element is just one of _beloved_'s intriguing aspects . 
<s>  all of the characters take for granted that ghosts are real . 
<s>  when paul d ( danny glover ) -- a former slave who escaped kentucky along with sethe -- arrives at the house eight years later and is confronted with the ghost's hellish visions , he doesn't run in terror . 
<s>  instead , he asks who the ghost is . 
<s>  as in morrison's novel , demme quickly establishes that the horror of the story will not come from the fact of the ghost itself , but from the terrifying past in which the ghost was created . 
<s>  sethe is the one being haunted , but the ghost in the house is the least of her fears . 
<s>  in fact , the ghost is one of the reasons she chooses to stay . 
<s>  the story takes an bizarre turn with the appearance of beloved ( thandie newton ) , a young black-clad woman who appears on sethe's front lawn , leaned christ-like against a tree stump . 
<s>  sethe and denver immediately take to the rasping woman and try to nurse her to health . 
<s>  they know not who she is , but that doesn't matter . 
<s>  only paul d is suspicious of the stranger . 
<s>  little does the family know that beloved will bring about many changes , and force sethe to release a guilt she has held onto so urgently for eighteen years . 
<s>  winfrey is arguably beloved's greatest asset . 
<s>  she inhabits the role of sethe so convincingly it is hard to believe this is the same woman who shines brightly on a tv talk show . 
<s>  lisa gay hamilton does an impressive job in the emotionally demanding role as the younger sethe , whose appalling actions make her the disturbed woman we see eighteen years later . 
<s>  danny glover is affable as the sympathetic paul d , as is kimberly elise as denver , sethe's wanderlusting daughter . 
<s>  as sethe's sage-like mother-in-law old baby suggs , beah richards authoritatively commands every scene in which she appears . 
<s>  the film's least palatable choice of casting is unfortunately that of the role of beloved herself . 
<s>  thandie newton plays the glassy-eyed girl with a demented fervor which is endearing at first , but which becomes off-putting and unintentionally laughable by the end . 
<s>  departing from the honed aesthetic he used in such films as _the silence of the lambs_ and _melvin & howard_ , director demme has used a bit of dramatic overstatement to get across the vivid descriptions in morrison's novel . 
<s>  totemic camera shots and color-saturated scenery are decidedly uncommon in demme's films , but the few he uses here work to the film's benefit . 
<s>  _beloved_'s most memorable scenes are those of baby suggs' gatherings in a forest clearing , where the bright yellow-greens of nature entrance the viewer as much as suggs' words do . 
<s>  for the most part , though , demme maintains his trademark directorial neutrality . 
<s>  this , combined with morrison's equally frugal method of storytelling , may make _beloved_ somewhat of a challenge to watch , even to those familiar with the book . 
<s>  though the film compliments the book extraordinarily well , it falls short in allowing the sort of accessibility one usually expects from a film . 
<s>  nothing is spoon-fed to the viewer . 
<s>  morrison's novel is just as enigmatic , but unlike a movie , a book can be put down to allow the various undercurrents and themes to churn and absorb . 
<s>  the movie begins like _poltergeist_ , and ends like _the color purple_ , with shades of _the scarlet letter_ and _little women_ somewhere in the middle . 
<s>  taken as a whole , beloved is a disquieting , one-of-a-kind experience , one to be viewed with guards down and spirits in abeyance . 
<s>  scream 2 isn't quite as clever as its predecessor , but it fills the gap with a cutting wit . 
<s>  death -- even gruesome , bloody death -- can be funny if handled the right way ( some will be offended by this statement , but you need look no further than pulp fiction for an example ) . 
<s>  and , while there's plenty of horror to go around in scream 2 , the latest '90s slasher flick incarnation , there are also a few laughs to be had . 
<s>  scream 2 is a slice-and-dice movie for those who don't take their horror too seriously . 
<s>  the success of the original scream took everyone in the industry by surprise . 
<s>  the unexpected blockbuster , whose gross soared over the $100 million mark during its six month release window , opened just about a year ago and turned into one of the most profitable horror films of all time . 
<s>  a sequel was inevitable ; fortunately , nearly the entire creative team has returned for scream 2 , including director wes craven , screenwriter kevin williamson , and actors neve campbell , courtney cox , david arquette , jamie kennedy , and liev schreiber . 
<s>  as stipulated by one of the " rules of sequels " uttered by a movie- obsessed character in the film , the body count in scream 2 is higher than that in the original . 
<s>  paradoxically , there's a lot less gore . 
<s>  there is blood , of course , but nothing excessive by slasher-movie standards , and there are no depictions of spilled entrails . 
<s>  craven has remembered that scares are more important that graphic displays of human insides and bodily fluids . 
<s>  a second strength of scream 2 is that it features a gallery of legitimate characters rather than a group of cardboard cut-out stereotypes lined up for slaughter . 
<s>  after all , we've known some of these people for two movies -- it's almost impossible not to care about them at least a little . 
<s>  scream 2 opens approximately two years after the original . 
<s>  as in the first picture , there's a slick , self-mocking prologue . 
<s>  this time , the victims are jada pinkett and omar epps , whose characters are visiting a local theater for a preview screening of the movie stab ( which is based on the " true life " events of scream ) . 
<s>  some of the smartest dialogue comes during this sequence as pinkett bemoans the lack of african american participation in horror films ( it's surely no coincidence that , in addition to pinkett and epps , scream 2 features two black characters ) . 
<s>  shortly thereafter , she and her boyfriend have been gutted , signaling the beginning of a series of copycat murders . 
<s>  craven lets loose a burst of tongue-in-cheek creativity for the " movie within a movie " sequences . 
<s>  they give him an opportunity to openly parody scream -- an act that he accomplishes with great panache . 
<s>  stab features heather graham in the " casey becker " role ( played in the original by drew barrymore ) and tori spelling as " sidney prescott " ( neve campbell ) . 
<s>  sadly , we only see a couple of scenes from stab . 
<s>  it would have been a little more fun , i think , had craven used joe dante's approach from matinee and shown lengthy excerpts from his satirical production . 
<s>  following the prologue , we are re-introduced to sidney prescott , who has left her sleepy hometown to go to windsor college . 
<s>  her friend randy ( jamie kennedy ) is a student there as well , and he's just as knowledgeable about horror films as ever . 
<s>  once the double murder at stab becomes big news , the media converges on windsor , looking to interview the original victim . 
<s>  at the head of the flock of vultures is gale weathers ( courtney cox ) , who has a little surprise for sidney . 
<s>  she has brought cotton weary ( liev schreiber ) , the man sidney falsely accused of murder , with her . 
<s>  also arriving at the college is deputy dewey ( david arquette ) , who is there to act as a big brother to sidney during this latest round of tribulations . 
<s>  in addition to the survivors from the original scream , the field of potential victims is well-populated . 
<s>  there's a blond co-ed named cece ( sarah michelle gellar , who has now appeared in two of williamson's movies -- this one and i know what you did last summer ) ; sidney's requisite boyfriend , derek ( jerry o'connell ) ; a local newswoman ( laurie metcalf ) ; gale's new cameraman ( duane martin ) ; a british drama teacher ( david warner ) ; and several sorority sisters and would-be sorority sisters ( portia de rossi , rebecca gayheart , elise neal , marisol nichols ) . 
<s>  ultimately , there are lots of attractive corpses . 
<s>  from the stab scenes to lines like " brothers don't last long in situations like this , " craven and williamson are clearly having a lot of fun with scream 2 , and the movie is enjoyable , if a little overlong ( the livelier first hour is better than the second ) . 
<s>  their resolution to the obligatory " whodunit ? " 
<s>  is less of a letdown than it could be , and knowingly offers a wink and nod at past unmasking scenes . 
<s>   ( " nice twist , " quips the killer . 
<s>   " didn't see it coming , didya ? " ) 
<s>  one senses , however , that , by the end of this picture , the overall concept of a hip , self-referential slasher film has been played out . 
<s>  supposedly , there's going to be a scream 3 , but , if the film makers don't come up with something radical , we could end up with a classic case of sequel overkill . 
<s>  when 17 year old beau hall ( jonathan tucker , " the virgin suicides " ) gets in a car accident after drinking with his 30 year old companion , club owner darby reese ( josh lucas , " session 9 " ) , his mom , margaret ( tilda swinton , " the war zone " ) pays reese a visit to convince him to leave her son alone . 
<s>  instead , reese travels out to their lake tahoe home and lures beau out to the boat house where beau learns that his mother was right about reese . 
<s>  the next morning margaret discovers darby's dead body on their beach and , suspecting the worst , weights it down in a distant part of the lake . 
<s>  but her troubles are just beginning , as she soon learns with the arrival of blackmailer alek spera ( goran visnjic , " practical magic " ) in " the deep end . " 
<s>  the incredibly pale , red-headed scottish actress swinton immerses herself into the role of the reserved american super-mom whose life revolves around serving the needs of her three children and live-in father-in-law jack ( peter donat , " the game " ) . 
<s>  she shows great strength while allowing other emotions to glimmer through - discomfort at challenging reese in his gay disco ( named the deep end ) , near panic at having to dive down to his body to retrieve car keys , or even wry humor when an attempt to get help from jack becomes hopelessly miscommunicated . 
<s>  gradually her loneliness becomes apparent ( her husband's a naval officer , usually away at sea ) when her attempts to email him her concerns about beau are deleted and later , when a most unusual , yet chaste , romance turns tragic . 
<s>  it's a terrific performance . 
<s>  the stendahl syndrome-like script , adapted from elisabeth sanxay holding's 40's noir novel 'the blank wall' by directors scott mcgehee and david siegel , would be unbelievable if not for swinton and her costar visnjic . 
<s>  alek spera is a wrong side of the tracks loser who arrives after reese's body has been discovered . 
<s>  he shows margaret a videotape of beau having sex with reese and demands $50 , 000 or he'll turn the tape over to the reno police . 
<s>  subsequent visits will turn his mind set upside down and backwards , though , as he comes to admire and even love the woman he set out to blackmail . 
<s>  there's yet another problem , though - his partner nagle ( raymond barry , " dead man walking " ) is a harder cored criminal who won't let up until his share of the money is delivered . 
<s>  visnjic's dark , brooding turn has an interior shading to it that makes us believe he's a victim of circumstance and environment . 
<s>  his turnaround is palpable as he witnesses margaret's inherent decency and her workaday surroundings . 
<s>  also outstanding is tucker as beau , who has a terrific character arc and pas de deux with his mother . 
<s>  initially beau's the typical sullen teen . 
<s>  'you're blowing this out of proportion , ' he says of her concerns about reese , not comprehending that his mom has enough insight to have divined the true nature of the relationship . 
<s>  as his mom gets in deeper and deeper trying to cover up a crime he didn't commit , beau becomes suspicious of her actions and apparent new companion , turning tables . 
<s>  his early black eye becomes her later split lip . 
<s>  while the two can never be completely honest with each other , their love for each other comes through strongly . 
<s>  the directors ( " suture " ) have a firm grip on their material and cast . 
<s>  the story builds perfectly with bold strokes amidst a myriad of subtler underpinnings . 
<s>  water imagery is constant ( an early shot of weirdly rushing green is revealed to be a young boy cleaning out an aquarium ) . 
<s>  giles nuttgens ( " fire " ) cinematography , which won the 2001 sundance festival award , is crisp and startlingly clear . 
<s>  the tahoe locations and production design by kelly mcgehee and christopher tandon provide a dual personality for the film , contrasting the calm , well off existence of the lake against the gambling city of reno . 
<s>   " the deep end " is a complex story of domino deeds and shifting relationships . 
<s>  take the plunge . 
<s>  leonardo decaprio ( what's eating gilbert grape ) and claire danes ( tv's my so called life ) star in director baz luhrmann's modernized version of william shakespeare's classic , romeo & juliet . 
<s>  surrounded by a superb supporting cast , in-cluding paul sorvino ( goodfellas ) , brian dennehy ( tommy boy ) , pete poslethwaite ( the usual sus-pects ) and john leguizamo ( executive decision ) , decaprio and danes shine throughout the film . 
<s>  the story starts off at a gas station , where the " montague boys " meet the " capulet boys " and square off with one another . 
<s>  symbolizing the swords of shakespeare's day were their weapons , like the " rapier-9mm " or the " longsword- shotgun . " 
<s>  instead of killing each other right away , they shoot around , just like in sword fights of old . 
<s>  another great thing about the film was the performance of harold perrineau as romeo's best friend . 
<s>  mercutio , who in shakespeare's novel was quite a stud , was portrayed as an afri-can-american cross-dresser whose violent na-ture , was a definite plus . 
<s>  miriam margoyles , a virtually unknown actress was astounding as juliet's nurse , even though she was never given a name . 
<s>  she was the only one who could keep juliet out of her fantasy world . 
<s>  verona was the home of the rival families in shakespeare's version , only slightly changed in luhrmann's . 
<s>  now known as verona beach , the capulet's ( led by sorvino ) and montague's ( led by dennehy ) are now rival corporate dynasties . 
<s>  and their small family skirmishes were now huge gang wars . 
<s>  one slight problem with the film was the difficulty to comprehend the dialogue , since it was spoken in old english . 
<s>  sub-titles could have helped in the beginning of the movie , but toward the end , it became easier to understand . 
<s>  this excellent movie poses another prob-lem : what genre is it ? 
<s>  romeo & juliet contains so much drama , yet enough comedy and action to be placed in either of those categories . 
<s>  with the same award-winning formula that was used by quentin tarantino in reservoir dogs and pulp fiction , romeo & juliet is a sure fire modern masterpiece .

<s>  ---- 29 june 1998 
<s>  more than forty years ago , the " sword and sandals " genre of historical epic ruled the box office . 
<s>  during the 1950's hollywood sought to give audiences a reason to turn off their televisions and go out to the movies by offering the grand spectacle of the roman empire in cinemascope . 
<s>   " ben-hur . " 
<s>   " cleopatra . " 
<s>   " the robe . " 
<s>   " sparticus . " 
<s>   " the fall of the roman empire . " 
<s>   " quo vadis . " 
<s>  sometimes brilliant , sometimes campy , the roman epic was the technicolor funeral pyre of classic hollywood . 
<s>  since then , epics have appeared infrequently ( " the last emperor , " " braveheart " ) and some of the best have been small-screen affairs produced in the 1970's ( " roots , " " shogun " ) . 
<s>  yet , the phrase " we who are about to die salute you " has been absent until now . 
<s>   " gladiator " begins in germania in a . d . 180 . 
<s>  roman general maximus ( russell crowe ) has conquered yet another group of barbarians for his emperor marcus aurelius ( richard harris ) , and he is eager to retire to his plantation in spain where his wife and son are waiting . 
<s>  however , the emperor is worried that his decadent weakling son commodus ( joaquin phoenix ) will prove a poor successor , so he wants to make maximus his heir as a transition toward rome becoming a republic again . 
<s>  when commodus hears the plan , he strangles his father and orders maximus and his family murdered . 
<s>  maximus escapes from the executioners , but he arrives home too late to save his wife and son . 
<s>  a caravan of slavers pick up the wounded hero and carry him off to north africa . 
<s>   ( why the caravan happened to be cruising by maximus' place is never explained . ) 
<s>  an african named juba ( djimon hounsou ) treats maximus' wounds . 
<s>  proximo ( oliver reed ) , a gladiator who won his freedom , purchases maximus and juba as fodder for the arena . 
<s>  of course , maximus proves as able a gladiator as he was a soldier , and his fame spreads . 
<s>  when commodus reopens the coliseum , proximo brings his troupe of warriors to rome to compete . 
<s>  our hero wins the hearts and minds of the cheering crowds and finds that he has an ally in commodus' sister lucilla ( connie nielsen ) . 
<s>  the similarities to " braveheart " are obvious : an evil king , a determined warrior seeking revenge for his murdered family , the aid of a lovestruck princess . 
<s>  also , like mel gibson's epic , " gladiator " has a primarily visceral appeal and is driven forward by the hero's anger . 
<s>  it's a simple tale of good versus evil . 
<s>  maximus has all the manly virtues : nobility of purpose , courage in battle , loyalty to king and country , physical stamina , and devotion to family . 
<s>  commodus is his opposite in every way : a sniveling , selfish coward who is intended to disgust the audience . 
<s>  the opening night crowd in my theater was about 70% male , and that seems appropriate . 
<s>   " gladiator " is a guy movie ( would the opposite of a " chick flick " be a " dick flick " ? ) . 
<s>  there's much pumping of testosterone and chopping off of body parts in gruesome battle sequences . 
<s>   ( those easily offended by gore should stay away . ) 
<s>  lucilla is the only female character , and what sparks there are between her and maximus are dampened by his devotion to his dead wife . 
<s>  joaquin phoenix gives an astounding performance . 
<s>  in the scene where commodus kills his father , phoenix shows the pain of a son who has never had his father's love or pride . 
<s>  throughout the picture , phoenix manages to give depth to a character who's scripted as a caricature of evil . 
<s>  i've been a russell crowe fan since " romper stomper . " 
<s>  this role doesn't offer him the complexities of his parts in " l . 
<s>  a . confidential " and " the insider " -- essentially his job is to grunt heroically -- but his voice , which has a richard burton resonance textured by a clint eastwood rasp , is perfect for the genre . 
<s>  the late oliver reed gave us the best work of his career in his last role . 
<s>  i hope it will be rewarded with an oscar . 
<s>  my only major quibble with " gladiator " is its stylized look . 
<s>  several scenes are tinted . 
<s>  we've seen a lot of the tinted look lately , particularly in " payback " and " the matrix . " 
<s>  i don't get the appeal of the style , which makes feature films look like tv ads . 
<s>  in " payback " it was merely annoying , but in " gladiator " it bleaches the color out of the grand spectacles that are the raison d'etre of the roman epic . 
<s>   ( perhaps it's meant to gloss over the imperfections of the computer-generated shots . ) 
<s>  also , the battle scenes are filmed in a strange herky jerky style that seems to be slo mo and fast forward simultaneously . 
<s>   ( it reminds me of the way the flash runs in the comic books , leaving a half-blurred trail of images of himself behind . ) 
<s>  with a more realistic look , " gladiator " could be even more satisfying than " braveheart " because it has a tighter script and a more fulfilling conclusion .

<s>  the andromeda strain is the greatest science fiction film ever made . 
<s>  i know that is very sweeping statement , so i'll qualify it by adding that the andromeda strain is one of the few films made that genuinely deserve the label of " science fiction , " stories in which speculative science is at the core of the plot . 
<s>  2001 : a space odyssey is probably a better film , but it really only qualifies as science fiction if you consider metaphysics to be a science . 
<s>  most all other films we normally classify as science fiction , or sf , are really just fantasy , action or horror stories set in a futuristic setting . 
<s>  the andromeda strain starts out with two soldiers in a high-tech ( for 1970 ) van looking for a crashed satellite in a tiny new mexico town . 
<s>  something bad happens to them . 
<s>  pictures from a reconnaissance plane show a shocking sight . 
<s>  apparently everyone in the town is dead .

<s>  some went insane before they died and two of them , a baby and an old wino , are miraculously still alive .

<s>  what they find on the satellite when they get back to the lab is andromeda , an organism that defies all the normal rules of earth-like life and mutates as it grows . 
<s>  their only hope to cure it is to find out what a perfectly healthy baby boy has in common with an old derelict . 
<s>  what they find out is that organism feeds directly on energy and that detonating the a-bomb over the town would only spread it across the entire planet . 
<s>  they barely call off the bombing in time . 
<s>  but then the organism mutates into something that threatens to eat through the labs defenses and break out . 
<s>  this triggers the lab's last-ditch defense mechanism , an atomic bomb . 
<s>  to those raised on the brainless action fare that pollutes movie theaters these days , the andromeda strain will probably seem interminably slow . 
<s>  much of the film is a lot of people standing around looking at video screens and computer readouts . 
<s>  but what the characters see on those screens ratchets up the tension with every turn of the screw . 
<s>  the performances are universally fine , with the actors keeping things low-key and restrained , just like scientists . 
<s>  to me , the real appeal of this film is the fact that it shows scientists acting like scientists and makes it seem exciting . 
<s>  we follow the logic of their deduction step by methodical step , puzzling like they do every time andromeda behaves in a way we don't expect . 
<s>  this film is only available on wide screen on dvd and that is the way to see it . 
<s>  it was originally rated g when first released but it now carries the pg rating , mostly for very mild nudity and one scene in which a body's wrist is slashed , spilling its powdered blood .

<s>  alien 3 is the only alien film i have seen in theaters .

<s>  martin scorsese's kundun , which chronicles roughly the first twenty years of the life of the currently exiled dalai lama , has been criticized for its lack of narrative structure . 
<s>  personally , i don't think it needs one : it works perfectly well as a study of tibetan buddhist culture and how communist china . 
<s>  scorsese views the dalai lama the way many tibetans probably do , as a larger-than-life symbol of buddhist spirituality and political leadership : the only glimpses into his head come from several interesting yet oblique dream sequences , but his portrayal is appropriate for a film that concentrates on the political and spiritual rather than the personal .

<s>  everyone else around him has similar symptoms .

<s>  the only person who seems able to appreciate beauty and freedom and life is the person most deprived of it : a dope-dealing teen from across the street who is practically imprisoned by a domineering , bullying father . 
<s>  when lester embarks on a mad scramble to feel the edge again , the fact that he has quit his job to feel what it's like - - and his newfound interest in exercise to impress a teenage girl - - ruffle a lot of feathers in the family .

<s>  opinion : people say it all the time : you never appreciate good health until it's gone . 
<s>  likewise , people raised in fabulously pampered prosperity can become unhappy and spiteful over the dumbest , most inconsequential problems , simply because they have no clue how good they have it .

<s>  the deprivation/appreciation cycle is a major theme of american beauty .

<s>  and though elizabeth works well on many levels , it falls short of excellence because of that very reason . 
<s>  elizabeth takes place in england in 1554 , as queen mary , half sister of elizabeth and a monarch on the side of catholicism is dying . 
<s>  before she dies , though , she cannot bear to sign a document which would condemn her half sister to death because of her heretical protestant beliefs . 
<s>  as a result , amidst much anger within the council , elizabeth becomes the queen of england . 
<s>  the film chronicles her rise to power as she fights for a unified church of england and tries to bring order to her personal and political life . 
<s>  much of the film deals with elizabeth's love for lord robert , a mysterious man who thrusts his lordship onto many a woman as he continues to proclaim his love for the queen .

<s>  each frame is rich with color contrasted with blackness or blown-out white light from windows . 
<s>  the costumes by alexandra byrne deserve a mention as they are such an inportant aspect of each shot .

<s>  like emmerich's id4 , this is obvious propaganda where the americans are the hapless underdogs motivated by freedom for all . 
<s>  sure it's predictable and melodramatic , but for a moment after leaving the theater , i was dumbfounded with patriotism . 
<s>  and isn't that the point of the patriot ? 
<s>  gibson plays benjamin martin , the lionized french and indian war veteran , who , at the beginning of the film , is emotionally suffering after his loving wife passed away . 
<s>  he is left to father seven children at his south carolina estate along with black servants ( not slaves ! ) . 
<s>  as the revolutionary war rumbles miles away , martin swears to keep his family close and away from the battlefields . 
<s>  but when the oldest son enlists anyway and another is murdered by a wicked redcoat colonel ( jason isaacs ) , martin quickly decides to save the day ( or save the fate of america as presented by emmerich ) . 
<s>  forming a band of aggressive farmers and using guerilla tactics considered unfair in the art of war , martin becomes the number one target of the british army . 
<s>  the best parts of the patriot are the scenes in which martin and his rugged militia men outsmart the british armies left and right .

<s>  everything is performed in an orderly ( but still quite gory ) fashion - one side shoots , then the other side , then the remaining soldiers charge . 
<s>  it's organized , strategic and , according to martin , ineffective .

<s>   " if there's a beast in men , it meets its match in women , too . " 
<s>  starring sarah patterson , angela lansbury , tusse silberg , david warner directed by neil jordan written by jordan and angela carter , from a story by carter cinematography by bryan loftus 
<s>  in recent years , there has been a trend in the field of fantasy : writers have been revisiting the fertile world of myth and fairy tale and reclaiming that world , investing it with new life and energy . 
<s>  in modern times , fairy tales have become disneyfied and debased ; they have become trite adventures involving leering witches , friendly dwarves , and cuddly talking animals . 
<s>  but in their original forms , fairy tales have a dark , wicked edge . 
<s>  crows tear out the eyes of cinderella's sisters , a gorier fate then they receive in the animated version . 
<s>  hansel and gretel relish cooking the witch in her own oven . 
<s>  writers have become fascinated by the bloodier , morally ambivalent aspects of fairy tales , and are now modernizing the old stories while simultaneously going back to their roots . 
<s>  before this trend was in vogue , angela carter--whose stories always have a dark , wicked , subversive edge--had been reinventing fairy tales for years . 
<s>  in the company of wolves , she and neil jordan retell the story of red riding hood , enlivening it with werewolves , rolls royces , and a visit from satan . 
<s>  the story is structured as a dream , occurring in the mind of rosaleen ( sarah patterson ) , an adolescent girl about whose 'real' life we learn very little . 
<s>  within the dream , there are a number of inset stories , most told by dream-rosaleen's grandmother ( angela lansbury ) , and these tales gloss the central story in intriguing , suggestive ways . 
<s>  the result is a surprisingly successful example of a sinister , contemporary fairy tale . 
<s>  i say " surprisingly " because there are so many ways this film could have gone wrong . 
<s>  and there are ways in which it does . 
<s>  the performances are mediocre , except for lansbury's--she finds the right note for the prim , apple-cheeked granny , the wise and stern teller of cautionary tales . 
<s>  the soundtrack , synth-heavy , reminded me of bad 80s horror movies , as did the special effects in the shapechanging scenes . 
<s>  probably state-of-the-art at the time , they are now laughable . 
<s>  but jordan succeeds at what i consider the trickiest aspect of the film : he transcends the poor acting/music/effects and conveys a sense of the fantastic , of otherness . 
<s>  one of the problems in adapting full-blown fantasies is that fantasy is often best left to the imagination of the reader , rather than being subjected to the 'realism' of the screen . 
<s>  part of me would love to see an adaptation of 'the lord of the rings , ' but , on the other hand , i know that any filmmaker's recreation of ents , hobbits , and balrogs is inevitably going to be really lame compared to what i picture in my mind . 
<s>  this makes jordan's accomplishment here seem mighty impressive to me : he imbues the company of wolves with a genuine sense of magic and mystery . 
<s>  the somewhat ruritanian dreamworld becomes a kind of ur-reality . 
<s>  the sunshine is exceptionally warm and abundant . 
<s>  the nights are quiet and misty and eerie and ghostly . 
<s>  the peasant village is rustic and cozy , the woods old and hoary . 
<s>  this archetypal realm is the setting for a smart , subtle , literate script , a script which is as good as you'd expect from jordan ( himself an accomplished fiction writer ) and carter . 
<s>  for carter , the cauldron of story is a witches' brew , bubbling over with primal ingredients : mist-shrouded forests , ancient graveyards , virginal girls and wise women , wolves with glowing eyes . 
<s>  she adeptly blends them all together . 
<s>  there is a symbolic richness to the film ; everything is permeated with a sense of significance . 
<s>  the point of it all , i think , is to represent a girl's rites-of-passage on an unconscious , primordial level . 
<s>  a night-journey through the forest , from the village to the grandmother's home , is the crux of the company of wolves . 
<s>   " don't stray from the path , " rosaleen is told , again and again , and the path is both literal and figurative : the path through the forest and the path of life . 
<s>  staying on the path is the conventional approach suggested by rosaleen's elders . 
<s>  carter and jordan , never conventional , explore what goes on when you leave the path . 
<s>  those who stray will supposedly meet with a dark fate . 
<s>  this fate is literalized in the dream as werewolves , but the werewolves connote many things : death , sex , knowledge . 
<s>  if straying from the path leads to death , then it's not a good idea--but if that's what you have to risk to get sex and knowledge ( and therefore power ) , then maybe it's worth the risk . 
<s>  when you leave the path , the world becomes a dangerous , ambiguous place , but it's full of potential . 
<s>  and it's certainly more interesting than the disney version . 
<s>  contrary to the title , " the boxer " is not another rocky story only this time spliced with some cold hard politics . 
<s>  it's actually three movies in one : a political film , a boxing film , and a love story . 
<s>  all of these work in their own respects and have some pretty decent balancing betwixt the three elements of the story , but somehow it seems kind of cliched and unoriginal . 
<s>  we've seen it all before , and we're just not blown away with it like we should be . 
<s>  oh well . 
<s>  it's still an excellent irish story . 
<s>   " the boxer " of the title is danny flynn ( jim sheridan staple daniel day-lewis ) , an ex-ira member who gets out of a belfast prison after 14 years , and finds out that his troubles are far from over . 
<s>  first off , the ira is having a small civil war between its leader joe hamill ( brian cox ) , and one of its sub-leaders , harry ( gerard mcsorley ) , both having opposing views on getting many of their members out of jail . 
<s>  while this is going on , danny and his old drunkard buddie , ike ( ken stott , who played the chief inspector in danny boyle's " shallow grave " ) , re-open an old gym which allows the two opposing religios sects , protestant and catholics , to work together . 
<s>  danny not only begins teaching kids how to box , but has stayed in great shape whilst in prison , and is ready to start boxing real people again .
