<s>  but the two are slowly re-drawn to eachother again , and this begins to complicate things . 
<s>  the political story is nothing really special but works in itself . 
<s>  we've seen it many a time before , but it's at least interesting , sometimes emotional , and even riveting at times . 
<s>  there's a big riot towards the middle of the film which is frightening in its brutality and honesty . 
<s>  the boxing story is very minor to the story , but does represent people coming together to fight eachother fairly , and even with good sportsmanship .

<s>  as the film goes on , and circumstances get worse and worse , the characters have to make real human decisions , and we can sympathize with them as humans not characters . 
<s>  this is how you write a love story - take note , hollywood . 
<s>  these elements are pretty much equally balanced , with each of the parts of the stories working hand-in-hand with eachother . 
<s>  i loved how each of the different parts of the plot mattered , and sometimes spilled over into the next . 
<s>  it made sure that we didn't just care for one of them . 
<s>  i'm not saying they're all equally great , because the love story really carries the film , but at least they all work out respectively . 
<s>  the acting is amazing , with day-lewis and watson giving excellent performances and showing great chemistry . 
<s>  i'm not sure if they're oscar-nominee bound , but they're very good . 
<s>  in the supporting roles , billy cox is greatly sympathetic as the ira leader losing control of his daughter and his workers . 
<s>  but the film is stolen acting wise by ken stott as ike , who is just a great scene stealer . 
<s>  the direction and co-writing by jim sheridan ( with the other co-writing credit going to terry george ) is excellent , rounding out the characters well , but not pacing everything greatly . 
<s>  i noticed that the first half was very leisurely ( yet fascinating ) , but the second half whirls by at a quick pace , and ends much too quickly . 
<s>  more time could have been spent thinking up the ending , since it does seem quite sloppy . 
<s>  though " the boxer " is a good film , it never achieves the greatness that it should . 
<s>  sure , it's a masterpiece compared to most of the hollywood drivel we usually get , but on it's own , it just could have been better . 
<s>  but it still works out , gives us a great love story combined with a political and boxing drama , and features great acting . 
<s>  even if it could have been better , this'll do .

<s>  susan granger's review of " songcatcher " in the midst of this summer's fare of dinos revisited and romantic fiascoes , there are a few thoughtful movies - and this appalachian period drama is one . 
<s>  oscar nominee janet mcteer ( " tumbleweeds " ) stars as dr . lily penleric , an accomplished musicologist who , back in that pre-feminist era , was refused a full professorship at her university . 
<s>  determined to prove her worth , she ventures deep into the rugged mountains of north carolina , where her younger sister elna ( jane adams ) runs a school .

<s>  their music , as she puts it , is " as much a part of life here as the air you breathe . "

<s>  katherine kerr ) .

<s>  rated pg-13 , there's an intense scene of primitive childbirth . 
<s>  on the granger movie gauge of 1 to 10 , " songcatcher " is an intelligent , extraordinary 8 , transported by the transcendent power of song . 
<s>  elizabeth is a potent historical drama set in england in the mid-1500s . 
<s>  it is a time when stately royal ceremonies are as commonplace as public burnings . 
<s>  internally , the catholics wage war against the protestants . 
<s>  meanwhile , spain , scotland and france strategize their next moves in the struggle for power . 
<s>  little does england know that a young woman named elizabeth ( cate blanchett ) will be their greatest hope for survival . 
<s>  the film charts elizabeth's tumultuous struggle to gain true power over her kingdom . 
<s>  as a protestant , she is the last person any of the catholic royalty would want to be queen . 
<s>  but her half-sister queen mary ( kathy burke ) , deathly ill and unable to conceive a child , pleas with elizabeth to take over the throne . 
<s>  mary gives her her blessing on only one condition : that elizabeth renounce her faith and uphold the teachings of catholicism across the land . 
<s>  once declared queen , elizabeth immediately finds herself under assault , both by her own subjects ( including the duke of norfolk , played with steely-eyed grace by christopher eccleston ) and by forces abroad . 
<s>  slowly but surely , the neophyte ruler takes england by its reigns and forges a new path for her kingdom . 
<s>  elizabeth is surrounded by a keenly drawn cadre of subjects and advisers . 
<s>  her closest ally is the mysterious sir francis walsingham ( geoffrey rush , in a perfectly subtle performance ) . 
<s>  also on her side is sir william cecil ( sir richard attenborough ) , her well-meaning but misguided chief adviser . 
<s>  with few people she can trust , elizabeth must prove her self-worth any way she can , even if it means being the iron-fisted ruler she secretly despises . 
<s>  blanchett deserves an oscar for her performance as elizabeth . 
<s>  she portrays the young queen with just the right balance of gawky self-consciousness and shrewd charisma . 
<s>  though not a classical beauty , blanchett is able to entrance the viewer with just a coy smile or an impish smirk . 
<s>  she is at home with her character's playful tendencies , particularly in one scene where elizabeth dances unabashedly with childhood friend and lover lord robert dudley ( joseph fiennes ) . 
<s>  whether fending off unctuous suitors or " playing " the houses in court , blanchett's elizabeth radiates a confidence which impossible to dislike . 
<s>  almost as interesting as the character of elizabeth are shekhar kapur's visual delights . 
<s>  he and cinematographer remi adefarasin have crafted a film with a rich color palette that is a feast for the eyes . 
<s>  rolling green hills , extravagant ceremonial galas , dark and foreboding corridors -- all are depicted with a real sense of artistic appreciation . 
<s>  the castles and cathedrals of europe have rarely been doted on so lovingly as they are here . 
<s>  though writer michael hirst's script gets a little murky at times , and his injections of humor get a little overplayed , elizabeth pulses with the right amount of dramatic and cinematic verve to make it just deserving of a theatrical viewing . 
<s>  as a whole , the story survives because elizabeth's struggle is one which deserves attention . 
<s>  by the time she makes her shocking ( but very sensible ) final declaration , we're ready to bow to elizabeth as our own queen .

<s>  rose's narration shows us how she was an unhappy young girl , engaged to a rich man named cal hockley ( billy zane ) that she didn't want to marry . 
<s>  her mother is pushy and obnoxious , and cal hockley is arrogant . 
<s>  they are boarding the titanic , which is sailing to america , and this is where she is to marry cal . 
<s>  meanwhile , a young man named jack dawson ( leonardo dicaprio ) and his italian friend ( danny nucci ) win two 3rd class tickets aboard the titanic in a poker game . 
<s>  they are overjoyed , and rush aboard just as the boat is leaving . 
<s>  for them , this is their ticket to america , to a better life . 
<s>  for rose , she is sailing to her doom . 
<s>  the first hour and a half or so of titanic tells the story of how rose dewitt ( kate winslet ) and jack dawson fall in love . 
<s>  it's the classic wrong-side-of-the-tracks story , and does sometimes resort to a few cliches . 
<s>  but as i said above , the love portion isn't sappy and doesn't " weigh the film down " , as some critics have said . 
<s>  it's sweet , and it didn't make me restless at all , despite the fact that i usually hate love stories . 
<s>  of course , it might help that cameron introduces some pretty interesting characters to help keep our eyes glued to the screen . 
<s>  most of these people actually were passengers on the titanic back in 1912 , including the enigmatic molly brown ( played by the talented kathy bates ) , the captain of titanic ( bernard hill ) , and so on . 
<s>  all of these characters add an extra depth to the film , and make it that easier to watch . 
<s>  of course , things really start to get going after the hour and a half mark , where the titanic strikes the iceberg and begins a slow sink to the bottom . 
<s>  the sinking is depicted realisticly , and the effects are truly amazing . 
<s>  it is not told in a heroic fashion sense either , as people are portrayed as panicking , pushing others aside to get on the limited lifeboats , and drowning and dying horrible deaths . 
<s>  the best part of the movie , in my opinion , comes at the very end , when we flash back to the future . 
<s>  the crew , who at first had been skeptical of rose's story , now are totally aborbed by her . 
<s>  rose goes out onto the ship's ledge , and we then learn a secret about her that catches us off guard . 
<s>  we then see a dream of rose's , in which she returns to the titanic and is dancing with jack dawson . 
<s>  most people i talked with after the movie saw this as only a dream . 
<s>  however , i think it symbolized more ; i think it meant that rose had died , and is going to a sort of heaven , which would be the happiest part of her life : her and her one true love , jack .

<s>  sometimes you just have to tip your hat to a film . 
<s>  sometimes you just have to jump on the bandwagon and enjoy the ride . 
<s>  i saw the truman show with an audience full of teenagers , most of whom were no doubt drawn by ace ventura himself and hoping to see his latest take on fart jokes . 
<s>  surprised , they may have been , when they realized that this picture actually had something to say . 
<s>  but by the attentiveness of the crowd i'd say they were won over - as was i . i can't tell yet if truman really is that good , or if it only seems that good in comparison to the awful mountain of crap spewed forth from the bowls of hollywood so far this year . 
<s>  time alone will make that call . 
<s>  but by the end of the film we were all on truman burbank's side . 
<s>  we were concerned for his well-being , and wanted him to win . 
<s>  that we felt as we did is a tribute both to the film and to jim carrey , who has achieved legitimacy at last . 
<s>  the truman show is a film best viewed cold , with as little foreknowledge as possible about the plot . 
<s>  unless you're under a media blackout , however , you probably know the basics . 
<s>  carrey stars as truman burbank , a capra-esque everyman insurance agent living with his beautiful wife meryl ( laura linney ) in the south florida island town of seahaven , which looks like michael eisner's idea of the perfect american small town . 
<s>  truman would seem to live the perfect middle class lifestyle , complete with a working wife , a best bud , friendly neighbors and interesting co-workers . 
<s>  there is tragedy in his past - his father drowned in a horrible boating accident , leaving truman with a dreadful fear of water , and of travel in general - but overall , life is good . 
<s>  but then one day as truman leaves his house for work , a klieg light falls magically from the sky . 
<s>  this curious event may lead truman to discover what the rest of the world already knows : that he is a prisoner on the world's biggest soundstage , that his wife , friends and relatives are all actors paid to interact with him , and that his life has , for over 10 , 000 days , been broadcast as the world's most popular television program . 
<s>  what makes the first hour of truman so enjoyable to watch is the magical verisimilitude painstakingly constructed by niccol and weir . 
<s>  the soundstage , we're told , is " only the second man-made structure visible from space . " 
<s>  truman's movements are tracked ceaselessly by 5 , 000 cameras scattered throughout the town : button cams , dashboard cams , mirror cams , wife cams , big cams and small cams . 
<s>  weir cuts the film so we're never quite sure if we're watching truman through the camera of director weir or through the camera of the show's omnipotent creator christof ( ed harris ) who oversees the show from a control room built into the man-made moon in seahaven's sky . 
<s>  the second act offers a plethora of clues for truman as to the truth of his existence . 
<s>  his best friend marlon ( noah emmerich ) always has a six pack of beer with him . 
<s>  his wife seems to exist in an eternal commercial in which she is always endorsing the latest hot household product . 
<s>  he sees the same people walking in the same set patterns all over town . 
<s>  one wonders why he didn't pick up on any of this earlier , but christof has an answer for this : " people tend to accept the reality with which they're presented . " 
<s>  nevertheless , truman begins to grow restless , and dreams of escape to fiji , where an old college sweetheart ( natasha mcelhone ) supposedly lives . 
<s>  this convincing reality of television as progenitor of reality is a magical and provocative concept ; the best thing jim carrey does is stay out of its way . 
<s>  by underplaying truman , he allows the subtle manipulations of the film to take over . 
<s>  there is a particularly poignant scene in which truman confides his fears to marlon , and marlon answers with best-friend sincerity , " i'd gladly step in front of a bus for you . " 
<s>  but that line was fed to marlon through an earpiece by christof . 
<s>  the abject cruelty to which truman is subjected to hits home - and from that moment , we're on his side . 
<s>  the truman show derives much of its success from playing to our own secret paranoid fantasies - haven't we all , at least once , doubted our place in the world , doubted the sincerity of those closest to us ? 
<s>  ultimately , however , the picture rises above its own artifice to raise some real questions about the relationship of humankind and our creator . 
<s>  what does god really think of us ? 
<s>  does he resent our abandonment of paradise ? 
<s>  who exactly is watching us , up there in the sky ? 
<s>  if you enjoy the picture as much as i did , credit weir for allowing the magic of the screenplay to work . 
<s>  as for carrey - well , truman burbank is the kind of role that jimmy stewart was born to play . 
<s>  carrey is no jimmy stewart ; to his credit , he doesn't try to be . 
<s>  he just tries to feel the way you or i would , if we suddenly found out that the whole world was watching us . 
<s>  i didn't realize how apt the name of this movie was until i called the mpaa ( the motion picture association of america - the folks who decide what's g , nc 17 , pg , r or x ) to ask why the preview was rated r . so that we can make some sense of their response , let me tell you about the movie itself . 
<s>   " the celluloid closet " is a documentary about how homosexuality has been portrayed in the movies over the past several decades . 
<s>  it's brilliant , funny , naughty and extremely poignant . 
<s>  it tore at my heart to watch a gifted lesbian screenwriter explain that , as a rule , gay audiences hunger for any hint of homosexuality on screen . 
<s>  regardless of how veiled - or how sordid - the presence of a gay or lesbian person allows others to lessen their sense of isolation and makes them feel as if they're not quite so invisible as america seems to want them to be . 
<s>  the movie itself is rated r - and for good reason . 
<s>  it contains scenes of bloody , violent gay bashing and graphic , uninhibited , sex . 
<s>  as with any movie , i appreciate knowing about these things ahead of time , so i can decide for myself whether to see the movie with a friend , a date , my 11 year old niece , alone or not at all .

<s>  i would , however , like to suggest that it's they who are in the closet on this one . 
<s>  and the light ain't good in there . 
<s>  but , having seen " the celluloid closet , " and being one of a handful of straight people involved in a primarily gay and lesbian weekly bible study ( email me and i'll give you the details ) , none of this was any big surprise . 
<s>  the point of the movie was that homosexuality , even in the politically correct 90s , is ridiculously perceived as a threat to a mostly heterosexual society . 
<s>  a point well made in this candid and honest film .

<s>  i just don't feel the need to go there , because it seems so obvious . 
<s>  i'll instead suggest that the mpaa re-evaluated their evaluation criteria . 
<s>  let the ratings reflect not subject content , like " sex " and " violence " . 
<s>  let them reflect attitude content . 
<s>  in the future , i'd be interested in knowing whether the movie is rated d for disrespectful or s for stereotyped . 
<s>  then i'd truly be able to make an informed decision about how i spent my time .

<s>  mamoru oshii is a name that probably isn't very well-known to most american audiences , but perhaps it should be . 
<s>  oshii was the director of last year's best-known japanese animated film import , _ghost in the shell_ , and is known among fans of japanese animation , or anime , for making films with a deep philosophical bent . 
<s>  one of these films was the first theatrical venture for the patlabor animated series . 
<s>  in its many incarnations--graphic novels ( " manga " ) , two different runs of made-for-video episodes ( original animation videos , or oavs for short ) , and a television series running to nearly fifty episodes--patlabor has proven to be one of the most popular series ever in japan . 
<s>  set in the very near future ( though it was a somewhat farther away near future when the series was first conceived ) , this atypical giant robot anime features the characters , rather than the machinery , as the primary focus . 
<s>  as a whole , patlabor is the story of an exciting time for japan . 
<s>  as the prologue to each episode of the television series explains , giant industrial robots , known as " labors " ( an interesting play on words , considering that " robot " is derived from the czech word for labor ) , have come into widespread use in japan toward the close of the twentieth century . 
<s>  with the rise of labors , however , has come a new menace--labor crime . 
<s>  this led to the creation of the two special vehicle divisions , using patrol labors to fight labor crime . 
<s>  the patlabor story centers around the second special vehicle division , sv2 , who , through no fault of their own , have acquired a bad reputation for destructiveness . 
<s>  sometimes utterly hilarious , sometimes almost deadly serious , the patlabor series explores the interpersonal relationships of the special vehicle crewmembers , and also looks at the effects of technology on modern life . 
<s>  those who are unfamiliar with the patlabor story and characters may find themselves slightly confused coming into the movie , although there is ample background exposition provided for new viewers . 
<s>  the story , as has much of patlabor before , centers around the controversial babylon project , a gigantic seawall that will , on its completion , allow the reclamation of thousands of square miles of land from tokyo bay . 
<s>  this project has been an almost constant target of environmentalist terrorists , most notably the house of sea organization . 
<s>  however , the threat in this case comes not from any terrorist , but from someone who is already dead . . . 
<s>  shinohara heavy industries , the premier labor manufacturer in japan ( if not the whole world ) , has just come out with a new operating system that increases labors' movement speed and efficiency by 30% . 
<s>  this hyper operating system , hos for short , has very quickly been installed into well over 90% of the nation's labors . . . including the patrol labors of sv2 . 
<s>  since that installation , dozens of labors , including a heavily-armed military model , have begun to go on berzerk rampages for no apparent reason . . . and the only factor they all had in common was that they were all running under the new hos . 
<s>   ( some wags have compared this to windows 95 . ) 
<s>  it's up to asuma shinohara , labor command officer with sv2 and the son of the president of shinohara heavy industries , to find the source of these problems before more labors--including sv2's own--fall victim to them , and before hos drags his father's company down with it . 
<s>  as was the case with _ghost in the shell_ , if you just want a no-brainer actionfest , this might not be the movie for you . 
<s>  _patlabor : the movie_ is more of a psychological thriller , a technological suspense drama . 
<s>  it is closer , perhaps , to a chrichton novel than to an action movie ( crichton novels that have been made _into_ action movies notwithstanding ) . 
<s>  there are long , thoughtful montages of dialogueless footage as two investigators make their way through slums and derelict housing in old quarters of tokyo , similar to sequences from _ghost in the shell_ . 
<s>  this movie is fraught with symbolism--in fact a large part of it is based on christian symbolism . 
<s>  patlabor's near-future setting is , aside from the giant robots tromping around , very similar to our own present day . 
<s>  the film uses this setting to make its central point : is progress moving too fast for humans to keep up ? 
<s>  are history and culture falling by the wayside like the old buildings that are being torn down and replaced with new ? 
<s>  this is a question just as applicable to today as it is to patlabor's alternate-1999 setting . 
<s>  as far as the technical aspects of the film go ( referring to the subtitled version , as that's the only one i've seen ) , the film transfer is clear , almost phenomenally so . 
<s>  the animation quality is incredible , though the character design is different from what most patlabor fans will be used to . 
<s>  the oavs and tv series were more cheerful , better-suited to humor ; the movie , however , makes everyone look a great deal less cute , and emphasizes that this is going to be , for the most part , a deadly serious storyline . 
<s>  as far as cinematography goes , there are many interesting moments in _patlabor : the movie_ . 
<s>  i don't think i can recall ever seeing a fish-eye perspective used in any other animated film ( save for _ghost in the shell_ , another oshii film ) , or indeed , in many other movies at all . 
<s>  the cinematography is well-suited to the storyline , emphasizing what it needs to , though a couple of scenes ( where characters' features are exaggerated in anger ) may seem slightly strange to western audiences . 
<s>  the audio track of _patlabor : the movie_ is in glorious hi-fi stereo , and should be used to demonstrate home theater systems--it _is_ that good . 
<s>  even without headphones , sounds from either side of the screen can be clearly heard to _come_ from that side . 
<s>  giant robot footsteps are deep and booming . 
<s>  the sometimes-understated , sometimes-blaring score is crisp and clear , and always right on the mark , enhancing the moods created by the animated scenery . 
<s>  as far as the subtitles go , i have to say that they're among the most easily-readable subtitles i've ever seen for _anything_ . 
<s>  large enough that they don't strain the eyes , but small enough not to conceal too much of the screen . 
<s>  although it does have several action sequences in it , most notably the climactic conclusion , _patlabor_ is foremost not an action movie . 
<s>  although it is a superbly-realized film , it relies in large part upon prior familiarity with some of the characters to carry the story , and that could detract from some people's enjoyment .

<s>  everything from sex to drugs to violence is covered in a film with a much blacker edge in comedy than swingers .

<s>  there's a moment in schindler's list when a number of jews are trudging through snow , clean and crisp , dark edges and frost on the ground . 
<s>  one girl waltzes through , wearing a red dress that stings the eyes . 
<s>  it is probably the finest moment through out the film . 
<s>  when i first saw it i began to cry , though i could not say why . 
<s>  this landscape is the setting of many small moments that add up to one big whole . 
<s>  when one man is shot in the head we see blood oozing out onto the ground -- so black and murky , its almost pomegranate red . 
<s>  at another time we follow a young boy as he runs , searching for a hiding spot before finally squeezing into a toilet -- which is already occupied . 
<s>  like so ( citizen kane , fargo , the godfather , the godfather part ii , greed , ) many of the greatest american films , schindler's list plays with the concepts of money , power , and soul . 
<s>  but this is a movie about a man who does the right thing . 
<s>  starkly emotional , and brutally powerful , schindler's list strips away everything on the outset and leaves us ony feelings . 
<s>  the following that it has gained is not suprising -- this is probably , thus far , the best film of the decade . 
<s>  steven spielberg has always been a skilfull filmmaker -- his assured hand churned out both jurassic parks , jaws , the indiana jones films , and e . t . 
<s>  -- but it wasn't until 1993 that we saw what a brilliant man he can be . 
<s>  the product of his genuis is really something to see -- it can bring tears to your eyes just as it uplifts you . 
<s>  throughout , we sense the deep control which he so masterfully spreads . 
<s>  we watch oskar schindler ( liam neeson ) grow from an arrogant , self important man who hires jews only to save money into a moving figure , with a deep sense of pride and accomplishment . 
<s>  the film requires much work , and can be a harrowing experience -- go expecting a quick entertainment and you'll be bitterly dissapointed . 
<s>  it does reward the patient viewer .

<s>  it's a three-hour long saga about the life of one of the most hated and misunderstood leaders of the 20th century . 
<s>  stone doesn't hold back anything as he digs deep inside politics and legal maneuvers of the white house . 
<s>  the director holds nixon responsible for everything he has done .

<s>  in tim burton's `sleepy hollow' , there is a mysterious headless horseman who decapitates residents of the small town of the same name . 
<s>  he rides a beautiful black steed and carries an imposing sword that cauterizes the wound of his victims with an immediate swipe . 
<s>  burton's update on washington irving's classic tale of `the legend of sleepy hollow' offers us the mystery of the horseman , when the screenplay should have merely settled on the aspect of the horror . 
<s>  writer andrew kevin walker ( `seven' ) throws in perhaps too healthy a dosage of sherlock holmes , but the visual treatment of the film is absolutely entrancing , as burton offers foggy locales and detailed costumes that are gorgeous and stirring to examine . 
<s>  as `sleepy hollow' opens , we're greeted with a juicy cameo from martin landau , who won an oscar in burton's `ed wood' . 
<s>  landau plays a prominent citizen of sleepy hollow , who , on a fateful carriage ride through the forest , is decapitated by an unseen horseback rider . 
<s>  after two more murders haunt the residents of the quaint little town , constable ichabod crane ( johnny depp ) is sent in to investigate . 
<s>  landlord baltus von tassel ( michael gambon ) explains to crane that the heads have been severed from the carcass and mysteriously taken in each separate case , and that they believe the murderer is a dead hessian trooper ( played briefly by a wonderfully jarring christopher walken ) who has risen from the grave after being decapitated in the western woods . 
<s>  crane is not a man of great superstition , and is determined to root out the human culprit with his assortment of gizmos and gadgets ( things i was not surprised to find in a tim burton movie ) . 
<s>  first and foremost , `sleepy hollow' is a fun horror film . 
<s>  as with virtually all burton movies , we are treated to a wonderful score by composer danny elfman , who has once again poured excitement and imagination into an atmospheric soundtrack that accentuates the gothic mood perfectly . 
<s>  the horseman f/x are stylish and impressive , particularly in perfectly blended battle sequences involving actual actors . 
<s>  but why did i enjoy `sleepy hollow' as much as i did ? 
<s>  although enjoyable , it was not the numerous beheadings and the plentiful gore that spurted left and right . . 
<s>  it was the light comic touch that burton applied . 
<s>  the film has the sweetness of a candy apple , usually channeled through depp's wonderful performance as the lovable geek ichabod crane , who is no longer a mild-mannered school teacher but still attains his cowardly qualities . 
<s>  this is certainly not the only alteration that's been made . 
<s>  as the film progresses , it becomes apparent that walker is more concerned with the mystery of the murders than the murders themselves . 
<s>  the momentum is slowed considerably once crane begins piecing the mystery together , because for the audience , it's not an issue we particularly wish to be solved . 
<s>  it's more effective for the headless horseman to be an elusive demon than an elusive demon with an ulterior motive . 
<s>  still , we are still captivated by the breathtaking technical detail and burton's keen eye to capture our attention . 
<s>  the costuming is exceptional , and the dialogue is crisp and effective throughout ( it's recognizable that the script was refined by award-winning playwright tom stoppard ) . 
<s>  the supporting cast exhibits more color and playfulness than many . 
<s>  a blonde christina ricci is in fine form as von tassel's daughter katrina , and an unlikely romance between she and ichabod is surprisingly consistent . 
<s>  walken , michael gough ( who appeared in burton's `batman' films ) and miranda richardson are all enjoyable in tackling their separate roles . 
<s>  i suppose the strengths behind `sleepy hollow' lie within the central trio : director burton , constable depp and the headless horseman who hunts him down with ruthless accuracy . 
<s>  all of this is not to be taken seriously , of course . 
<s>  `sleepy hollow' is a lavish , frightening and altogether amusing reworking of a classic tale that many people cherished as children . 
<s>  if you've got a decent head on your shoulders , you'll have the good sense to gallop off to the theater and enjoy it one last time .

<s>  bowfinger is a good movie about the making of a very bad one . 
<s>  the screenplay , written by co-star steve martin , skewers everything in hollywood from cheesy science-fiction movies to chop-socky fight sequences , and all in a crafty and accomplished manner . 
<s>  anyone who knows of , or has had any association with movie-making should thoroughly enjoy this clever comedy for it's entire duration . 
<s>  the central premise behind the film is an inspired and promising one . 
<s>  bobby bowfinger ( martin ) , a cheapskate and small-time hollywood producer , has always dreamed of making a successful motion picture but has never attained the proper tools to do so . 
<s>  a new script , an alien invasion story entitled chubby rain , has caught bowfinger's eye . 
<s>  after confronting a big-name producer named jerry renfro ( robert downey jr . ) in a restaurant , an agreement is made to finance the movie . 
<s>  but first , bowfinger must get renowned action star kit ramsey ( eddie murphy ) to sign in on the project . 
<s>  kit turns the offer down immediately , but bowfinger still has the intent to shoot the film . 
<s>  after emptying out his life savings , the hapless producer tells the remaining cast and crew that ramsey is involved , and then prepares to film the movie without the star's knowledge . 
<s>  the actors confront ramsey on the street , saying their lines as hidden cameras peek through bushes to capture the footage . 
<s>  the unknowing star , who is terrified of aliens and being abducted , is brought to believe there is actually pod people after him . 
<s>  when the conditions become even more treacherous , bowfinger is forced to hire a kit ramsey look-alike named jiff ( also murphy ) , a sweet-natured dork who runs for coffee in-between shooting vital scenes . 
<s>  these include attempting a suicide run across an 8-lane freeway , and one of the `hot' scenes involving supporting actress daisy ( heather graham ) removing her blouse . 
<s>  bowfinger takes it's sweet time getting started , but when the plot switches into high gear , great things happen . 
<s>  certain scenes are so precisely executed , perfectly framing moments that are absolutely fall-down funny . 
<s>  no , hilarious . 
<s>  standouts include the chase through a parking garage in which ramsey , who's supposed to be being followed , keeps checking behind him to investigate a strange tapping noise ( it's actually bowfinger's dog in high heels ) . 
<s>  and just try not to laugh in the climactic kung-fu sequence , featuring jiff in an excerpt from another bowfinger classic entitled fake purse ninjas . 
<s>  while the entire 97-minutes of bowfinger isn't always on target , individual scenes may have you rolling in the aisles . 
<s>  masterful comedy director frank oz ( dirty rotten scoundrels , in and out ) , who has never made a bad movie , ensures a quality final product and is aided immensely by martin's sharp-edged script . 
<s>  however , the real on-screen star is eddie murphy . 
<s>  this is the actor's finest work since his breakthrough into the hollywood market in the early 80's . 
<s>  murphy excels at every corner , not only succeeding with presenting believable paranoia in the eyes of kit ramsey , but in creating a likable buffoon in jiff as well . 
<s>  these three talented comic minds have squeezed every morsel of potential out of this premise , and the reward is a virtually guaranteed helping of hearty laughs . 
<s>  steve martin generates the power behind bowfinger , but murphy fuels it . 
<s>  this is a summer-time comedy that , unlike something such as american pie and south park , doesn't break any rules . 
<s>  but it's still just as uproarious , or perhaps even more side-splitting than anything we've seen this season . 
<s>  the supporting cast , including christine baranski as a work-loving actress and jamie kennedy as the cameraman , all perform well within their limits .

<s>  graham , attempting to further her stardom after appearing as the new powers' girl in ap2 , displays a cheerful but naive persona that nicely corresponds with the wackiness of the screenplay . 
<s>  i wouldn't be caught dead buying a ticket for chubby rain , but watching how it all came about is certainly entertaining enough .

<s>   " gattaca " represents a solid breakthrough in the recent onslaught of science-fiction films -- it's a genre picture that doesn't rely on alien creatures or loud explosions to tell its story . 
<s>  the movie takes place in a futuristic world where babies are created through genetic tampering and not sexual reproduction . 
<s>  this allows parents to predetermine what kind of eye color , intelligence and life span they'd like for their child , and also eliminates most pesky chances of health defects . 
<s>  those made the old-fashioned way are labeled as " in-valids " and confined to the lower rung of society . 
<s>  vincent freeman ( ethan hawke ) is one such person , born not too long before the genetic process was perfected and forced to grow up in a home with his petrie dish-molded younger brother anton . 
<s>  fed up with being second-rate and enchanted by dreams of one day traveling through space , vincent leaves home and takes a janitorial position at the gattaca aerospace corporation . 
<s>  everyday , he watches as " superior " folk make his fantasy a reality . 
<s>  determined to do the same , vincent meets a dna broker ( tony shalhoub in a funny cameo ) who sells fake identities to in-valids . 
<s>  his counterpart for this scam is jerome morrow ( jude law ) , an ex-athlete left paralyzed in an accident and confined to a wheelchair for life . 
<s>  for a price and the promise of a caretaker , jerome supplies vincent with his identity , as well as blood , skin and urine samples for all of those pesky on-the-job tests and physical examinations -- this future is one where employees clock in by pricking their fingers instead of punching a time card . 
<s>  because of his drastically improved status , vincent is quickly propelled to a high position in gattaca , and catches the eye of comely co-worker irene ( uma thurman ) on the way -- obsessed with her own minor heart defect , she's enamored by his flawless persona she doesn't know is a lie . 
<s>  but on the figurative eve of his upcoming planetary departure , the mission director is murdered . 
<s>  two ardent detectives ( alan arkin and billy bathgate's loren dean ) determine the killer is on the inside of gattaca , and the sole clue they find at the crime scene -- one of vincent's eyelashes -- threatens to blow vincent's cover and derail his goal . 
<s>  even if " gattaca " were dramatically empty , it would still boast a sublime set of production credentials -- the film's look is dazzling without ever being flashy . 
<s>  first-time director/writer andrew niccol ( he also wrote the screenplay for the upcoming jim carrey drama " the truman show " ) demonstrates a keen eye for the stylish ; his collaboration with cinematographer slawomir idziak , production designer jan roelfs and costume designer colleen atwood result in a sophisticated composition that emanates classy , retro ambiance . 
<s>  an opening credits sequence -- where skin , nail and hair fragments fall in slow-motion through a colored camera lens -- displays these combined talents uncannily . 
<s>  niccol even utilizes voice-over narration ( a device almost always poorly-employed ) in an effective way . 
<s>  when it comes to acting , the movie is also flawless . 
<s>  ethan hawke does magnificent work , proving his ability to carry a film and reaffirming his enormously high charisma level . 
<s>  his chemistry with thurman is a bit on the icy side , but needfully so , adding to the setting's clinical chill . 
<s>  as the bitter jerome , jude law has a star-making presence , and it's his scenes with hawke that give the movie its fine emotional core . 
<s>  in " gattaca " 's series of final shots , the fates of vincent and jerome are superimposed over each other , and the effect is sad , lyrical and beautiful . 
<s>  things get a little strange as the movie nears its climax , when vincent's relationship with his brother comes back into view . 
<s>  the big dramatic culmination is a swim race , which is somewhat silly albeit beautifully photographed . 
<s>  still , the single most surprising aspect of gattaca is its use of backdrop -- it's successful sci-fi without showy special effects , it's a crisp thriller with character-driven thrills , it's a futuristic fable without blood and guts . 
<s>  even its murder mystery is relegated to a secondary subplot , ensuring that a smart story about smart people and smart science takes center stage . 
<s>  although it's portrayal of the upcoming century is grim , " gattaca " serves up one of the most thought-provoking societal forecasts ever depicted on film .

<s>  f . w . murnau's career ended sadly and prematurely . 
<s>  the german director of such classics as " sunrise " and " the last laugh " died in a car accident shortly after signing a deal to make american pictures at paramount . 
<s>  murnau was reportedly a giant man , well over six feet , a towering figure probably incapable of anything but a grand entrance . 
<s>  which brings us to " nosferatu : a symphony of horror " : surely he felt a kinship with his title character , the looming vampire embodied by intimidating max schreck ; in one of the most indelible images in film history , silent or otherwise , schreck rises from his grave , gnarled hands outstretched , and he's so big that part of his head is cropped by the top of the frame . 
<s>  the plot of " nosferatu . . . " 
<s>  is lifted--unauthorized--from bram stoker's " dracula " . 
<s>  the british hutter is an eager real estate man assigned to visit and discuss future living arrangements with count orlock of transylvania . 
<s>  he leaves behind girlfriend emily , only to discover orlock's secret--he's a bloodsucker--and struggle to return to england before the nosferatu reaches his lady love . 
<s>  in addition to schreck's performance , the cinematography and effects are outstanding . 
<s>  arrow video's digitally remastered version of the classic is something of a mixed-coffin . 
<s>  the cover art features a red-tinted , hairy , goateed vampire staring straight at you , his fanged mouth agape , while the bodies of two sexy , writhing women entice you below . 
<s>  trouble is , murnau's monster is pale-faced , bald , pointy-eared , and non-goateed , and there isn't a single sexy , writhing woman to be found in his movie . 
<s>  this sort of misleading packaging makes little sense when one recalls the countless number of ghouslish scenes in the film from which cool cover art could have been extracted . 
<s>  additionally , notifying the viewer that this is in fact murnau's film seems like afterthought since his name and the genuine title are written in small print below our goateed vampire . 
<s>  that said , a good mastering job has been performed on the film itself . 
<s>  the original elements are not in the best condition--non-studio silents were unlucky in their preservation-- so we're still dealing with a slightly washed out , scratched , jittering image . 
<s>  but at least the day and night scenes are tinted sepia and blue , respectively , especially helpful to an audience who may question nosferatu's waltzing around during what seems like sunlight ( it took a lot of light to expose stock in the twenties ) . 
<s>  the title cards have been redone , and they are legible , accurate , and digitally altered to flicker--a very nice touch . 
<s>   ( even the opening copyright warning flickers ! ) 
<s>  the score has been replaced by music from type o negative , a hard-rock group , arguably gothic , and their songs underscore the film nicely-- certainly the coolest video a band can ask for . 
<s>  when our hero , hutter , first steps onto the doomed carriage to count orlock's castle , we hear a well-timed " now you're dead ! " 
<s>  from lead singer peter steele . 
<s>  david carradine makes an appropriately vampiric host ; he fiddles with a blade and cane while introducing the film . 
<s>  after the feature , which runs about 63 minutes , is included a new music video from type o negative , the black-and-white fang-fest " black no . 1 " . 
<s>  of course , " nosferatu : a symphony of horror " is the main attraction , and while my latest viewing raised questions ( why is the woman called emily in the title cards but " mina " --as bram stoker called her--in hutter's letters ? , for instance ) , it made me realize how much this movie has inspired and been stolen from . 
<s>  coppola's 1992 " bram stoker's dracula " owes a great stylistic debt to murnau's masterpiece , but the one thing it couldn't thieve was the original's abstract charms . 
<s>  this latest incarnation from arrow will probably- -like the rescored " metropolis " a few years back--turn a silent film into more palpable entertainment for the latest generation of film freaks . 
<s>  when i left the theater after seeing david lynch's " lost highway , " i remarked to a fellow movie-goer , " i feel like someone just sucked my brains out through my nose and put them back in through my ears . " 
<s>  in his first feature film in five years , lynch delivers a film second only to his debut picture " eraserhead " on the weirdness scale . 
<s>  you won't " know " what happened when it's over , though there are certainly enough clues with which to make some reasonable guesses . 
<s>  it is difficult to describe the plot of this film , because it depends partly on how you interpret it . 
<s>  i can , however , describe what we see on the screen : l . a . jazz saxophonist fred madison ( bill pullman ) and his wife renee ( patricia arquette ) , whom he clearly suspects of infidelity , receive a series of videotapes apparently filmed inside their house while they were asleep . 
<s>  they are , naturally enough , more than a little frightened and confused , and it doesn't help matters any when " mystery man " ( robert blake ) approaches fred at a party and proceeds to call himself on the telephone at the madisons' house in a scene that is at once hilarious and unnerving . 
<s>  the next morning , fred finds another videotape which , to his ( and our ) surprise , shows him brutally murdering renee in their bedroom . 
<s>  he is convicted of her murder and sent to death row , where he inexplicably disappears one night and is replaced by a young mechanic named pete dayton ( balthazar getty ) . 
<s>  the perplexed prison officials release dayton , whose life begins to intersect with fred in a number of ways - most notably his affair with alice wakefield ( arquette again ) , a blonde who is otherwise renee's spitting image , and another encounter with the mystery man . 
<s>  i would be giving away a little too much to reveal any more , but suffice it to say that lynch doesn't offer any neat wrap ? ups , nor does he put a lid on the metaphysical confusion : the cinematic demons of " lost highway " are out in full force from beginning to end . 
<s>  this description might make " lost highway " sound like a giddy exercise in haywire surrealism , but in fact , while there are traces of lynch's weird sense of humor , this film is anything but giddy most of the time . 
<s>  on the contrary , lost highway is a dark and perplexing mystery that takes lynch's previous excursions into murder and intrigue one step farther . 
<s>  the film does not revolve around a character investigating a mystery ; rather , the character * is * the mystery . 
<s>  there are recurring and at times deeply disturbing images of suspicion , distrust , and infidelity thoughout the film that seem to indicate a deluded , fractured psyche at the root of all the bizarre goings-on here . 
<s>  we , the audience , are left to puzzle out whose psyche it is that is driving this ( probably fred's , in my opinion ) and what , in that case , the other characters and events are meant to represent . 
<s>  all of this proceeds , appropriately , in lynch's typically slow-paced , idiosyncratic style . 
<s>  as is often the case , lynch relies on sound , imagery , and mood more than on dialogue and action to tell his story , and in " lost highway " it works perfectly . 
<s>  there are scenes when the camera lingers on fred's blank expression as he drifts uncomfortably down a hallway , or on his pained face in his prison cell while the haunting strains of this mortal coil's " song to the siren " can be heard faintly in the background ; nothing is technically " happening " in these scenes , yet they present a vivid picture of a man losing his grip just as effective as , if not more so than , the hysterical screaming found in most movie presentations of insanity . 
<s>  lynch's direction and director of photography pete deming's darkly lit cinematography serve to create a nearly suffocating atmosphere of tension and fear that are exactly what is needed for this story . 
<s>  well , most of the time , anyway - i have to admit that i was a bit bored at times during the section of the film with pete dayton as the protgaonist , which is less inherently interesting and mostly keeps the viewer's attention because of its tie-ins to the original mystery . 
<s>  the main characters in this " reality " - dayton ( a well-meaning but none too intelligent 24-year-old ) , a sleazy gangster ( who for some reason has two names but otherwise is pretty much a stock character ) , and his porn-star girlfriend ( the blond arquette ) - are nothing you couldn't find in any of the two dozen " pulp fiction " wannabes ; fortunately , the reappearance of the mystery man as well as some other typically lynchian elements , such as the strained , awkward conversations between pete and his parents , help to preserve the film's spooky , unnerving tone during this stretch . 
<s>  lynch's typically graphic and disturbing portrayals of fringe sexuality , while relevant to the themes of jealousy and adultery , are also somewhat overdone here . 
<s>  it's not exactly exploitative - like almost everything else in this film , the sex is thoroughly weird and creepy and is unlikely to provide any cheap lurid thrills - as much as it is unnecessary and frankly kind of dumb by the seventh or eighth time arquette takes her clothes off . 
<s>  that said , these minor flaws don't prevent " lost highway " from attaining its place as one of the darkest , most unsettling films to hit the screens in recent years . 
<s>  it is a one-way ride down the lost highway of a disturbed mind , and as such it is gripping , intense , and brilliantly effective .

<s>  jake kasdan , son of one of the best screenwriters around , breaks into filmmaking by writing and directing this hard-to-categorize detective story : part mystery , part comedy , part character study and part romance . 
<s>  for the most part , kasdan manages to combine the genres successfully and create a captivating film . 
<s>  daryl zero ( bill pullman ) is a modern day sherlock holmes . 
<s>  the parallel is present down to his love of music ( though zero plays the guitar rather than the violin ) , and his addiction to drugs ( amphetamines , rather than morphine ) . 
<s>  he even titles his cases with such sherlockian epigrams as the case of the mismatched shoelaces , the case about the man who lied about his age , or the case of the hired gun who made way way too many mistakes . 
<s>  however zero's observance of the fine art of detachment , though it makes him a brilliant private investigator , makes him somewhat of a self-imposed outcast in society .

<s>  arlo is not happy with his job . 
<s>  he is thrilled to be around zero's brilliance , but his bizarre behavior , and strange requests , are frustrating to the former lawyer . 
<s>  and they're even more so to his girlfriend , jess ( angela featherstone ) , who is fed up that her boyfriend's boss means more to arlo than her .

<s>  now , stark is being blackmailed , and needs to reclaim his key before the nightmare can end .

<s>  however , this is when he is vulnerable . . . and 
<s>  this time he falls for charms of a wily paramedic , gloria sullivan ( kim dickens ) , who may be involved in the blackmail scheme . 
<s>  for the first time , zero has to question his own objectivity , as he finds his client less and less sympathetic . 
<s>  zero effect is weakest in its obviously " wacky " scenes depicting daryl zero's odd behavior . 
<s>  such scenes might be appropriate in an out-and-out satire , making zero an ace ventura-ish character . 
<s>  however , there's a much meatier movie in here . . . it just takes a while to get out . 
<s>  that's not to say that there's not a place for humor in this film . 
<s>  in fact , some of the best scenes are ben stiller's wonderfully underplayed comic moments of absolute disgust and frustration with his employer . 
<s>  however , the over-the-top scenes never quite gel with the rest of the film , and they aren't funny enough to stand on their own . 
<s>  once the investigation is underway , however , zero's brilliance really begins to shine .

<s>  zero effect works well during its romantic scenes as well .

<s>  however , we are always kept distant from gloria's character .

<s>  and , although it is sometimes hard to take a detective called " zero " seriously , it is at this moment that the viewer understands the meaning behind the name .

<s>  in 1998 , director brett ratner and his stars , jackie chan and chris tucker , breathed new life into the buddy-action film genre with the cross-cultural " rush hour " - to the tune of about $250 million . 
<s>  you don't mess with success , so the team is back again , and better , in " rush hour 2 . " 
<s>  the combo of the terrific physical talents of chan and the non-stop motor mouth of tucker made for an ethnically unusual duet in " rush hour " that played well to audiences around the world . 
<s>  the formula worked so well , in fact , that the sequel was inevitable . 
<s>  i'm never thrilled with the idea of a follow-up to a successful original since they rarely meet the previously set expectations . 
<s>  surprisingly , " rush hour 2 " wastes no time getting down to business and turns out to be better than the flick that spawned it . 
<s>  the script , by jeff nathanson ( utilizing the characters developed by ross lamanna in the first film ) , wastes no time getting to the point right from the start . 
<s>  terrorists have bombed the us embassy in hong kong , killing two american translators , and chief inspector lee ( jackie chan ) is handed the job of solving the crime . 
<s>  concurrently , his friend james carter ( chris tucker ) arrives on the island for some much needed r&r and expects his friend to spend some time and show him the sights . 
<s>  instead , lee drags carter into the case and the duo get involved in stopping a conspiracy to counterfeit hundreds of million of us dollars . 
<s>  the makers of " rush hour 2 " are working at a distinct advantage over the original . 
<s>  we , the viewer , are familiar with the two lead characters and the already-existing chemistry that chan and tucker developed so well the first time around . 
<s>  that chemistry was a high point ( and probably the saving point ) before and , now , the pair wears their friendship like a comfortable suit . 
<s>  little time is wasted in getting to know the key players so the screenplay capitalizes on those things we liked best in " rush hour . " 
<s>  first and foremost to me , in " rh2 , " is the immense pleasure in watching jackie chan's artistry in fight choreography . 
<s>  the 47-year old martial arts master has a renowned reputation for doing all of his own stunt work and , here , he does not disappoint . 
<s>  chan's use of props when battling bad guys continues as he pulverizes his opponents with whatever item comes to hand , such as a trash bucket . 
<s>  his moves look every bit as good as they ever did as he fights four or five nemesis at once on bamboo scaffolding , on the tail end of a yacht , in a hong kong massage parlor and , for the finale , in a las vegas casino . 
<s>  like harold lloyd or buster keaton , chan takes pride in putting his physical self on the line in pursuit of his artistry and is a joy to watch . 
<s>  chris tucker reprises his role as the motor mouthed la cop , carter , who teams , again , with lee to put down the bad guys . 
<s>  when he is unceremoniously pulled from his vacation to help his colleague and friend with the big case , he still looks to have some fun . 
<s>  when lee goes into a karaoke bar , the lair of chief bad guy ricky tan ( john lone ) and his hoods , carter takes the spotlight on stage with a credible michael jackson riff . 
<s>  the comedian made the move from the improv stage to the big screen and , with jackie chan , has a franchise to hang his coat on to pay the bills . 
<s>  the combo of chan's flying feet and fists with tucker's fast mouth make a duet more endearing than riggs and murtaugh in the " lethal weapon " films . 
<s>  the supporting cast is here to move things along efficiently . 
<s>  john lone , as ricky tan , is a suave villain who is the real power behind the throne of american bigwig steven reign ( alan king in a walk through performance ) . 
<s>  lone doesn't chew scenery or make pronouncements to " get lee and carter , " but gives the chief bad guy elegance . 
<s>  zhang zi-yi ( " crouching tiger , hidden dragon " ) continues to display her martial arts skills as ricky's taciturn henchlady , hu li , who carries on an ongoing battle with carter . 
<s>   ( carter has a problem , through most of the film , with hitting a woman , but this falls aside with their eventual one-on-one melee at the conclusion . ) 
<s>  roselyn sanchez is knockdown gorgeous ( and resembles sandra bullock ) as undercover agent isabella molina - she doesn't add much to the equation but is terrific to watch . 
<s>  director ratner and the original " rush hour " production team have assembled a crew of skilled craftsmen to work behind the camera . 
<s>  cinematographer matthew f . leonetti has had a long career of shooting action flicks and gives " rh2 " the fluid camera movement the genre film needs . 
<s>  production design by terrence marsh spans continents and gives the right look , whether it is in a hong kong karaoke bar or a high stakes las vegas casino . 
<s>  the rest of the techs are of the same high quality .

<s>  his suspicions are confirmed when the ghost of his father appears and relates the story of his murder at his own brother's hands .

<s>  with external scenes filmed at blemheim palace in england ( also the one of the sites for the recent the avengers ) , the grandiose quality of the setting is immediately established . 
<s>  interior scenes are similarly graced with intricate and flamboyant rooms and chambers .

<s>  costuming is equally grand , drawing upon both history and imagination . .

<s>  in addition to directing , kenneth branagh also plays the title character .

<s>  from the anticipation of seeing his father's ghost , to the melancholy of finding the burial site of his childhood jester , to his eventual wrath , branagh delivers in spades .

<s>  the year is 1962 and the military is conducting nuclear testings . 
<s>  involved in these tests is hank marshall ( jones ) , an army colonel who is critical of the above-ground tests that are being done .

<s>  amy locane is very good as she fights to keep her family together while struggling with her own doubts as to whether she even should . 
<s>  blue sky is based on the story of the stagner family . 
<s>  the screenplay was written by rama laurie stagner ( with arlene sarner and jerry leichtling ) . 
<s>  the film marks the final work of tony richardson who died shortly after its completion in 1991 . 
<s>  he had made such classics as look back in anger ( 1958 ) and tom jones ( 1963 ) . 
<s>  orion pictures underwent bankruptcy and caused the film to sit on a shelf for three years . 
<s>  the film joins an alread promising fall line-up of films and is well worth catching for the performances alone .

<s>  in some respects , rush hour is the ultimate exercise in cliched filmmaking . 
<s>  the hero is the renegade cop that prefers to work alone . 
<s>  the cop in question cannot solve the case until he gets in trouble . 
<s>  all chinese people are somehow involved in the criminal element .

<s>  rush hour is jackie chan's first major hollywood film since the dismal the protector ( 1985 ) . 
<s>  proving once again that hollywood can learn many things from foreign film markets ( ie : hong kong ) , jackie chan is given much more free reign than before . 
<s>  still , some die-hard jackie chan fans may be disappointed , as even chan himself has voiced displeasure over the length of the fight scenes ( which he views as too short , according to one interview ) . 
<s>  this film takes a familiar theme of east meets west . 
<s>  jackie chan is lee , the straight laced inspector who is imported to help deal with a kidnapping case , while chris tucker is carter , the loudmouthed , destructive cop that is `promoted' to the fbi to help him . 
<s>  or , at least , so he thinks ( also another classic notion in action films : the fbi must always get in the way of our heroes ) . 
<s>  despite the necessary conventions of action films , rush hour is some of the most fun you'll spend and hour and forty minutes watching . 
<s>  jackie chan continues to be one of the most exciting martial artists on the big screen , continuing to perform his own stunts and dazzling audiences with his flashy kicks and punches . 
<s>  chris tucker , familiar from his whiny , annoying role in the fifth element is more palatable , complementing jackie chan's straight-laced character . 
<s>  however , jackie chan still maintains his comic-slapstick edge , as expected of him and his films . 
<s>  perfectly downplaying the `fish-out-of-water' routine through his character's attempts at mixing into american culture , he makes up for the down time his character experiences . 
<s>  when he is in action , however , you'll be amused and dazzled . 
<s>  still being inventive in the use of objects to beat people up ( in this case , a steering wheel , a serving tray , and a barstool ) , jackie chan proves to be the pioneer of slapstick kung fu . 
<s>  chris tucker's character may come across as irritating , yet is also humorous . 
<s>  since he's not a physical actor to the level of jackie chan , he uses his main weapon : his mouth ( hence , the tagline , `fastest hands in the east meets the fastest mouth in the west' ) . 
<s>  while dialogue is not necessarily shakespeare , it is appropriate for the film and still very funny . 
<s>  while not necessarily poignant , attempts at character development and growth between characters come off surprisingly well .

<s>  while rush hour is not at the same level as police story 3 and 4 ( known in north america as supercop and jackie chan's first strike , respectively ) , it more than makes up for the poorly received films operation condor and mr . nice guy .

<s>  reviewed by brandon herring october 7 , 1999 . 
<s>  i have to admit that i disliked this film initially . 
<s>  it certianly isn't for every taste , and it's sheer torture to sit through if you're in a restless mood . 
<s>  that said , if you are in the right mood , it's absolutely incredible . 
<s>  this was my second favorite movie of 1998 , and would have been a shoo-in for first in almost any other year . 
<s>  perhaps the big turn-off for many was this film's unconventionality . 
<s>  i'd be hard-pressed to compare it to any other film that i've seen - it is very , very artsy , incredibly slow - and amazingly , it works beautifully . 
<s>  on my second viewing , i realized that the film follows the three act structure ( i didn't think it had any sort of structure at all when i first saw it ) . 
<s>  the first act serves to set up the characters - sort of . 
<s>  it exists even moreso to set a mood of tension and restlesness , and perhaps even feelings of boredom . 
<s>  and then it is shattered by the intense violence of the second ( which encompasses most of the movie ) . 
<s>  the majority of the film is one extended battle scene , intercut with brief flashbacks and voice-overs . 
<s>  the artsier elements do not detract from the action , but add to it - they succeed in briefly letting the viewer peek into the minds of the soldiers , only to be suddenly yanked back into reality when the battle resumes . 
<s>  the battle scenes are amazing ( second only to " saving private ryan " in my opinion ) . 
<s>  they're brutal , horrifying , and at times beautiful due to the amazing cinematography . 
<s>  the second act is as immersive , brilliant , and haunting as any film that i have ever seen . 
<s>  the only problems come during the first and third acts . 
<s>  malick takes a little too long to get the film started . 
<s>  although the initial scenes - which consist of two soldiers' experiencing a near-eden-like paradise while going awol , and the preperations for battle - are effective and necessary , hints of pretentiousness sink in . 
<s>  the film is just a tad too artsy near the beginning , and a lot of people that disliked the movie probably gave up on it because of this . 
<s>  the final act is effective at winding the film down , but the problems from the first persist - it's a bit too long , and comes over as pretentious at times . 
<s>  that said , there are two sequences ( one where a soldier gets a devastating note from his wife , and another where one of the main characters is killed ) that are nothing short of incredible . 
<s>  the performances are phenominal all around . 
<s>  the two standouts are nick nolte and newcomer jim caviezel , both of whom should have been nominated for oscars . 
<s>  nolte is riveting and intense as the colonel in charge of the operation . 
<s>  his character is hard , mean , and somewhat reckless with the lives of his men , and yet nolte somehow manages to evoke sympathy for him . 
<s>  caviezel is forever questioning the nature of war , his place in it , and if there's any deeper meaning to the hell that he's going through . 
<s>  he is absolutely perfect - genuine , sympathetic , sincere , and yet strong when he needs to be . 
<s>  although restricted to a relatively small role , sean penn is also very good as the company's pessimistic seargent . 
<s>  as to how it stacks up to " saving private ryan " - it was my second favorite movie of 1998 , " ryan " was my first . 
<s>  it's really hard to compare the two - they are so , so different - so i won't , beyond saying that spielberg's film had more of an impact on me . 
<s>  however , the two are comparable from the standpoint of quality ( i can easily see why someone would " the thin red line " above " ryan ) . 
<s>  i highly recommend both of them , and consider them to be the two best war movies ever made . 
<s>  all in all , " the thin red line " is filmmaking of an incredibly high order . 
<s>  it's slight faults are easily offset by the sheer brilliance of what is done right . 
<s>  it's a real shame that it tanked at the box office - films this unconventional , powerful , and thought-provoking don't come along very often . 
<s>  it was a rainy friday afternoon in columbus when i persuaded a friend to see a matinee performance of mst3k : tm . 
<s>  he had never seen any episodes of the show , and i have watched a scant few , due to its unsocial airtime on comedy central and the uneven nature of many of the episodes . 
<s>  for those of you not familiar with the premise , dr clayton forrester ( beaulieu ) wishes to take over the world by finding the worst film ever made and unleashing it upon an unsuspecting public . 
<s>  to achieve this , he ( in the words of the tv series' theme , which is missing in the movie ) " bumped [mike nelson ( nelson ) ] on the noggin and then shot him into space " , and is monitoring nelson's reactions to the movies he is forced to endure . 
<s>  rather than succumb to the sheer awfulness of many of the movies , nelson spends his time making wisecracks with the help of his two robot companions , tom servo and crow t . robot . 
<s>  the format of the show consists of nelson , servo and crow making their comments while silhouetted against the movie being watched , and breaks every 20 minutes or so for segments set on the satellite of love , the ship on which our heroes are marooned . 
<s>  only two things are different in the movie : the absence of forrester's sidekick , tv's frank , and the slower pace of the jokes . 
<s>  this latter change is presumably deliberate to avoid the viewing audience missing some of the best lines while laughing from the previous joke . 
<s>  for their big screen outing , the producers have chosen " this island earth " , a 1954 classic , and one of the first sf films to have a special effects budget larger than the average grocery bill . 
<s>  unfortunately for that film ( but making it ideal mst3k fodder ) , acting and dialogue appear to have taken a back seat to the effects which , by today's standards , are less than impressive . 
<s>  nelson & co . make jokes about everything from japan's dominance in the world market , to star trek , to the state of disrepair of seattle's kingdome , and most of them work . 
<s>  unfortunately , the segments set outside the satellite's movie theater seem out of place and aren't particularly funny , but at least they're fairly short . 
<s>  the big question about this movie though is : why ? 
<s>  i presume it was an attempt to gain a larger following to keep support behind the series ( rumours of its impending demise circulated for some time before the plug was eventually pulled a few months ago ) , but the format gains nothing from its transition to the big screen -- there are no special effects to dazzle you , no action sequences to keep you on the edge of your seat , and no use of digital surround sound . 
<s>  so , it seems pointless to spend $8 per person to see this movie when in a few months it will be out on video and you can watch it for $3 , and not have to sit in a room full of popcorn addicts . 
<s>  nevertheless , mst3k : tm provides more laugh-out-loud opportunities than any film you're going to see this year , and i thoroughly recommend it to anyone with a pulse . 
<s>  given its uniqueness , i hesitate to grade it against other films , but it fulfils its claims and so in the class of " unsubtle comedy films whose laughs come at the expense of bad b-movies " it does well . 
<s>  the uncompromising nudity bared throughout petrice chereau's intimacy has already garnered much notoriety , but it's in the naked faces of fearless actors mark rylance ( angels & insects ) and kerry fox ( welcome to sarajevo ) that the tender ache of emotional resonance is discovered . 
<s>  with sharp , intelligent eyes that reflect experience and maturity , rylance and fox are refreshingly detached from the false glamour of hollywood idols . 
<s>  their sex scenes together are bracing in their raw honesty , in the acceptance of flesh and messiness . 
<s>  less apparent , but no less remarkable , are the astute observations of behavior revealed through those carnal beats of haste and hesitance , often without a single line of dialogue . 
<s>  not aiming for the spiritual poetry of in the realm of the senses or the philosophical transgressions of crash , chereau keeps his sexual odyssey firmly grounded in terms of straightforward character development . 
<s>  that may be the very reason why intimacy seems unerringly impressive but never particularly significant on more than a tactile , sensory level . 
<s>  the themes of human isolation are barren and obvious , a science project devoid of any especially groundbreaking hypothesis . 
<s>  intimacy does manage to stand out from lesser portraits of " human interconnectedness " and pinter-esque rummages through psychological dirty drawers ( okay , kill me ) . 
<s>  shallow though it might sound , it's amazing how much is filled in through an inspired cast , perceptive camerawork , and imaginative ways of treating the love scene . 
<s>  those ingredients are too assured and confident to merely dismiss as icing on the cake , especially since they are the substance of the cake itself . 
<s>  adapted from a pair of short stories by british novelist hanif kureishi , intimacy weaves desperate lovemaking between two strangers in london . 
<s>  every wednesday , jay ( rylance ) and claire ( fox ) meet in his cluttered , dank apartment for an hour or two of sexual release from their uninspired lives . 
<s>  he's been head bartender at a posh restaurant for over six years . 
<s>  she's a mystery to him but her glum workaday appearance reveals a similar dissatisfaction . 
<s>  they're both married , but his relationship has curdled into an embittered separation . 
<s>  as the weeks draw on , jay obsessively takes it upon himself to uncover claire's personal routines . 
<s>  in his attempt to gain a fuller semblance of who she is , he opens wounds that hadn't existed before by single-handedly corrupting the fantasy . 
<s>  if it weren't for a few unnecessary subplots involving jay's brother and his bevy of disgruntled co-workers , this minimalist premise might be described as a modern fable on the perils of wish fulfillment . 
<s>  chareau's restless camera ( once again wielded by superb and ever-attentive cinematographer eric gautier ) is less appropriate here than in his family transit-oriented those who love me can take the train . 
<s>  the scenes that linger are the still ones where rylance and fox separately , pensively attempt to carry on with their makeshift household routines . 
<s>  these are often captured in lingering , unblinking wide shots that view them stranded amidst their drab workplaces and homes . 
<s>  separation proves haunting in a melancholy series of intercut shots as rylance and fox undress on opposite sides of the room , crawling across the floor to meet in the center . 
<s>  despite being as restless as a fly during the hyperactive restaurant scenes ( all the better to blend in with a hustling crowd of gabby trendsetters ) , you'd be hard pressed to find a single uninteresting image . 
<s>  intimacy takes an interest in its sordid world of the lower-middle class , with lonely pubs and busy shopping streets -- it also understands the people who inhabit those spaces , viewing them with sympathy scraped raw . 
<s>  an evaluation would be incomplete without highlighting the great timothy spall ( the robust scene-stealer of many a mike leigh collaboration ) . 
<s>  as claire's cuckolded husband , this jocular heavyweight plays out his handful of bitter pill scenes with the unforced menace and self-effacing embarrassment of his imposing bulk . 
<s>  bangs in his eyes , his mouth forming into quizzical pouts and dry smirks , he may seem the fool in his barroom encounters opposite a sarcastic , gleaming mark rylance ( whose jay has arrived on the scene looking to stir up some trouble ) , but spall is no one to trifle with . 
<s>  his overreaching best pal demeanor suggests a mind abuzz with secret passageways of guile , his pointed questions only na ? ve if you choose not to read into their crafty insinuations . 
<s>  in his unassuming way , spall's carefully etched interpretation of hostility buried under a mountain of surface propriety may become one of the most criminally underappreciated performances of the year , but maybe also one of the best . 
<s>  he's that good . 
<s>  george little ( jonathan lipnicki ) wants a little brother .
