<s>   " quest for camelot " is warner bros . ' first feature-length , fully-animated attempt to steal clout from disney's cartoon empire , but the mouse has no reason to be worried . 
<s>  the only other recent challenger to their throne was last fall's promising , if flawed , 20th century fox production " anastasia , " but disney's " hercules , " with its lively cast and colorful palate , had her beat hands-down when it came time to crown 1997's best piece of animation . 
<s>  this year , it's no contest , as " quest for camelot " is pretty much dead on arrival . 
<s>  even the magic kingdom at its most mediocre -- that'd be " pocahontas " for those of you keeping score -- isn't nearly as dull as this . 
<s>  the story revolves around the adventures of free-spirited kayley ( voiced by jessalyn gilsig ) , the early-teen daughter of a belated knight from king arthur's round table .

<s>  synopsis : a mentally unstable man undergoing psychotherapy saves a boy from a potentially fatal accident and then falls in love with the boy's mother , a fledgling restauranteur . 
<s>  unsuccessfully attempting to gain the woman's favor , he takes pictures of her and kills a number of people in his way . 
<s>  comments : stalked is yet another in a seemingly endless string of spurned-psychos-getting-their-revenge type movies which are a stable category in the 1990s film industry , both theatrical and direct-to-video . 
<s>  their proliferation may be due in part to the fact that they're typically inexpensive to produce ( no special effects , no big name stars ) and serve as vehicles to flash nudity ( allowing them to frequent late-night cable television ) . 
<s>  stalked wavers slightly from the norm in one respect : the psycho never actually has an affair ; on the contrary , he's rejected rather quickly ( the psycho typically is an ex-lover , ex-wife , or ex-husband ) . 
<s>  other than that , stalked is just another redundant entry doomed to collect dust on video shelves and viewed after midnight on cable . 
<s>  stalked does not provide much suspense , though that is what it sets out to do . 
<s>  interspersed throughout the opening credits , for instance , a serious-sounding narrator spouts statistics about stalkers and ponders what may cause a man to stalk ( it's implicitly implied that all stalkers are men ) while pictures of a boy are shown on the screen . 
<s>  after these credits , a snapshot of actor jay underwood appears . 
<s>  the narrator states that " this is the story of daryl gleason " and tells the audience that he is the stalker . 
<s>  of course , really , this is the story of restauranteur brooke daniels . 
<s>  if the movie was meant to be about daryl , then it should have been called stalker not stalked . 
<s>  okay . so we know who the stalker is even before the movie starts ; no guesswork required . 
<s>  stalked proceeds , then , as it begins : obvious , obvious , obvious . 
<s>  the opening sequence , contrived quite a bit , brings daryl and brooke ( the victim ) together . 
<s>  daryl obsesses over brooke , follows her around , and tries to woo her . 
<s>  ultimately rejected by her , his plans become more and more desperate and elaborate . 
<s>  these plans include the all-time , psycho-in-love , cliche : the murdered pet . 
<s>  for some reason , this genre's films require a dead pet to be found by the victim stalked . 
<s>  stalked is no exception ( it's a cat this time -- found in the shower ) . 
<s>  events like these lead to the inevitable showdown between stalker and stalked , where only one survives ( guess who it invariably always is and you'll guess the conclusion to this turkey ) . 
<s>  stalked's cast is uniformly adequate : not anything to write home about but also not all that bad either . 
<s>  jay underwood , as the stalker , turns toward melodrama a bit too much . 
<s>  he overdoes it , in other words , but he still manages to be creepy enough to pass as the type of stalker the story demands . 
<s>  maryam d'abo , about the only actor close to being a star here ( she played the bond chick in the living daylights ) , is equally adequate as the " stalked " of the title , even though she seems too ditzy at times to be a strong , independent business-owner . 
<s>  brooke ( d'abo ) needs to be ditzy , however , for the plot to proceed . 
<s>  toward the end , for example , brooke has her suspicions about daryl . 
<s>  to ensure he won't use it as another excuse to see her , brooke decides to return a toolbox he had left at her place to his house . 
<s>  does she just leave the toolbox at the door when no one answers ? 
<s>  of course not . 
<s>  she tries the door , opens it , and wanders around the house . 
<s>  when daryl returns , he enters the house , of course , so our heroine is in danger . 
<s>  somehow , even though her car is parked at the front of the house , right by the front door , daryl is oblivious to her presence inside . 
<s>  the whole episode places an incredible strain on the audience's suspension of disbelief and questions the validity of either character's intelligence . 
<s>  stalked receives two stars because , even though it is highly derivative and somewhat boring , it is not so bad that it cannot be watched . 
<s>  rated r mostly for several murder scenes and brief nudity in a strip bar , it is not as offensive as many other thrillers in this genre are . 
<s>  if you're in the mood for a good suspense film , though , stake out something else . 
<s>  capsule : in 2176 on the planet mars police taking into custody an accused murderer face the title menace . 
<s>  there is a lot of fighting and not a whole lot of story otherwise . 
<s>  john carpenter reprises so many ideas from his previous films , especially assault on precinct 13 , that the new film comes off as his homage to himself . 
<s>   , 0 ( -4 to +4 ) . 
<s>  john carpenter apparently believes that action scenes in which people fight something horrible are the same as horror scenes . 
<s>  for a writer and director of horror films , supposedly an expert on horror , it is a very bad mistake to make . 
<s>  ghosts of mars is called a horror movie , but it is more just a drawn out fight between humans and a surprisingly low-powered alien menace . 
<s>  in addition if anybody but john carpenter had made ghosts of mars , carpenter would have grounds to sue . 
<s>  this film is just chock full of pieces taken from assault on precinct 13 , the thing , and prince of darkness . 
<s>  it is , in fact , surprising that carpenter managed to fit so many pieces of his previous work into this film in such an admittedly novel way . 
<s>  but that still does not make for a really good science fiction experience . 
<s>  ghosts of mars takes place in the year 2176 . 
<s>  mars has been mostly terraformed so that humans can walk on the surface without breathing gear ( which is good for the film's budget ) . 
<s>  it is never mentioned , but the gravity on mars has been increased somehow to earth-normal , again making it easier to film . 
<s>  society has changed a bit by that time , but it has advanced surprisingly little . 
<s>  apparently the culture has changed so that women are much more in positions of control . 
<s>  and from carpenter's view , women have really made a mess of things . 
<s>  society has stagnated under female control so that beyond some minor technological advances society has changed less in 175 years than we might expect it to change in ten . 
<s>  the basic plot of ghosts of mars has much in common with that of assault on precinct 13 except that precinct 9 ( yes , precinct 9 ) has been replaced by a somewhat tacky looking rundown martian mining colony . 
<s>  instead of having the criminal " napolean " wilson , this film has the criminal " desolation " williams .

<s>  ghosts of mars takes place entirely at night and is filmed almost entirely in tones of red , yellow , and black .

<s>  so ask yourself what " 8mm " ( " eight millimeter " ) is really all about . 
<s>  is it about a wholesome surveillance man who loses sight of his values after becoming enmeshed in the seedy , sleazy underworld of hardcore pornography ? 
<s>  is it about the business itself , how , bubbling just beneath the surface of big-town americana , there's a sordid world of sick and depraved people who won't necessarily stop short of murder in order to satisfy their sick and twisted desires ? 
<s>  or is it about those who can , those who are in a position to influence the making of the kinds of films sick and demented people want to see ? 
<s>  i'm not talking about snuff films , supposed " documentaries " of victims being brutalized and killed on camera . 
<s>  i'm talking about films like " 8mm " and its director , joel schumacher . 
<s>  with a recent run of big budget movies to his credit-- " batman & robin , " " a time to kill , " " batman forever , " " the client " --schumacher certainly has that kind of influence . 
<s>  is " 8mm " something you really want to see ? 
<s>  probably not . 
<s>  the first two-thirds of " 8mm " unwind as a fairly conventional missing persons drama , albeit with a particularly unsavory core . 
<s>  then , as it's been threatening all along , the film explodes into violence . 
<s>  and just when you think it's finally over , schumacher tags on a ridiculous self-righteous finale that drags the whole unpleasant experience down even further .

<s>  nicolas ' " snake eyes " ' cage plays private investigator tom welles who is hired by a wealthy philadelphia widow to determine whether a reel of film found in her late husband's safe documents a young girl's murder . 
<s>  welles goes about his assignment rather matter-of-factly , and the pieces of the puzzle fall into place rather neatly , almost as if you don't need any specialized skills or training to do this . 
<s>  welles certainly makes it look easy . 
<s>  and cops , obviously , never look in toilet tanks for clues .

<s>  nine months is a complete failure , low on laughs and intelligence and high on loud , unfunny slapstick , failed jokes and other uninspired lunacy .

<s>  call it a road trip for the walking wounded . 
<s>  stellan skarsg ? rd plays such a convincingly zombified drunken loser that it's difficult to spend nearly two hours of screen time in his smelly , boozed-out presence . 
<s>  yet this ever-reliable swedish actor adds depth and significance to the otherwise plodding and forgettable aberdeen , a sentimental and painfully mundane european drama . 
<s>  playwright august strindberg built his career on families and relationships paralyzed by secrets , unable to express their longings until the hour is far too late . 
<s>  that's an accurate reflection of what aberdeen strives for , focusing on the pairing of an alcoholic father , tomas ( skarsg ? rd ) and his alienated , openly hostile yuppie daughter , kaisa ( lena headey , gossip ) .

<s>  unable to find true notes of unspoken familial empathy in the one-note and repetitively bitchy dialogue , screenwriters kristin amundsen and hans petter moland fabricate a series of contrivances to propel events forward -- lost money , roving street hooligans looking for drunks to kick around , nosy cops , and flat tires all figure into the schematic and convenient narrative .

<s>  best remembered for his understated performance as dr . hannibal lecter in michael mann's forensics thriller , manhunter , scottish character actor brian cox brings something special to every movie he works on . 
<s>  usually playing a bit role in some studio schlock ( he dies halfway through the long kiss goodnight ) , he's only occasionally given something meaty and substantial to do .

<s>  cox plays the role of big john harrigan in the disturbing new indie flick l . i . e . , which lot 47 picked up at sundance when other distributors were scared to budge . 
<s>  big john feels the love that dares not speak its name , but he expresses it through seeking out adolescents and bringing them back to his pad . 
<s>  what bothered some audience members was the presentation of big john in an oddly empathetic light . 
<s>  he's an even-tempered , funny , robust old man who actually listens to the kids' problems ( as opposed to their parents and friends , both caught up in the high-wire act of their own confused lives . ) 
<s>  he'll have sex-for-pay with them only after an elaborate courtship , charming them with temptations from the grown-up world . 
<s>  l . i . e . stands for long island expressway , which slices through the strip malls and middle-class homes of suburbia . 
<s>  filmmaker michael cuesta uses it as a ( pretty transparent ) metaphor of dangerous escape for his 15-year old protagonist , howie ( paul franklin dano ) . 
<s>  in his opening voice-over , howie reveals a morbid preoccupation with death on the road , citing the l . i . e . 
<s>  highway deaths of filmmaker alan j . pakula , songwriter harry chapin , and his own mother on exit 52 . 
<s>  he's both fascinated and disturbed by the l . i . e . , and those feelings are projected onto big john ( who follows howie around in his bright red car , but never makes a move to force the boy to do something he doesn't want to do . 
<s>  this makes him much more complex than the usual child molesters seen in movies -- he's a beast , but ashamed of it . ) 
<s>  l . i . e . would have worked best as a half-hour short film about howie's ill-advised foray into big john's haven . 
<s>  there is unnecessary padding with howie's miserable dad ( bruce altman ) in the hot seat for a white-collar crime , degenerate youngsters who get their kicks from robbing middle-class houses , and some homoerotic shenanigans with wise-ass gary terrio ( billy kay ) , a handsome artful dodger . 
<s>  rather than add to the themes of suburban ennui ( not that we needed another movie on that subject ) , these awkward subplots pad out the running time to adequate feature length . 
<s>  concurrently , the relationship between howie and big john is evenly paced and exceptionally well acted . 
<s>  cox , sporting a baseball cap and a faded marine tattoo , is all bluff and bluster . 
<s>  dano is quiet and at first glance seems so withdrawn as to be transparent . 
<s>  we're so used to child actors whose dramatic choices are broad and obvious ( calling haley joel ! ) , it's surprising to see one who actually listens throughout any given scene . 
<s>  the restraint is admirable . 
<s>  but l . i . e . 's screenplay doesn't always give them the best material . 
<s>  when howie reads big john a walt whitman poem , the moment feels a bit too precious . 
<s>  director michael cuesta lingers on an ecstatic reaction shot of big john , who may as well be hearing glenn gould performing bach's goldberg variations . 
<s>  it's too much . 
<s>  there are also some obvious dramatic contrivances involving big john's other boy toy ( walter masterson ) , jealous over the newbie . 
<s>  this plot thread predictably leads to violence . 
<s>  not content to be a haunting , observational portrait of teen alienation in a royally screwed up world ( like terry zwigoff's superb ghost world ) , cuesta lacks the confidence in his own work to end on an ambivalent note . 
<s>  it's typical of unimaginative cinema to wrap things up with a bullet , sparing the writers from actually having to come up with a complex , philosophical note . 
<s>  in this regard , l . i . e .

<s>  how often does real life work this way ? 
<s>  to extend the question : if a movie is striving for realism , do dramatic contrivances destroy the illusion ? 
<s>  janeane garofalo in a romantic comedy -- it was a good idea a couple years ago with the truth about cats and dogs but is almost excruciating in the matchmaker . 
<s>  this is a by-the-books movie that plods along on a predestined course with no surprises and very few laughs . 
<s>  it also jumps on the ever-popular political satire bandwagon and manages to fall flat there , too . 
<s>  garofalo plays a campaign aide to a massacusetts senator ( jay o . sanders ) running for reelection . 
<s>  denis leary plays the stereotypical strategist with no ethics who decides the only way for the scandal- plagued senator to win is to play up his irish roots and cash in on that boston roman catholic democrat contingent that's made the kennedy family so popular . 
<s>  so leary orders garofalo to go to ireland and dig up some relatives to exploit . 
<s>  she soon learns why " easier said than done " is the mantra of movies like this . 
<s>  the matchmaker falls for every cliche of things that can go wrong -- garofalo has to take a tiny plane to ireland , almost misses the bus to town , can't get a hotel room , ends up in the smallest , trashiest one around , has a dog piss on her luggage , and so on . 
<s>  then comes what roger ebert calls the " meet cute . " 
<s>  it happens in every romance : the man and woman have to meet each other for the first time in some unconventional , cinematic way . 
<s>  in the matchmaker , it happens when garofalo walks into her hotel bathroom and finds a nude sean ( david o'hara ) in the bathtub , his dog sitting at his side . 
<s>  no points for guessing it's the same dog that just made water on her luggage . 
<s>  also no points for guessing garofalo hates o'hara on sight . 
<s>  that's how it works in movies like these . 
<s>  i know from the instant i saw that irishman in the bathtub that she'd hate him for awhile , then succumb to his charms , live happily for a reel or so before allowing some superficial detail to throw the relationship into turmoil , after which they'd reconcile in time for a happy irish tune to play over the end credits .

<s>  what the message here ? 
<s>  sometimes even the most respectable person of comedic distinction , like garofalo , will sell out with a weak script .

<s>  both of them should have known better . 
<s>  and now the high-flying hong kong style of filmmaking has made its way down to the classics , and it isn't pretty . 
<s>  this time out the nod to asia goes by way of france in the excruciating bland and lukewarm production of the musketeer , a version of dumas's the three musketeers . 
<s>  by bringing in popular asian actor/stunt coordinator xing xing xiong -- whose only prior american attempts at stunt choreography have been the laughable van damme vehicle double team and the dennis rodman cinematic joke simon sez -- our musketeers are thrown into the air to do their fighting . 
<s>  the end result is a tepid and dull action/adventure rip-off that stinks of indiana jones and bad asian kung fu . 
<s>  the story is so simple my grandmother could have adapted the screenplay . 
<s>  d'artagnan ( justin chambers ) is the vengeful son of a slain musketeer . 
<s>  he travels to paris to join the royal musketeers and find the man that killed his parents . 
<s>  in paris , he meets the cunning cardinal richelieu ( stephen rea ) , who is trying to overthrow the king , and richelieu's man-in-black associate febre ( tim roth ) , the killer of his folks . 
<s>  he finds the musketeers in paris disbanded and drunk , so he rounds up aramis ( nick moran ) , athos ( jan gregor kremp ) and porthos ( steven spiers ) to free the musketeer's wrongfully imprisoned leader treville from the king's prison . 
<s>  d'artagnan and his new frisky love interest/chambermaid francesca ( mena suvari ) play footsy and coo at each other as the cardinal hunts down the musketeers until finally the queen ( catherine deneuve ) ends up being captured by the menancing febre , forcing the musketeers to regroup , with d'artagnan leading the charge , and save the day . 
<s>  director peter hyams ( end of days ) obviously wanted to blend eastern and western filmmaking styles , but here it's a disaster . 
<s>  one problem is that , in reality , most eastern films have taken their lead from western ones . 
<s>  jet li's high risk is a rip-off of die hard -- not the other way around . 
<s>  ironically , there is awfully little swordplay or action in the film at all -- maybe ten minutes of swashbuckling spread over five scenes . 
<s>  most asian action films carry the bulk of their production with 20- to 30-minute action sequences , because they know the scenes have to carry the picture . 
<s>  the musketeer instead weighs itself down with a predictable and monotonous screenplay by gene quintano ( sudden death ) , horrible acting by stephen rea and tim roth , and the prosaic attempt of justin chambers ( the wedding planner ) to deliver his mousy self as a leader . 
<s>  chambers' d'artangnan isn't a musketeer -- he's a mouseketeer ! 
<s>  and hyam's use of candles and torches to light the grime and filth of 17th century paris are well-noted , but that's the only standout in an overall flat production . 
<s>  a movie like mortal kombat : annihilation works ( and must be reviewed on ) multiple levels . 
<s>  first , there's the rampant usage of randian subtext that pervades the entire movie . 
<s>  but occasionaly , almost as if making an ironic , self-depreciating remark , the movie tosses in clearly marxist imagery .

<s>  in all seriousness however , and to be fair to the movie , it * is * necessary to provide two viewpoints : that of a movie watcher unfamiliar ( or only marginally familiar ) with the whole mortal kombat phenomenon , and that of a fan of the first movie and/or a fan of the games . 
<s>  the first movie ( mortal kombat ( 1995 ) ) concerned itself with a martial arts tournament that would decide the fate of earth ( and it's 5 billion inhabitants ) . 
<s>  the mortals won , and in theory this should have prevented the emperor shao khan from taking over the earth . 
<s>  unfortunately , shao khan was a poor loser , and the very final scene in mortal kombat showed him arriving anyway , ready to take over the planet , as our heroes assumed a fighting stance . 
<s>  the first movie was extraordinarily entertaining for those ( like myself ) who are fans of the game . 
<s>  i'd even go so far as to say that many folks who didn't know about the game probably enjoyed the movie . 
<s>  the writers and directors knew the limitations of both their cast and of the basic story itself , and they didn't try to overachieve . 
<s>  there were a lot of really cool fight scenes ( with really cool accompanying music ) , intersperesed with some distracting ( but ultimately non-intrusive ) bits of fluff passing itself off as a plot . 
<s>  and , as we know , the movie was a smashing success at the box office . 
<s>  mortal kombat : annihilation picks up precisely where that movie left off , with some introductory exposition to clue in those who may not have seen the first movie . 
<s>  shao khan has decided that he's going to take over the earth * anyways * , and to hell with some silly rule about mortals winning the tournament . 
<s>  thereafter follows approximately 85 minutes of film that alternates between being confused , being trite , being silly , and being just plain stupid . 
<s>  one gets the general impression that the producers of the movie thought " hey , that last movie was such a success that we can get more money and make a * real * movie now . " 
<s>  too bad they didn't simply stick with the formula from the first movie . 
<s>  i could write volumes about the things that are wrong with this picture , but here are the high points : 
<s>   * the acting is truly bad . 
<s>  sandra hess ( playing the sonya blade character ) is particularly execrable , especially in scenes where she tries to convince us that she loved johnny cage ( a character from the first movie who gets greased at the beginning of this movie ) . 
<s>   * in one of the worst pieces of mis-casting i think i've * ever * seen , james remar plays raiden , the god of thunder . 
<s>  in the first movie , christopher lambert played raiden and played his character as though he was in on the joke : a french actor playing a japanese thunder god being revered by chinese mystics . 
<s>  i generally like it when actors are cast against type ( tim " tiny " lister , jr . being cast as the president of the u . s . in the fifth element , for example ) , and remar has always been one of my favorite " utility " actors but he's so totally wrong for this part that he doesn't even have the luxury of amused self-awareness . 
<s>   * there are too many characters that are introduced as being potentially important , but then never seen again . 
<s>   * there are a number of completely meaningless story sidetracks , including a muddled scene where liu kang ( robin shou ) seeks out nightwolf ( litefoot ) , has a mystical hallucination , and then wanders off with jade ( irina pantaeva ) . 
<s>  for these reasons ( and many others ) , i can only give the movie a 2 . . . 
<s>   . . . unless you're a huge fan of the games and/or the first movie . 
<s>  in that case , the following critiques also apply : 
<s>   * sandra hess , while being an even worse actress than bridgette wilson ( who played sonya blade in the first movie ) , is much more convincing as a fighter . 
<s>  wilson looked like she was simply mimicing some movements taught to her by the fight choreographer . 
<s>  hess looks like she actually knows some martial arts , and puts together a much more believable fight scene . 
<s>   * in the fights , each of the characters does at least * one * thing they do in the game ( and often more ) . 
<s>  sonya does her " kiss of death , " jax does his " earthquake , " liu kang does his " animality , " and so on . 
<s>  a big bonus for those of us who were looking for similar moves in the first movie and found them only rarely . 
<s>   * there aren't as many fight scenes in this movie as there were in the first , because the folks making the movie mistakenly try to hang a more robust plot in between . 
<s>  silly , silly folks . 
<s>  and the lamest fight involved two of the women in what turns into a mud-wrestling match . 
<s>  lame and so obviously sexist even i ( politically incorrect , for the most part ) noticed and remarked upon it .

<s>  john carpenter makes b-movies .

<s>  carpenter's latest horror opus with a science fiction bent ( or science fiction outing with a schlock horror bent ) is the aptly-titled " john carpenter's ghosts of mars " ( in case , i suppose , you went looking for someone else's " ghosts of mars " ) . 
<s>  like all those films prefixed by the very possessive " john carpenter's , " " ghosts of mars " is an unashamed b-movie punctuated by a b-movie plot , b-movie actors , and b-movie special effects . 
<s>  in category one , above , we have a storyline that borders on idiotic ( and , at times , chaotic ) . 
<s>  dormant martians ( i . e . , swirling red gases ) awakened by meddling humans possess the souls of hapless mining colonists rendering them testy marilyn manson lookalikes .

<s>  officer ballard went in to bring back incarcerated felon james " desolation " williams ; what she found was not a pretty picture . 
<s>  in the second category we have ms . henstridge , her blonde hair pulled back tightly and awkwardly into a ponytail , ice cube ( as the appropriately-named " desolation " ) , pam grier ( briefly , oddly--who wanted to work with whom i wonder ? ) , and a host of extras all assuming that the story and special effects were going to carry this film and therefore they didn't need to try too hard . 
<s>  in category number three we have , in addition to those swirling red gases and the silly-looking train , a couple of bird's-eye-view shots of a sprawling martian metropolis ( reddish also ) . 
<s>  state-of-the-art special effects have never been a carpenter trademark and once again the writer/director ( who seems to have no problem finding work , however ) doesn't waste any of the film's budget in that department . 
<s>   " ghosts of mars " is lock , laughing stock , and barrel all your standard carpenter fare : dingy interiors , cluttered exteriors , inane dialogue , lots of leather , scarred , crazed-looking aliens , and lots and lots of weaponry . 
<s>  the film often and always explodes into warfare without warning--spontaneously , stupidly . 
<s>  carpenter might like to think he's made a western here but it's a western without any real heroes , villains , or border conflicts . 
<s>  it's just the shootouts minus a hissing snake plissken .

<s>  it's not * all * the same , however . 
<s>  dubbed the " one-note wonder " for his minimalist music soundtracks , carpenter seems to have graduated from simplistic ( yet effective ) scoring by highlighting his action with loud , screeching guitar work . 
<s>  fortunately this drowns out a lot of the dialogue . 
<s>  the final exchange between henstridge and , er , cube though is both audible * and * priceless .

"

<s>   " in dreams " might keep you awake at night , but not because of its creepy imagery , bizarre visual style or story about a clairvoyant madman who lures young girls to their untimely deaths . 
<s>  no , the source of potential sleeplessness here lies within the movie's brutally squandered potential , the least of which is an admittedly nifty premise - even by tired serial killer genre standards . 
<s>  the big letdown , however , comes upon the realization that this 100-minute head-scratcher was masterminded by neil jordan , the man behind " the crying game . " 
<s>  he's no stranger to cinematic weirdness , but this nutty nonsense really pushes the envelope . 
<s>  things start out strong enough , with cinematographer darius khondji's stunning camera work guiding viewers into the bowels of a underwater ghost town during a creepy prologue that establishes a notably grim tone right off the bat . 
<s>  this eerie opulence remains a dazzling display of showmanship throughout the entire film - there's even something macabre about the way khondji photographs a rustic , seemingly innocent new england autumn - but if there ever was a film that didn't deserve so good a polish , it's this one . 
<s>  don't knock the look , but say what you will about the foolish plot , underdeveloped characters and flat dialogue . 
<s>  annette bening , another asset " in dreams " shouldn't be so lucky to boast , gives an increasingly effective performance in a role that doesn't do much for her in return . 
<s>  she plays claire cooper , a massachusetts children's book illustrator who's plagued by terrifying nightmares involving kidnaped children . 
<s>  she thinks these visions are a warning knell for horrible , soon-to-be-committed crimes , but neither her ho-hum husband ( aidan quinn ) nor the ho-hummer police can muster up the sense to take her seriously . 
<s>  this being a thriller , we know that she is , in fact , on the money , and it's a credit to bening's acting that she delves equally into claire's madness and compassion . 
<s>  but as soon as a body turns up and claire has given the authorities reason enough to believe her claims , " in dreams " trades in its nifty supernatural chills for a long series of allegedly spooky jolts that simply refuse to make sense .

<s>  subplots appear and disappear .

<s>   " knock off " is exactly that : a cheap knock off of an action movie . 
<s>  it's also the worst movie i have seen thus far this year . 
<s>  i figured it would be at least a couple of months before i saw the worst film of 1998 , but alas , it has already been found . 
<s>  jean-claude van damme stars as ( i think ) a designer jeans executive who discovers his half-brother has been supplying him with cheaper goods .

<s>  seconds later , the car drives off at full speed .

<s>  and it's not even one of those movies that's so bad it's funny . 
<s>  it's too inept to be funny . 
<s>  there are no redeeming factors in " knock off " and i seriously hope that every print of this film is burned to a crisp and that somehow my memory of watching the film can be erased . 
<s>   " snake eyes " is the most aggravating kind of movie : the kind that shows so much potential then becomes unbelievably disappointing . 
<s>  it's not just because this is a brian depalma film , and since he's a great director and one who's films are always greeted with at least some fanfare . 
<s>  and it's not even because this was a film starring nicolas cage and since he gives a brauvara performance , this film is hardly worth his talents . 
<s>  it's worse than that . 
<s>  it's aggravating for the sole reason that its story could be so much more , could be totally intelligent , and it opens up with absolutely no subtlety that it will be handled complexly and intensely . . . then at one point in the movie makes on wrong turn that leads it to the hall of fame of half-assedness . 
<s>  or more deservedly , the hall of fame of the eighth-assedness . 
<s>  in certain circles , " snake eyes " was being advertised as a kind of modern day version of kurosawa's classic " rashomon , " where a crime is told from the four different ( and i mean different ) perspectives , and it looks as though it may actually be just like this with the opening , which , i might add , is superb . 
<s>  in one very very very long steadicam shot , we meet the protagonist , crooked atlantic city detective , rick santoro ( cage ) , and follow him before a boxing match as he talks on his cell phone with his wife , interupts a pay-per-view event on tv , chases down a gambler , enters the arena all pumped up for the fight , sits down and talks with his bud , kevin dunne ( gary sinise , who's character should not be confused with that of actor kevin dunn , who's also in this ) , and watches as it happens . 
<s>  there's a big name in the crowd , and that's the secretary of defense , charles kirkland ( joel fabiani ) , who's sitting behind rick , and who gets shot a second after the heavyweight champion , lincoln tyler ( stan shaw ) , is knocked out . 
<s>  this all happens in the opening shot , and it creates so many red herrings and possibilities of what happened that it opens this scene up for close examination and total deconstruction . 
<s>  what really happened , this film asks , and it sets this film up extremely well for when rick begins to question people and get different perspectives on the scene . . . and 
<s>  discovers there's a very good possibility it was a conspiracy . 
<s>  as we follow rick trying to learn of more information , we also meet a woman who was talking to kirkland before he was shot ( carla gugino ) , and who flees the scene in a panic , and tries to hide from the cops in the arena and the adjacent casino/hotel since the cops have blocked off the doors so they can get witness' takes on what happened . 
<s>  this is all going pretty fine and dandy , and it's extremely interesting to watch . . . then 
<s>  it takes one wrong step . 
<s>  we follow the wrong character , and we learn of the answer to the mystery too early on , and way before rick can find it out . 
<s>  but that's not the worst part of it : it's that it's the one person you didn't think it would be because he was too obviously supposed to be the red herring , the one you didn't think did it because it would be stupid and cliched of that person to be behind it . 
<s>  it only gets worse : the film turns into a chase film about half way through the film , and since we already know what happened , we can't rely on rick's investigation to be all that interesting . 
<s>  it's as if the film ran out of the guts to be really complex and original about a third of the way in , and decided to just fall back on an easy way out , and that just happens to mean that it has to become less and less credible . 
<s>  events become more and more proposterous , and by the end , the film has decided to rely on the worst offender in mysteries like this : the deux ex machina . 
<s>  that's where some outside intereference brings the film to a sudden conclusion and makes everything okay . 
<s>  this time , it's a hurricane , an out-of-control police car , and a big round ball that adorned the arena . 
<s>  what went wrong ? 
<s>  depalma and the screenwriter , david koepp , are extremely credible people in their respective fields , and have been known for bringing life and complexity to mysteries such as this . 
<s>  depalma , who idolizes hitchcock to death , has done many a film like this , such as his masterpiece , " blow out , " where a movie soundman uses movie elements to uncover a conspiracy piece by piece . 
<s>  but granted , depalma at least makes it intriguing to watch , what with his over-the-top shot set-ups , notably the beginning and a sequence where the camera pans over top of a bunch of rooms in the hotel , forgetting anything about boundaries . 
<s>  at least his direction makes up partly for it . 
<s>  then there's koepp , who showed such great ability at making a character's flaws come to life like he did in depalma's earlier " carlito's way , " a film that dove right into the life and past of its character and examined him extremely well . 
<s>  he can write a flawed character , but his rick santoro seems to be just a half-assed effort . 
<s>  he's flawed , and we can see redemption if the story wasn't so formulaic . 
<s>  a scene towards the end where he has to make a fatal decision is cheapened by the fact that his answer has no emotional buildup . 
<s>  he may as well have said the opposite of what he says ; it would have at least gone with what the character was like . 
<s>  this is the most disappointing kind of film because it promises intelligence and complexity , because it promises disection of a flawed character and perhaps even redemption , then pulls the rug from under us just as we were about to be convinced it would be able to go all the way . 
<s>  as i was watching the first half hour , i couldn't wait to see how the mystery would be unearthed , how many different perspectives he'd be given , and perhaps he'd have to make a choice between who's he has to believe . 
<s>  now there's a film . 
<s>  unfortunately , the film has two major deux ex machinas : one in the disasterous ending ; the other , about a half hour in when the film goes into autopilot and becomes a stale and recycled piece of crap we've seen all too much before , but never from someone like depalma . 
<s>  forgive the fevered criticism but the fervor of the crucible infects . 
<s>  set in 1692 at salem , massachusetts , the crucible opens with a group of teenage girls passionately singing and dancing around a boiling cauldron in the middle of a forest under the glow of a full moon . 
<s>  they beckon the names of men as the targets of their love spells . 
<s>  then one of the girls lets her hair down and sheds her clothes . 
<s>  not to be outdone in her quest to regain the attention of john proctor ( daniel day lewis ) , abigail ( winona ryder ) suddenly seizes a chicken , beats it against the ground and smears her face and lips with the fresh blood . 
<s>  taking even adolescent hormone surges into account , surely this chicken-bashing bit is a bit excessive , especially for prim puritan sensibilities ? 
<s>  surely to the puritan eye this is as close to a coven of witches as it gets ? 
<s>  the crucible errs from the beginning and arthur miller's name should be summoned for blame here for the addition of the above scene to his screen adaptation of his play . 
<s>  this is far from a harmless event , a bad start to an already shaky morality tale . 
<s>  the play describes the film's opening scene during tense exchanges that makes one wonder about the veracity of both accusation and reply , and this adds to the play's charged atmosphere . 
<s>  in the film , the opening scene becomes an unintentional pandora's box . 
<s>  not only is credulity stretched but abigail's obsession is unfortunately spotlighted . 
<s>  it positions the crucible more as a cautionary fable about obsessive and malevolent women than against witch hunts ; it will bring back the memory of a rabbit boiling away in a pot . 
<s>  not surprisingly , the nighttime forest frenzy does not go unnoticed and when two girls fail to wake the following morning , witches are invoked by those eager to blame . 
<s>  when the girls are questioned , their confession of guilt is accompanied with an announcement of their return to god and they are thereafter converted to immaculate witnesses , led lustfully by abigail . 
<s>  with alarming synchronicity our hormonally-advantaged girls zealously gesture and point accusing fingers at innocents , constant reminders that abigail's passion sets all this into inexorable motion . 
<s>  abigail seizes on this opportunity to rid herself of her rival for john proctor's love , his wife elizabeth ( joan allen ) , by including her among those accused of witchcraft . 
<s>  appropriately narrow-waisted and equipped with a distractingly white smile ( watch his teeth deteriorate much too quickly to a murky yellow ) , day lewis plays the dashing moral hero with an over-earnestness that longs to be watched . 
<s>  director nicholas hytner is guilty of encouraging day lewis' foaming-mouth fervour with shots where we stare up at proctor as if he was mounted on a pedestal for our admiration . 
<s>  otherwise , hytner's direction is unremarkable . 
<s>  ryder's performance as abigail is as consistent as her mood swings . 
<s>  her fits of frenzy are energetic enough but the quieter moments are less successful . 
<s>  abigail supposedly revels in her newfound power , but ryder fails at being convincingly haughty although there is much haughtiness to spare here . 
<s>  paul scofield is fine as the overzealous judge danforth , but the incessant moral posturings of all the characters along with the recurrent histrionics of the young girls pricks at the nerves . 
<s>  probably because she is the only refuge of restraint amidst all the huffing and puffing , allen's elizabeth comes out as the most sympathetic character . 
<s>  a scene near the end featuring a private conversation between the imprisoned elizabeth and john is undeniably powerful because for once we are given a reprieve from the moral bantering and the human consequences are revealed . 
<s>  unfortunately , when john's audience again increases to more than one his urge to pontificate returns and the human urgency of his situation is lost . 
<s>  it is clear that miller meant well but i do wish he did it with more delicacy and fewer diversions . 
<s>  his screenplay is an imperfect creature with the distractions coming out as loud as the message . 
<s>  the result is a clumsy muddle - i felt like the chicken from the opening scene , head ceaselessly banged with piousness too heavy-handed to be wholly believable . 
<s>  when the gallows beckoned , it was sweet release indeed . 
<s>  far from bewitching , the crucible tests the patience . 
<s>  one might expect a cathartic viewing experience walking into a new jean-luc godard film . 
<s>  after all , he was a founding member of the highly influential french new wave . 
<s>  he is also an esteemed film critic , lending intelligence and historical perspective to us in much of his writing . 
<s>  however , his latest creation , in praise of love , is possibly the most exasperating film experience of the year . 
<s>  the abstract concept on which the film is based had merit , to dissect love into the following four categories : meeting , physical passion , quarrels , and reconciliation . 
<s>  these four universal truths would be revealed through three different couples : young , adult , and elderly . 
<s>  it is edgar's ( bruno putzulu ) self-appointed task to capture these moments after a recent breakup , to define a central idea : " it's only when things are over that they make sense . " 
<s>  whether this project will end up a play , film , or opera remains undecided . 
<s>  the thesis is simple enough that , if played right , it could really hold sympathetic value for anyone . 
<s>  instead what ensues is an hour and a half of repetitive vignettes , the next scene no more engaging than the last . 
<s>  only once does any character utter something worthwhile , but by the time it happens you're so thoroughly bored you can easily miss it . 
<s>  but don't fret , it will surface again . 
<s>  you could easily sleep through whole sections of the film ( as some fellow critics did ) and wake up in a scene exactly like the one you nodded off in , not having missed anything worthwhile . 
<s>  but you hold hope for some time . 
<s>  the background music keeps you in a state of urgency , and even suspense , for the first few conversations . 
<s>  it's only after repeated failures to pay any of this off that you lose all hope . 
<s>  and with speeches like , " i am thinking of something , but i can only think of that something when i am thinking of something else , " how can you expect to hold anyone's interest ? 
<s>  to godard's credit , he certainly knows how to frame a scene . 
<s>  the black and white footage used for the first half of the film is starkly beautiful . 
<s>  watching edgar read while walking along a train track on a mountain makes you wish you had something to ponder along with him . 
<s>  and if this film had anything poignant to say , you would have , which makes you all the angrier at the numerous missed opportunities . 
<s>  the environments , be it city or country , are impeccably captured in crisp detail , but the script never complements them . 
<s>  unfortunately , godard also manages to pillage his photographic eye by randomly cutting to black numerous times within any given scene . 
<s>  sometimes these breaks are used for chapter headings , but these are even more cryptic than the spoken words . 
<s>  the second half is composed of nauseating hyper-color that often blurs the image . 
<s>  you suddenly feel like a doomed character straight out of scanners . 
<s>  the only scene that makes any sense is one that complains about the united states bastardizing history in the making of movies . 
<s>  steven spielberg is picked on in particular . 
<s>  while i'll grant that this does happen , and i tend to shy away from watching such garbage , it's still a pointless focus for a film that purports to articulate the specific qualities of couplehood . 
<s>  it just goes to show , an intelligent person isn't necessarily an admirable storyteller . 
<s>  the days of breathless are no more . 
<s>  america loves convenience . 
<s>  after all , we're the culture that invented the cell phone , the 24-hour atm , and my most beloved , the remote control . 
<s>  yet perhaps this time , with ghosts of mars , we have taken our love of convenience to far . 
<s>  ghosts of mars stars natasha henstridge as a tough as nails , pill-poppin' , martian cop , sent with her squadron to retrieve " demolition " williams ( ice cube ) from a remote mining town for trial back home . 
<s>  when she and her comrades , appropriately dubbed " the commander , " " the rookies , " and the guy with the cool accent discover the town's residents slaughtered , they are forced to team up with williams to escape from the remaining residents' head-chopping , alien-possessed clutches . 
<s>  filled with a lovely overuse of storytelling flashbacks , flashes-sideways , and viewpoint changes , ghosts of mars is a hapless mishmash of poorly constructed dialogue and ill-conceived action sequences . 
<s>  the only thing keeping this film from becoming an incomprehensible mess is the sheer idiotic simplicity of its story . 
<s>  ripped straight from the pages of a 1970s zombie movie , ghosts leaps from one convenient moment to the next , stopping only to kill the characters which are most convenient to lose . 
<s>  attempts at character interaction and development are rare and forced . 
<s>  most of these moments come off as kwik-e-mart wisdom , dispensed heartily around the slushee machine of life by the even-tempered streetwise hand of ice cube . 
<s>  with a gun in one hand and a dynamite cap in the other , cube reminisces about his street life , comparing the zombie-stomping fun to " me and my brother when we was kids . " 
<s>  apparently , crime in the bronx has gotten so bad that the residents have actually taken to ritually decapitating one another for entertainment . 
<s>  but , even in the film's darkest moments , fate conveniently lends a hand , supplying heavily armored transportation and easily accessible rifles and dynamite . 
<s>  yes , in the future , man may travel to space and conquer mars , but nothing beats a good stick of tnt . 
<s>  and as we all know , every police station , past , present , or future , keeps a healthy supply on hand . 
<s>  characters die , heads are lopped off , but they were only supporting roles anyway , so why should we care ?

<s>  explosions are fun . 
<s>  and even if the nukes don't get them , the conveniently placed dynamite packs on the train stolen from the set of the road warrior certainly will . 
<s>  in the end this film defines itself when our cop's tribunal pronounces , " is that all you have to tell us ? " 
<s>  for , indeed , john carpenter has run out of things to say , and has instead decided to use whatever is convenient to tell a ridiculously bad story . 
<s>  reindeer games is easily the worst of the three recent films penned by ehren kruger ( scream 3 and arlington rd are the others , each derivative in their own special way ) . 
<s>  the guy can't seem to write believable dialogue ( sample from reindeer games : " rule #1 : never put a car thief behind the wheel " ) , create multi-faceted characters , or even engineer coherent plots but he sure knows how to pile on numerous nonsensical twists and turns ( no matter if each one deems the actual story increasingly unlikely ) . 
<s>  his screenplay for reindeer games turns the tables on the audience so many times that watching the film becomes something of a punishment with no reward anywhere in sight . 
<s>  i can just envision kruger laughing behind his keyboard , " oh you thought my movie was gonna go here , f * ck you jack ass , take that twist , decipher this mother f * cker ! " 
<s>  it's almost as if the writer were angry at us for shelling out money to see his stupid movie . 
<s>  and why the hell would anyone want to invest time in a movie when the screenwriter keeps changing his own rules for no reason other than to congratulate himself on how damn clever he is ? 
<s>  auteur theory be damned ; it's kruger's " style " , not the director's that winds up on screen . 
<s>  kruger has obviously never paid much mind to the old chestnut " sometimes less is more " . 
<s>  and his numerous twists can't even claim to be originals ; arlington rd's ending is a direct steal from the much better alan j . pakula thriller the parallax view , and in reindeer games we get this ol' gem ; character incriminates themself by saying something they shouldn't know ( pronouns used to protect the gender of the " character " . . . grammar 
<s>  be damned ) . 
<s>   " how did you know that ? " 
<s>  the stunned protagonist asks , suddenly realizing that the character was in on the whole thing all along . 
<s>   . 
<s>   . 
<s>  since twist endings are currently so in vogue , and seeing as how kruger's screenplays usually come equipped with about three twists per ending , i guess it's no wonder why he works so frequently . 
<s>  he's quickly becoming miramax's mickey mouse ; the company has already signed him to work on several of their upcoming projects . 
<s>  this is appropriate considering that miramax ( which used to place their label on some of the most artistically daring films ) has quickly become a grindhouse for coddling foreign imports ( life is beautiful ) and freddie prinze jr . vehicles . 
<s>  their company's current logo could be " we ride the trends " . 
<s>  reindeer games stars ben affleck as rudy , a supposedly hardened criminal spending his days and nights behind bars with fantasies of pecan pies dancing atop his head . 
<s>  although affleck is given some barbed wire tattoos to insinuate bad assness , he plays the role like steve guttenberg preciously mugging through a police academy flick . 
<s>  affleck is such a puppy dog that it's impossible to believe he could survive in a harsh prison environment without becoming nearly everyone's bitch . 
<s>  the role itself is so badly written ( the character only grows balls when the plot calls for it ) , the twists so outrageous , and the directing so self consciously gritty that this is about as close to self parody as i can recall a recent " serious " movie getting . 
<s>  it may have been wiser had the film makers simply went all the way in that direction , casting jerry seinfeld as the hardened criminal and howard stern as the sniveling bad guy ( who's played here by gary sinise in yet another over the top villain performance ) 
<s>  james frain is nick , rudy's cellmate , a manslaughterer who's found a pen pal in the gorgeous ashley mason ( charlize theron ) . 
<s>  ashley is a prison groupie who sends nick many cheesecake photos of her though she's never seen one picture of him . 
<s>  which works out fine since the character is killed in a near-riot , and rudy ( who was to be paroled on the same day as nick ) takes his place , which leads to a sudden and very frenzied sex scene between ashley and rudy ( so frenzied it kinda looks like rape ) and a surprise visit from ashley's brother , gabriel ( gary sinise ) , who waltzes into their shabby hotel room flanked by his thuggish co-horts .

<s>  'rmd' is limited to a standard 4/4 tempo , not allowing for any emotional content whatsoever .

<s>  based on jim schutze's novelization of a true-life event , " bully " charts the story of a handful of disenchanted teenagers who , in 1993 , murdered their high school bully in cold , calculated blood . 
<s>  the film could have provided fascinating insights into what turned these aimless kids into premeditated killers . 
<s>  in the hands of controversial director larry clark ( " kids " ) , however , it has less to say about its subject matter and more to say about the filmmaker's pornographic proclivities . 
<s>  in terms of the incident and what provoked it , " bully " stirs up nothing new . 
<s>  the high schoolers are presented as a uniformly screwed up lot--bored with life , not much ambition , promiscuous , profane . 
<s>  the bully in question , bobby kent ( nick stahl ) , is certainly an unpleasant piece of work but he doesn't exactly tower over his colleagues in the pathological department . 
<s>  he hounds and harries and humiliates his " best friend " marty ( played by brad renfro ) and marty's girlfriend lisa ( rachel miner ) doesn't care for it at all and comes up with the idea of killing bobby .

<s>  there's no remorse--the next day they're talking about it as openly as a homework assignment . 
<s>  they did it because they wanted to , and because they could . 
<s>  what's most troubling about the film , however , isn't the unsettling subject matter and the matter-of-fact way these young people go about eliminating one of their own but the way in which clark is constantly distracted by his own material . 
<s>  not only is the nudity plentiful and graphic in " bully " but there's also an uneasy , exploitative feel to it . 
<s>  gratuitous crotch shots abound ( one of which makes the zipper cut-away in " there's something about mary " look like the height of subtlety ! ) . 
<s>  clark is so pre-occupied with his female ( predominantly ) leads that you forget , at times , what this movie is supposed to be about .

<s>  the conclusion of " bully " offers up literal snapshots of information about the sentences imposed on each of the protagonists for their involvement in the crime .

<s>  the plot is permeated with flashbacks , flash-forwards and what can only be described as random time-travel , without any evident purpose .

<s>  all through its production and into the early days of its initial , aborted pre-release publicity , hard rain bore the appropriate moniker of the flood . 
<s>  ultimately , however , paramount pictures , nervous that this movie would be confused with 1996's other , underperforming disaster films ( dante's peak , volcano ) , changed the title and shifted the release date by nearly a year . 
<s>  but , to paraphrase the bard , swill , by any other name , would smell as rank . 
<s>  no number of name changes can help this picture . 
<s>  it's not just about a disaster , it is a disaster . 
<s>  hard rain is the case of a movie that gets progressively worse with every passing minute . 
<s>  the best shot occurs during the opening credits , as the camera pans over the streets and byways of huntingburg , indiana as the water level slowly rises . 
<s>  the community , protected by an overworked dam , is being evacuated as the rain continues to pour relentlessly from the cloud-choked skies . 
<s>  from that moment on , it's all downhill . 
<s>  whatever initial entertainment value the film possesses has long since drained away by the halfway point . 
<s>  it takes forever to get to the end credits -- this is one of the longest-seeming 95-minute motion pictures i have recently endured . 
<s>  basically , hard rain is one extended , dull chase sequence punctuated by occasional shoot-outs . 
<s>  there's a lot of water , broken glass , gunfire , and explosions . 
<s>  it's all very routine and uninteresting because there aren't any real characters and the plot only occasionally makes sense . 
<s>  the film's conclusion is so preposterous that it's almost worth watching for the sheer masochistic enjoyment of seeing the monumentally idiotic way that the film makers decide to resolve the myriad subplots that are floating around . 
<s>  action films are supposed to become progressively more invigorating as they rush towards a conclusion . 
<s>  graham yost , the writer of both speed and hard rain , surely understands that principle . 
<s>  unfortunately , neither he , nor cinematographer-turned-director mikael salomon ( a far off place ) , applies it . 
<s>  the action in hard rain grows tedious through repetition . 
<s>  we see the same kinds of things -- speedboat chases , flood damage , shoot-outs , etc . -- over and over again . 
<s>  the movie constantly recycles about twenty minutes worth of material to pad the running time out to an acceptable movie length . 
<s>  the storyline gives us a number of paper-thin characters in contrived circumstances . 
<s>  there's tom ( christian slater ) , the one- dimensional action hero who works as a security guard driving an armored car full of cash . 
<s>  he and his partner , charlie ( edward asner , tv's " lou grant " ) , get stuck on a street that's rapidly turning into a river . 
<s>  a group of men , led by jimmy ( morgan freeman ) , arrive on the scene not as rescuers but as robbers . 
<s>  after charlie is killed in a shoot-out , tom hides the money , then runs .

<s>  there isn't any real acting in this film .

<s>  to wit , we present the disaster that is battlefield earth . 
<s>  a science-fiction opus starring the barbarino of the actors guild , battlefield earth should be shown only at maximum-security prisons when a prisoner is tossed in solitary for bad behavior . 
<s>  sci-fi is always a tricky beast : tight script , a good director , an ensemble cast of decent actors , and the ability to suspend even the most difficult of disbeliefs . 
<s>  battlefield earth fails at achieving even one of these attributes . 
<s>  here's the `plot . ' 
<s>  the year is 3000 . 
<s>  mankind has been become an endangered species thanks to the conquest of a race of aliens called the psychlos ( sounds like either the latest clown act from cirque de soleil or a white rap group ) . 
<s>  a small band of humans dwell in radioactive caves located in the rockies in fear of the `demons' who dwell in the cities below . 
<s>  the psychlos are strip-mining the earth for its resources and terel , played by travolta , is the head of security for the mining/slave base located in denver . 
<s>  a young rogue named jonnie goodboy tyler , played with dramatic flair by barry pepper , ventures from the safety of the caves into the city to uncover the truth about the `demons . ' 
<s>  he is promptly captured and taken to the alien base . 
<s>  after several attempts at escape , johnnie is placed in the middle of an underhanded subplot of terel's , involving circumventing gold from an exposed vein in the rockies to his own end . 
<s>  jonnie , assumed leader of the mining slave group , then manages to attain all psychlo and human intelligence through a learning machine terel forces him to use . 
<s>  then the story just runs along until jonnie teaches the rest of the humans the basics of trigonometry , the bill of rights , how to use a machine gun , and how to fly a harrier jet . 
<s>  the whole mess concludes with a big , loud , obnoxious gun-and-plane battle that had me praying for the end credits . 
<s>  roger christian , the director of this lumbering beast , must have rented dune , blade runner , planet of the apes , independence day , stargate , beastmaster , the airwolf episodes , the `v' miniseries , the matrix , and the omega man . . . 
<s>  and decided to steal every scene he could for battlefield earth . 
<s>  christian even shoots every scene in a weird dutch angle titled left or right for every frame of the movie ! 
<s>  and every scene in the movie ends with a middle wipe -- really . 
<s>  the psychlos reminded me of a cross between jamaican basketball players with bad teeth and bloated hands and klingon extras working the star trek convention circuit . 
<s>  travolta's acting hasn't been this bad since the experts or maybe perfect . 
<s>  jonnie goodboy tyler evolves into william wallace with lines like `you can have your freedom if you fight ! ' 
<s>  then there's the script : the film just never convinces you that the plight of jonnie in teaching his fellow humans to fight and `take back the planet' would be a difficult task to achieve . 
<s>  why ? 
<s>  because terel provides all the necessary tools to incite a revolt -- for no particular reason beside the fact that `humans are stupid . '

<s>  the recent onslaught of film noir that has popped up in multiplexes , with everything ranging from " l . a . confidential " to " palmetto " to " the big lebowski , " has proved to be an artistic commodity for veteran , talented directors . 
<s>  with this particular genre , directors are able to collate the sleazy underworld of the lower-class and the glamorous , opulent upper-class , while maintaining the noirish , ambiguous ambience , the staple of film noir . 
<s>   " wild things " could be classified as a black comedy , a sultry film noir or a plain ol' erotic thriller , but the one category it doesn't qualify for is that of a quality motion picture . 
<s>  overacted , overwrought and overlong , " wild things " is a confused mess , a movie that wants to have its cake and eat it too .

<s>  in spite of game efforts by kevin bacon and matt dillon , who manage to sustain straight faces throughout the ordeal , " wild things " not once jells in its eroticism , unpredictability , character motivation , sense of the world , plot , etc . there's not one redeeming quality in the picture that is not technical .

<s>  susan granger's review of " the watcher " ( universal ) 
<s>  just what we need : another lurid , trashy serial killer saga .

"

<s>  chris ellis , as spader's self-important colleague , is the only cast member who manages to be convincing .

<s>  ahh yes . 
<s>  the teenage romance . 
<s>  an attractive young cast is pitted into an unlikely scenario that could only happen in the movies , and in the end , the guy always gets the girl . 
<s>  and with the arrival of the breakout hit `she's all that' last year ( followed by a long catalogue of imitators including `10 things i hate about you' and `drive me crazy' ) , the genre previously on life support is once again a hot commodity . 
<s>  along now comes `down to you' . 
<s>  the folks at miramax are obviously trying to capitalize on the rabid `she's all that' craze with their latest project , which has the studdly freddie prinze jr . attached and all . 
<s>  only `down to you' doesn't have the ? unlikely scenario' mentioned above . 
<s>  it is an extraordinarily ordinary romance - a dull , unattractive teen comedy that sticks to the boring game plan that we're accustomed to . 
<s>  this is the kind of romance that only giggly 12-year old girls will find convincing . 
<s>  in strictly textbook fashion , college sophomore and aspiring chef al ( prinze jr . ) meets freshman artist imogen ( julia stiles ) . 
<s>  they hit it off like a couple can only in the movies . 
<s>  from here , it's the standard boy-meets-girl , boy-loses-girl , boy-drinks-entire-bottle-of-shampoo-and-may-or-may-not-get-girl-back story . 
<s>  the plot is conveniently assembled to suit the requirements of the main characters , who are frequently taking part in activities that . . . . 
<s>  well , only happen in the movies . 
<s>  fortunately , the cast of `down to you' has a certain appeal . 
<s>  freddie prinze jr . and julia stiles are an adorable couple , and when on screen together , they radiate the sort of warmth and charisma that the movie should have centered around . 
<s>  zak orth , as the newly realized porn star monk , shows an unmistakable flair with handling all of the film's intelligent dialogue . 
<s>  rounding out the impressive ensemble of young talent are shawn hatosy ( `the faculty' ) , selma blair ( `cruel intentions' ) and ashton kutcher ( tv's `that 70's shows' ) . 
<s>  even the fonz himself - henry winkler , the epitome of teenage angst and nostalgia - has a welcome role as al's dad , the host of the popular cooking program `chef ray' . 
<s>  maybe the concept of `down to you' looked good on paper to draw such a crowd . 
<s>  as a feature film , however , the finished product is bland and tasteless fluff with only an occasional whiff of cuteness to keep the gears from stopping entirely . 
<s>  perhaps worst of all , `down to you' is not funny . 
<s>  the jokes are drawn from obvious sources and the resulting humor is banal and uninspired . 
<s>  the characters on screen , often laughing at each other's goofy/embarrassing antics , seemed far more amused than the audience . 
<s>  even the giggly 12-year old girls had grown restless toward the end as they waited impatiently for the formula to run it's course . 
<s>  the one mildly clever segment featured winkler and prinze jr . in a fantasy sequence called `cooks' , a `cops' take-off in which the father and son would storm houses and cook a decent meal for ? needy' families ( with the assistance of a fully-armed swat team , of course ) . 
<s>  when this is the highlight reel , you know the remaining film could leave something to be desired . 
<s>  in order to make a teen comedy work , you've got to have characters that show something by way of depth and identity . 
<s>  `10 things i hate about you' actually featured characters who were more than walking flashcards , and the result was refreshing . 
<s>  no such luck with `down to you' . 
<s>  it's just a textbook romance where , despite absurd circumstances , everything is bound to work out in the end . 
<s>  and at the end of the whole clich ? d ordeal , the nicest thing you could possibly say would be ` . . . . 
<s>  only in the movies' . 
<s>   " virus " is the type of cliched , vacuous film that has been recylcled so many times before that you wonder why anyone would even bother putting work into making it . 
<s>  strangely enough , on the same mid-january weekend last year , another film was released like this , " deep rising , " about an ugly monster on a cruise liner . 
<s>  prior movies with the almost exact same storyline include 1989's " leviathan , " 1989's " deep star six , " and all four " alien " pictures . 
<s>   " virus , " in comparison , is a servicable thriller , well-made and produced , but since it doesn't include one moment of even remote originality or intelligence , it sinks under the weight of the water that the film was shot on . 
<s>  based on a series of comic books , " virus " concerns the crew of an ocean salvage tugboat , which becomes extremely damaged during a violent typhoon . 
<s>  after discovering that the boat is slowly sinking , ( un ) lucky for them , a huge ocean vessel that appears to be dead in the water turns up within the confines of their radar screen . 
<s>  once the team reaches the russian ship , they go on board to find that the place is seemingly deserted . 
<s>  after turning the power back on , however , there gradually are signs that something else is on the ship , and the electrical equipment is oddly working by itself . 
<s>  one survivor finally does turn up , nadia ( joanna pacula ) , who informs the suicidal and stern captain ( donald sutherland ) and one of the crew , kit foster ( jamie lee curtis ) , that a mysterious alien life form hit the santi mir space station which then was transported down to the ship , taking over the minds of all of the electrical machines and thinking that humans are viruses that should be completely wiped out . 
<s>  if " virus " sounds like all of the previously mentioned movies , you're correct . 
<s>  although the technical artistry is fairly impressive to bring the mechanical creature to life , the film itself doesn't appear to have a brain in its head . 
<s>  the film sticks so close to the worn-out conventions of the " creature " genre that it is amazing anyone would spend the money and time filming it when they could be making an original film . 
<s>  the actors are all very good and have all proven their acting abilities in the past , but they are sorely wasted here and do not really even have characters to play . 
<s>  in her second return to horror in the last year , jamie lee curtis once again proves to be a strong and resourceful heroine , but that is about it . 
<s>  although 1998's " halloween : h20 " was also a disappointment , at least she was given a few scenes to develop a character , unlike here . 
<s>  donald sutherland has fallen on hard times recently by starring in thoroughly disposable films , such as 1994's " the puppet masters , " although i just watched him in the superb 1978 sci-fi classic " invasion of the body snatchers , " where he was fabulous . 
<s>  the last of the three top-billers is william baldwin , but it is fairly hard to say if he is good or not in the picture , since he has nothing to do . 
<s>  basically , " virus " is another one of those films where a group of people walk around and investigate a space ship/ocean liner/haunted house until the deadly and equally grotesque and slimy creature pops up and kills them one-by-one . 
<s>  it is not the worst of its type , but it is far from one of the best , and when exactly are studios going to give up recycling such shameless and overdone plot gimmicks such as this ? 
<s>  as long as some of them keep making money , i suspect the answer is never . 
<s>  over 40 years ago , a japanese production company called toho introduced the land of the rising sun to gojira , a reptilian creature of immense proportions created by mankind's nuclear testing . 
<s>  partly flight of fancy , partly commentary on the exploitation of atomic power and weaponry , gojira emerged from the ocean to terrorize tokyo . 
<s>  a year later , gojira was marketed to the united states by adding three things : a new name , a dubbed english track , and raymond burr . 
<s>  as godzilla , the film took on the rest of the world . 
<s>  thirty years later , toho remade the classic film and once again took it to the american market by adding the same three things ( yes , including raymond burr ) and called it godzilla 1985 . 
<s>  now it's 14 years after toho's remake , and director roland emmerich has allowed the giant lizard to make an american first run . 
<s>  in emmerich's godzilla , matthew broderick plays dr . niko tatopoulos , a biologist who is called in to join other scientists in the south pacific already studying the existence of a radiation-induced super mutant which leaves footprints the size of livingrooms . 
<s>  when the mutant reptile suddenly appears out of the hudson river , tatopoulos and the rest of the team relocate themselves back to the states . 
<s>  meanwhile , tatopoulos's college girlfriend , audrey timmonds ( maria pitillo ) , works in new york city as an assistant to a big-time news reporter . 
<s>  she'd like to be a reporter herself , and when godzilla comes ashore , she figures this is her big break . 
<s>  of course , with the big guy running amok in the city , niko and audrey are bound to cross paths , and are joined by victor " animal " palotti ( hank azaria ) , audrey's trusty cameraman friend , and phillipe roche ( jean reno ) , an operative for the french government , whose nuclear testing started the whole problem in the first place . 
<s>  together they attempt to find and destroy the surprisingly elusive godzilla . 
<s>  with the resources of the most cutting edge special effects houses and the clout of one of the nation's premiere movie production companies , one would think emmerich could make a film truly deserving of the name godzilla . 
<s>  he didn't . 
<s>  right up there with the lost world , godzilla is one of the biggest disappointments in recent cinematic history . 
<s>  the plot is pretty much what we expect : the big dinosaur-like creature comes out of the water and starts smashing new york city , and it's up to our heroes to figure out why this thing is on its rampage and how it can be stopped , while the military makes futile attempts to bring the creature down . 
<s>  the script , however , is painfully bad . 
<s>  it's fraught with lines so corny , they don't even belong in b-movies , and includes many character actions which make you think , " you idiot , " or " you stupid girl . " 
<s>  i suppose when you've got a movie with a giant lizard loose in new york , any other semblance of reality goes out the window as well . 
<s>  why is it that godzilla topples some buildings by merely brushing against them , but is conveniently able to leap atop others ? 
<s>  why do helicopters have to follow godzilla by flying dangerously between buildings where they can lose sight of him , when they could more easily keep track of him by flying a little higher and in a straight line ? 
<s>  why do sidewinder missiles , which have small explosive warheads , blow up entire buildings when they miss godzilla ? 
<s>  why is a mission to bomb madison square garden carried out by three f-18 fighter-bombers , when flights of such aircraft are always comprised of multiples of two ? 
<s>  okay , maybe the last one was a bit nit-picky , but hey , i was on a roll . 
<s>  broderick is usually a good actor , but in this film he's weighed down by an unexciting character and an atrocious screenplay which seem to fight against him every step of the way . 
<s>  hank azaria does what he can , but don't expect to see development of any of the promise he showed in the birdcage . 
<s>  like broderick's , azaria's character is quite simply lacking in color . 
<s>  what really annoyed me was maria pitillo , who actually takes the bad script and makes it worse with her acting . 
<s>  casting must have been asleep on this one . 
<s>  the one bright spot here is jean reno , who oddly enough seems to fit well into a role which is often comedic , quite unlike what we've seem him do in the past . 
<s>  although his character is contradictory to the unfolding disaster , reno brings a style to the role of phillipe which makes him enjoyable . 
<s>  unfortunately , the same cannot be said of the other incongruities . 
<s>  the entire feel of the movie is tongue-in-cheek , and seems to pay comical homage to a dozen or so films that have come before it . 
<s>  this results in a significant amount of parody , which contrasts sharply with the threat of the monster , and ends up just producing a mess . 
<s>  most of the characters seem to be there for comic relief , and almost none are smart enough for the audience to take seriously . 
<s>  although emmerich obviously wanted to make a fun action picture , what good is it to sink millions into a cgi creature whose ferocity is undermined by the humans he threatens ? 
<s>  if we can't take the characters seriously , the threat they face is an empty one because we simply don't care what happens to them . 
<s>  godzilla simply pulls too many punches in its attempt to be a film more light-hearted than it should be . 
<s>  far be it from me to want to see more carnage in the theaters , but here's a behemoth running through the city ! 
<s>  there's bound to be a lot of casualties , but instead godzilla is afflicted with the after-school g . i . 
<s>  joe cartoon syndrome , where almost everyone seems to get out of harm's way just in time . 
<s>  in a couple of scenes , godzilla briefly breathes fire . 
<s>  none of the characters even remark upon this ability , nor is it used to any particular advantage by the filmmakers . 
<s>  it's as if the special effects people just wanted to show that yes , godzilla can do this , just like in the old movie . 
<s>  consider another punch pulled . 
<s>  through creative script writing , you can make a sequel out of just about any movie , but the final scene in this one doesn't just leave the door open , it opens into a hallway leading directly into a room where godzilla ii is waiting patiently . 
<s>  it made me want to gag . 
<s>  emmerich should have done away with 90% of the humor and in-jokes and played this one as a straight action film . 
<s>  with an intelligently written screenplay , godzilla could have been so much more . 
<s>  however , by confusing the viewer with a ton of add-ins and parodies , the movie ends up being something that just doesn't work . 
<s>  now if they only had raymond burr . . . . 
<s>  before the remake of psycho appears , we've got to suffer through this remake of an earlier hitchcock film , dial m for murder . 
<s>  as usual , hollywood has filled it with glitz and big name stars , and it all amounts to a loud sounding nothing . 
<s>  the film opens with emily ( paltrow ) and david ( viggo mortensen ) 'having fun' in an loft apartment .

<s>  mortensen agrees , but the murder goes awry , and the twists keep on coming as the film progresses . 
<s>  unfortunately , the film dosen't progress very fast . 
<s>  in fact , it moves like a tortoise with arthritis ( read : very , very s-l-o-w . ) 
<s>  the plot moves nowhere fast , and only becomes exciting in very short bursts . 
<s>  not too good for a 'thriller . ' 
<s>  also , the performances , apart from douglas , are below par . 
<s>  paltrow , showing immense talent in se7en ( 1995 ) and sliding doors ( 1997 ) is strangely stilted , even unconvincing , in this movie .
