<s>  perhaps her ancestors invested in some pompeii real estate . 
<s>  there are a couple of good things about this movie . 
<s>  the first is the scenery . 
<s>  there are panoramic shots of forests , lakes and mountains that are absolutely beautiful . 
<s>  the second is the special effects . 
<s>  they are the closest i've ever seen to a real pyroclastic eruption . 
<s>  but when elements which don't speak are going to be the best parts of your movie , you'd probably better rewrite the script . 
<s>  capsule : a ham-handed and over/underwritten morality play masquerading as entertainment , so muddled it doesn't even know what it's really advocating , if anything . 
<s>  a time to kill has been hailed as the best of the grisham adaptations , and it's easy to see why : it presents a strong , almost rancorously so , story ; it is full of good actors ( samuel l . jackson , matthew mcconaughey , sandra bullock , kevin spacey , charles dutton ) ; and it's ostensibly about some important social issue that we're all tangling with . 
<s>  it is not , however , a good movie , and all of the reasons i've listed above have something to do with why . 
<s>  right from the beginning , the movie is dead-set on stacking its deck as thoroughly and unrepentantly as possible . 
<s>  a pair of redneck whites , boozed and drugged out of their minds , kidnap a young black girl , abuse and rape her horribly , and leave her for dead . 
<s>  after their arrest , their father ( jackson ) takes an assault rifle and guns them down on the way to trial . 
<s>  mcconaughey is then drafted in as his lawyer , and the rest is somehow strangely predictable courtoom movie dramatics . 
<s>  the acting is not quite what it should be , given the cast we have . 
<s>  sandra bullock ( who is a good actress but not a serious one ) looks clueless ; spacey's accent switches itself on and off at random ( and he's given a totally thankless role to play as well , a role without an iota of depth ) ; and mcconaughey's role is stamped from the cardboard back of a cereal box . 
<s>  the most memorable role is donald sutherland's , and his is a bit part . 
<s>  i always consider it an index of a movie's desperation when it is able to present shocking and outlandish events , and somehow not have them generate an ounce of impact . 
<s>  there is one scene -- a riot outside the courtroom -- that should have created incredible tension , but winds up playing out like a textbook exercise on how not to deploy a scene like this . 
<s>  because the movie doesn't know what it's really about , it * can't * generate any genuine tension , and so it has to artifically inject tension through clumsy plotting . 
<s>  one of the ways it does this is by throwing in a whole subplot about a bunch of vicious kkk cross-burners -- which is tidied up so neatly that it borders on the nihilistic . 
<s>  i was reminded of the despicable betrayed , which tried to tart up a fundamentally empty story by injecting vile , graphic acts of racism as little more than an attention-getter . 
<s>  the movie immolates an enormous amount of its potential by making a few critical mistakes . 
<s>  first of all , the jackson character is not hard to judge ; there's no tension in his dilemma . 
<s>  he's self-admittedly guilty and should be sent to jail , no matter how moral his crusade . 
<s>  the old saw about how no court in the land would convict him , if he was white , is supposed to be the underlying theme of the movie , but it's never developed into an organic component of the story . 
<s>  it just sort of floats around on top while the movie grinds away furiously with its plot mechanics . 
<s>  another mistake is in motivational logic : by not having the two white thugs arraigned first -- or maybe tried and then dismissed from lack of evidence , say -- we have that much less empathy for jackson's character . 
<s>  i'm probably supposed to think that just because he had his daughter raped , we are * automatically * supposed to feel empathy for him , but that's precisely the kind of facile thinking that makes real justice impossible . 
<s>   ( see the virgin spring for more on that note . ) 
<s>  is jackson's character then simply insane ? 
<s>  that prospect isn't given terribly serious treatment either . 
<s>  one of the most aggravating things about coutroom movies is how little they seem to know about how the law works , or how lawyers get their information . 
<s>  mcconaughey's character makes an important slipup late in the movie , when one of his witnesses turns out to have been convicted of a capital offense . 
<s>  how did the prosecution get this information ? 
<s>  how come he didn't get it ? 
<s>  the whole way these questions get handled are symptomatic of the movie's way of dealing with complex legal and moral questions in cheap screenwriterly slam-bang fashion . 
<s>  this is the biggest problem : the movie isn't about jackson's character , or his dilemma , or this case , or any of its ( frequently interesting despite the porcine writing and direction ) characters . 
<s>  it's not ultimately about anything at all , except its stupid geared-down plot , which inches onwards in one unremarkable scene after another towards a totally contrived ending . 
<s>  at two and a half hours , the movie is overlong and drastically overwritten : there's endless stuff about things which ultimately add up to nothing , and no writing about the material that should really matter . 
<s>  it's all handwaving . 
<s>  the closing argument are also sneaky and underhanded , and underscored my suspicion that the movie is manipulative and unfair . 
<s>  it's not easy to make a movie about something . 
<s>  the other day i saw kurosawa's phenomenal rashomon , a movie that is really about the way people deal with truth and reality ( or don't ) . 
<s>  a time to kill is as empty and ponderous a movie as i've seen in a long time . 
<s>   " deep rising " gives you that sinking feeling both literally and figuratively : not only does the movie take place on a cruise ship slowly being immersed into the middle of the ocean by a squid-like menace , but the unfolding story is artificial , silly and almost completely derivative of countless other ( and , for the most part , better ) films . 
<s>  while dumb monster movies can at least be decent guilty pleasures -- take , for example , the schlocky mountain highs of last spring's " anaconda " -- " deep rising " has no tongue to put in its cheek . 
<s>  folks , we're only a month into the new year , and already here's a candidate for one of its stinkiest releases . 
<s>  most of the action takes place on the argonautica , a luxury liner in the middle of its maiden voyage ( uh-oh -- if these people had seen " titanic , " then maybe they'd have known to stay home ) when it's attacked by a giant , tentacled sea creature . 
<s>  the only survivors are slinky jewel thief trilian ( famke janssen ) , argonautica owner canton ( anthony heald ) and a few other crew members . 
<s>  a mercenary team , lead by resourceful captain john finnegan ( treat williams ) , board the argonautica looking for assistance after their own boat breaks down nearby . 
<s>  but what their search of the ship uncovers is something blood-soaked , hungry and not very helpful . 
<s>  the main problem with " deep rising " is its overt familiarity ; the movie makes absolutely no attempt to differentiate itself from most sci-fi/horror films in recent memory . 
<s>  the concept is " leviathan " meets " titanic , " with a dash of " speed 2 " thrown in for good ( or is that bad ? ) 
<s>  measure . 
<s>  this monster is equal parts " 20 , 000 leagues under the sea " and " the relic , " knows how to open doors like the raptors from " jurassic park " and even gets to expel a half-digested victim ( a neat effect , admittedly ) a la the giant snake in " anaconda . " 
<s>  some of the attack sequences are straight out of " jaws " and " alien . " 
<s>  a scene where the remaining survivors have to travel under water to escape death is right out of " alien resurrection . " 
<s>  there's even a jet ski chase like " hard rain . " 
<s>  and the list goes on . 
<s>  watching " deep rising " 's cast battle the beast is a murky chore in itself , because none of them have well-developed characters , nor do they seem to project even the slightest sense of fear when facing their enemy . 
<s>  williams is affable enough , but his finnegan just isn't believable . 
<s>  an interesting supporting cast is thoroughly wasted ; pretty famke janssen , best known as " goldeneye " 's killer thighs , is trapped in a forced romantic interest with williams , while kevin j . o'connor , as finnegan's mechanic , provides comic relief with screechy manic shtick that gets old fast . 
<s>  djimon honsou , who received raves for his performance as a noble slave in december's " amistad , " pops up in a brief part . 
<s>  he needs to stay away from the water . 
<s>  the movie's final shot is a groaner , as is the 11th-hour regurgitation of a subplot involving an on-ship saboteur . 
<s>  as if a cast deserving of their snack food-fate isn't bad enough ( when you taunt the monster , you're really asking for it ) , " deep rising " is a slow , stupid slog through a story without a single bright spot . 
<s>  and since we all know that the higher the casualty rate is , the closer we are to the end of the movie , rooting for this overgrown squid to swallow the whole ship isn't out of the question . 
<s>   " mandingo " has traditionally been seen as one of two things : either a much-needed revisionist look at slavery in the south , or in the words of film critic leonard maltin , " a trashy potboiler " that " appeals only to the s&m crowd . " 
<s>  actually , i think " mandingo " is a strange combination of the two , although it fails on both fronts . 
<s>  it's too trashy to be good drama , but too dramatic to be good trash . 
<s>  the story takes place on a dilapidated louisiana plantation run by crotchety old warren maxwell ( james mason ) and his son , hammond ( perry king ) . 
<s>  one day in new orleans , hammond comes across a slave trader selling a mandingo named mede ( heavyweight boxer ken norton ) . 
<s>  although the movie never explains it , a mandingo is simply the name for africans who come from the region of the upper niger river valley . 
<s>  according to the movie , mandingos were the rolls royce of african slaves . 
<s>  hammond pays top price for mede and has to fight off others in order to get him . 
<s>  hammond then spends his time training mede to be a fighter in money brawls with other slaves . 
<s>  meanwhile , hammond has married his cousin , blanche ( susan george ) , because she wants to escape her family and he is under pressure from his father to produce a grandchild . 
<s>  hammond , however , is happier spending nights with his " bed wench , " the derogatory name given to female slaves used by their masters for easy sex . 
<s>  it is quickly apparent that hammond , despite his overt racism , is more in love with his bed wench , a sensitive slave girl named ellen ( brenda sykes ) , than he is with blanche . 
<s>  hammond considers blanche tainted goods because he finds out on their wedding night that another man had " pleasured " her before he did . 
<s>  of course , it's fine that he's slept with numerous slave girls , but the fact that his wife , a " white lady , " had been with another man out of wedlock destroys his capacity to care for her . 
<s>  so blanche is usually left lonely and sex-starved while hammond is sleeping with ellen . 
<s>  blanche gets back at hammond by seducing the studly mede and bearing his child . 
<s>  hammond and his father cannot stand the idea that blanche has given birth to a half-black child ( although it's okay that ellen was pregnant by hammond ) , so warren kills the child by letting it bleed to death after birth , and hammond poisons blanche . 
<s>  hammond then finds mede , shoots him twice in the shoulder , and pushes him into a giant cauldron of boiling water . 
<s>  yes , you read right : the film ends with hammond getting his revenge by boiling mede alive . 
<s>  judging only by the plot , " mandingo " is pure sexploitation . 
<s>  the main purpose of the film seems to be getting as many blacks and whites into bed together as possible , with only the slightest commentary on what that would mean in 19th century southern society . 
<s>  when " mandingo " was released in 1975 , it was still a bit of a shocker to see miscegenation on screen in such a graphic detail ; this way the movie could revise cinematic history while attracting large audiences of curious voyeurs . 
<s>  dramatically , " mandingo " is weak and unfocused , and historically it's mostly confused . 
<s>  if one were to judge history by this film , it would be easy to walk away with the notion that the entire system of american slavery was based on sexuality , not economics . 
<s>  not once in the film do we see any of the slaves working , except for a few house servants . 
<s>  the men spend most of the time sitting around , while the sole purpose of a female slave seems to be free sex for the owner . 
<s>  there is historical basis in the notion that slave owners often slept with their female slaves , but " mandingo's " overwhelming emphasis on this aspect of slavery gives the movie the unpleasant taste of a cheap sex flick ( although there's plenty of violence -- fights , vicious beatings , shootings , and the aforementioned human boiling sequence -- thrown in for good measure ) . 
<s>  some tried to write off " mandingo " as a blaxploitation film , one of a number of quickly-made , low-budget films appealing to black sensibilities in the early seventies , but it's not that easy . 
<s>   " mandingo " was studio-financed by paramount pictures , and produced by dino de laurentiis , the grandiose italian producer behind such notorious productions as " the bible " ( 1966 ) , the remake of " king kong " ( 1976 ) , and the ill-fated " dune " ( 1984 ) . 
<s>  the director was richard fleischer , a veteran who was best known for several special effects-laden action movies including " 20 , 000 leagues under the sea " ( 1954 ) and " fantastic voyage " ( 1966 ) , as well as such superior suspense films as " the narrow margin " ( 1952 ) . 
<s>  the script , based on the supermarket best-seller by ken ostott ( and the subsequent play by jack kirkland ) , was penned by norman wexler , who had been nominated for an oscar two years earlier for his work on " serpico . " 
<s>  james mason , perry king , and susan george were well-known and respected actors ( mason already had three oscar nominations under his belt ) , and ken norton appeared to have a promising film career . 
<s>  so why is " mandingo " so bad ? 
<s>  a number of reasons , including the fact that all those experienced filmmakers behind and in front of the camera did a lousy job . 
<s>  wexler's script is pure poor hokum bordering on the offensive ; it combines stereotyped slave-talk ( " yessuh , massuh " ) , stereotyped southern white trash talk ( " fer whut're you gittin' outta bed ? " ) , and stereotyped contemporary militant black talk ( " if you see me hang , you gonna know you killed a black brother ! " ) . 
<s>  fleischer's direction is clumsy , especially during the fight scenes , and all the actors give weak performances , especially susan george whose constant shrieking finally becomes laughable . 
<s>  nevertheless , credit should be given where credit is due . 
<s>  despite its exploitative nature , " mandingo " was one of the first hollywood movies to take an alternative look at slavery . 
<s>  until then , there had been a kind of underlying racism in all hollywood films dealing with slavery . 
<s>  even classics such as " gone with the wind " ( 1939 ) can be seen as inherently racist by its glossing over the subject matter . 
<s>   " mandingo " reassessed the south , and showed that it wasn't all beautiful plantations , green fields , and pretty sunsets . 
<s>  but all this is constantly undermined by the film's negligible point-of-view -- it claims to see things from the black perspective , but the entire narrative focus is on the soap opera tales of the white owners . 
<s>  with a little more maturity and different handling , " mandingo " might have been an effective , worthwhile film . 
<s>  while it portrays many sensitive aspects of slavery , it never deals with them . 
<s>  the issues the movie brings up are worthwhile , but wexler's script refuses to move them beyond a surface level of trashily vicarious viewing . 
<s>  there is a great deal of potential in honestly exploring the nature of a sexual relationship between slave and owner , but " mandingo " never does it . 
<s>  steven spielberg touched on that same topic in " schindler's list " ( 1993 ) , by looking at a nazi officer writhing in inner turmoil because of his feelings for a jewish maid . 
<s>  the difference between that film and " mandingo " is that spielberg dealt with the situation in a fair , unexploitive manner that focused on the inherent human dilemma . 
<s>   " mandingo " is satisfied to simply show some skin , and because of that , its " trashy potboiler " nature overshadows any potential social good it might have accomplished .

<s>   " the doom generation " is advertised as a road trip movie about people who go around killing others who attack them , and also as another " teen angst " film ( one of the slogans is " teen is a four-letter word " - hardy har har ) .

<s>  the film's meaning is pretty easy to detect : that , you know , teens are so precious , and the world is such a horrible place , that when the two entities collide , there's a giant explosion of horrific violence . 
<s>  otherwise defined as " teen angst , " or the belief that being a teenager is a horrible thing and that the world is too bad for you .

<s>   " ladybugs " is a typical comedy that relies on three supposed guarantees : the pathetic team who beats the champs ; cross dressing ; and the presence of rodney dangerfield . 
<s>  this picture doesn't play like a comedy for children , so who is it aimed at ? 
<s>  and why is it told like a 91-minute sit-com instead of a feature film ? 
<s>  rodney dangerfield stars as chester lee , a total schmuck working at a huge corporation . 
<s>  he obviously doesn't have a lot of self esteem and thinks he has to kiss up to get ahead , which he does by volunteering to coach the company's girls' soccer team .

<s>  the happy bastard's quick movie review 
<s>  the concept of enjoying a stupid comedy is best realized as keeping it stupid , really . 
<s>  shift gears even once and the audience can be thrown miserably out of control . 
<s>  sadly , that is the case with kingpin , a film directed by the farrelly brothers , the duo that brought us there's something about mary and dumb and dumber . 
<s>  since the duo directed and didn't write the script , i can assume that's part of the problem . 
<s>  the story seems good enough : a pro bowler in the 1970's by the name of roy munson ( woody harrelson ) is sitting on top of the world . 
<s>  his popularity has gone through the roof and he's getting his career off the ground . 
<s>  then , however , he runs into ed mccracken ( bill murray ) , a rival bowler with hardly any real consideration for , well , anything . 
<s>  these two form an ill-timed relationship that involves risky betting , and , before roy sees it coming , ed's abandoned him and he's about to lose his hand in a bowling ball machine . 
<s>  forward seventeen years later , where roy has become quite the loser , complete with mechanical hand , torn-up car , and , of course , the occasional knocking up of the ugly-ass landlord to avoid paying rent for a while . 
<s>  however , he finds a glimmer of a hope upon a visit to a local bowling alley , where he runs into an amish kid named ishmael ( randy quaid ) , who has quite the bowling arm . 
<s>  with the kid's help , he figures he can be known again , particularly at the biggest bowling tournament rapidly approaching in reno , nevada . 
<s>  of course , the amish kid needs some coaxing , particularly when you consider , well , he's amish . 
<s>  this leads to some of the best comic scenes in the film , such as roy's process of removing horseshoes or milking the cow . 
<s>  finally , the duo get on the road and , along the way , pick up an additional helper- a beautiful hustler ( played by the gorgeous vanessa angel ) . 
<s>  the main problem i had with kingpin wasn't the fact it wasn't funny . 
<s>  in fact , it does have some rather hilarious scenes in it , such as the aformentioned above and roy's explanation of not having children ( something involving a cheese grater ? ) . 
<s>  but that's just it- scenes . 
<s>  there's a couple of really serious scenes that throw off the entire momentum of the movie , like the abuse angel takes from her hustler ex-boyfriend . 
<s>  i mean , was this really necessary ?

<s>  based on a novel by twilight zone writer richard matheson , what dreams may come is clunky , manufactured material doused with a extra load of sugar .

<s>  the catch phrase for disney's rocket man is one spoken by fred z . randall ( harland williams ) , the bumbling idiot computer programmer turned astronaut who continuously wreaks havoc everywhere he goes . 
<s>   " it wasn't me ! " he proclaims over and over as the aftermath of his stupidity brings about looks of disgust from the others . 
<s>  well when it comes to this movie being as horrible as it is , williams can't take all the blame , but he sure can't justify himself with his own simple tag line either . 
<s>  fred has dreamed of space travel since he was a young boy , turning the clothes dryer into a mock space shuttle and staring out wide-eyed at a poster of the earth . 
<s>  as a 30-year-old , fred hasn't grown up much , but at least he's somewhat closer to his goal , now designing astronaut software for nasa . 
<s>  when an astronaut for an upcoming mission to mars becomes injured , nasa calls on the person who knows the programming inside and out to fill the void . 
<s>   . 
<s>   . 
<s>  fred . 
<s>  yes , although he's an obviously klutzy moron , nasa doesn't think twice about throwing him into a rigorous training program so he can assist one of the most important events the space program , and time itself , has ever known . 
<s>  for the first part of the film , we watch as fred takes on the training program much like an amusement park . he laughs , he screams , but he never once breaks a sweat or views the preparation as anything more than child's play . 
<s>  his passive approach to the program eventually leads to many record-breaking feats , much to the dismay of cocky counterpart , mission commander captain overbeck ( william sadler ) , who once held the records . 
<s>  overbeck will regretfully accompany fred and two others to the red planet , one being astronaut julie ford ( the stupids' jessica lundy ) , and the other being a chimpanzee who is much more civilized than our antagonizing protagonist .

<s>  you know , standard kid movie material . 
<s>  almost sounding like a poor james stewart impressionist , williams is awful in his first starring role .

<s>  why ? 
<s>  because while he possesses the stupidness needed to pull off such a role , his performance is too understated and boring . 
<s>  classic comedic dunces were generally oblivious to their own idiocy . 
<s>  stan laurel , for example , was so innocent in all his trouble-making that we were immediately fond of him . 
<s>  peter sellers , as inspector clouseau , was so self-assured and confident that when he did something as simple as trip , it was humor at it's best . 
<s>  williams , on the other hand , can't garner the pity he needs to make us love him in all his anti-glory . 
<s>  as for the rest of the cast , including some bigger names in smaller roles ( beau bridges and shelley duvall ) , nobody is worth watching whatsoever . 
<s>  this is just another example of the fast-food equivalent of cinema : mass-produced , less than mediocre , over priced , and hard to stomach . 
<s>  giving it one-and-a-half stars is * extremely * generous , but even i'll admit to laughing a few times . 
<s>  the amazing thing is that even in a theater packed with little kids , laughter was something rarely heard - even from the children ! 
<s>  i must admit that it gave me more respect for the kids when they didn't crack up over every little thing . 
<s>  then again , maybe they were asleep . 
<s>  some people might think critics are harsh on kid movies , claiming adults aren't the targeted audience and therefore aren't meant to , and won't , enjoy them . 
<s>  sadly , it's also true that kids will enjoy almost anything if it's presented right . 
<s>  a two-hour still shot of a dog with a cartoonish voice over could entertain a lot of toddlers out there , but would that make it as artistic as beauty and the beast , which could easily do the same thing ? 
<s>  and saying that a parent's perspective isn't important is quite a poor theory to have when they're the ones who take the kids to these films in the first place . 
<s>  based on the novel set in 1914 by joseph conrad , victory spins a tale of a pair of lovers , heyst ( william dafoe ) and alma ( irene jacob ) , who seek refuge on heyst's isolated island . 
<s>  however , their idyllic world begins to crumble upon the arrival of mr jones ( sam neil ) , martin ricardo ( rufus sewell ) and their servant , pedro ( graziano marcelli ) , who have come to steal heyst's rumoured plunder . 
<s>  while the novel is largely complex in characterization , the film sadly transposes conrad's characters into lacklustre leads , the most disappointing being heyst himself . 
<s>  conrad's heyst adheres religiously to his late father's ways of detachment and isolation . 
<s>  his ascetic lifestyle is thrown into question when he meets alma , a helpless orchestra girl who charms him with her voice . 
<s>  the struggle to embrace the arrival of alma into his solitude , however , is lost in mark peploe's ( director and writer ) diluted version of heyst . 
<s>  without properly establishing the crucial details of heyst's character , all that is left of conrad's main character is a very shallow treatment of his internal conflict between detachment and human involvement . 
<s>  on the one hand , actualizing the subtext is a mammoth task ( though not impossible ) , but on the other hand , dafoe's flat acting cannot be excused as an attempt at stoicism . 
<s>  in the end , we are supposed to witness heyst renounce his philosophy and finally come to an understanding of what it is to love another . 
<s>  the final transformation , while perceptible , lacks the cathartic revelation which is undeniable in conrad's novel . 
<s>  its absence in the film is unforgivable . 
<s>  the film seems more concerned about moving the plot along when so much has yet to be said about the relationship between the two complete strangers . 
<s>  alma is supposed to have overcome great emotional barriers in the relationship , namely heyst's underlying philosophy of detachment , which heyst himself grapples with . 
<s>  the struggle against heyst's ignorance of true human involvement accounts for much of the greatness of alma's love for him . 
<s>  jacob , fair-skinned , gentle and yet passionate , handles the role with precision , detailing nuances where possible . 
<s>  unfortunately , she is let down by a superficial script . 
<s>  the couple's relationship develops too hastily , leaving all subtlety effaced and replaced with a blatant show-and-tell approach . 
<s>  all we know of the characters are mostly explained by their lines alone . 
<s>  this is unsatisfactory when so much of the turmoil experienced by the two stem from their buried thoughts and emotions . 
<s>  the sketchy handling of their relationship stands out as sorely as dafoe's american accent ( an inappropriate one since heyst spent most of his life in london ) . 
<s>  the other characters such as schomberg ( jean yanne ) , the owner of a hotel , and mr jones ( sam neill ) , also fall short of conrad's meticulous characterization . 
<s>  while schomberg should have been more menacing and vindictive , mr jones should have been portrayed as something more of an enigma . 
<s>  sam neil's caricature of a slightly stout , effeminate and soft-spoken gentleman-at-large nullifies the effect intended by conrad who describes mr jones as " an insolent spectre on leave from hades , endowed with skin and bones and a subtle power of terror " . 
<s>  poor characterization aside , kudos goes to rufus sewell for his excellent portrayal of ricardo , secretary to mr jones , a reckless ruffian capable of murder . 
<s>  sewell , with his cockney accent and large expressive green eyes , becomes the true terror of the unholy trinity , masterminding deceitful plans behind jones' back . 
<s>  at the same time , we are entertained by the foolhardiness of his plans . 
<s>  despite the authentic setting and marvellous cinematography by bruno de keyzer , very few images are left behind for us to savour after the film has ended . 
<s>  sourabaya and its surrounding islands and volcanoes may have their charm , but mean nothing once the film fails to capture the essence of an epic , which is what victory deserves to be . 
<s>  the delicately inter-woven complexities in the love story are lost to an inadequate production . 
<s>  at the end of the film , we are told that perhaps alma's victory was in teaching heyst how to love . 
<s>  a hollow victory indeed .

<s>  chill factor is a carbon copy of speed with one notable exception : instead of a speeding bus , we now have an ice cream truck . 
<s>  the truck is driven by arlo ( cuba gooding jr . ) and mason ( skeet ulrich ) , who have been instructed by a dying scientist to transport a deadly chemical weapon to a military base by the name of fort mcgruder . 
<s>  this particular weapon ( nicknamed `elvis' ) must be kept below a temperature of 50 degrees , or else the shockwave will goo-iffy everything in a mile radius . 
<s>  that would be pretty nasty . 
<s>  the power of elvis is revealed in the opening scene , as dr . richard long ( david paymer ) conducts a test on an isolated tropical island . 
<s>  long accidentally melts 18 soldiers and defoliates virtually the entire island , due to an enormously miscalculated safety distance . 
<s>  the commanding officer , general brynner ( peter firth ) , is sentenced to 10 years in prison for the murder of his troops . 
<s>  upon his release , the general is intent on tracking the good doctor down , snatching elvis , and selling the weapon to the highest international bidder . 
<s>  protecting the fate of the world is a drifting hamburger flipper ( ulrich ) and a feisty ice cream delivery man ( gooding jr . ) , who must elude brynner's men and get elvis to safety at fort mcgruder . 
<s>  all the while , of course , they must keep the weapon below 50 degrees . 
<s>  this proves to be tricky . 
<s>  among the wild adventures arlo and mason partake in is a trip down a tree-covered mountainside in a boat , and a fist fight on top of a moving vehicle . 
<s>  they also crack a few dozen witty retorts that we are supposed to find amusing . 
<s>  to put it simply , i'll use a clever pun : chill factor should be put on ice . 
<s>  director hugh johnson has mixed elements from speed , broken arrow and the lethal weapon series to create a lifelessly bland cocktail of a chase movie . 
<s>  when there is some occasional action , the audience seems oddly detached from it . 
<s>  perhaps that's because we've already waded through a pool of clich ? s and boring dialogue ; all material that's been used before , and with a lot more spice . 
<s>  take the villains , for example . 
<s>  they are typical stereotypes of every terrorist that has ever walked the silver screen . 
<s>  they speak lines that have been recycled profusely from one movie to the next , divulge important plot details while holding their enemies at gunpoint , and act in very predictable ways . 
<s>  the tag-team of gooding jr . and ulrich sounds much more exciting than it is . 
<s>  frankly , i'm not sure i can accept cuba as an ice cream man . 
<s>  i suppose it's better than him dressed like a giant hot dog , selling jumbo frankfurters on a street corner . 
<s>  gooding displays one single emotion in this movie , which is frequently on display in lines like `i'm gonna get on yo ass like last year's underwear ! ' and the incessant sputtering of `oh , sh * t ! ' 
<s>  this is virtually the same character he played in jerry maguire and as good as it gets . 
<s>  but where gooding was once an exciting actor , he now seems dull and endlessly monotonous . 
<s>  at least he's a bit more captivating than ulrich , who has all the film's worst dialogue , but does nothing noticeable to enliven his character . 
<s>  the supporting cast , which includes every personality you expect to pop up , is also wasted . 
<s>  to be fair , there are a few brief moments of serviceable action . 
<s>  and i did chuckle a few times . 
<s>  one example is when ulrich ( an employee at `darlene's diner' ) is at the counter when brynner walks through the door . 
<s>  `you own this place ? ' 
<s>  the general asks . 
<s>  `yeah , ' ulrich says . 
<s>  `they call me darlene . ' 
<s>  these little tidbits of humor are ( mainly ) welcome in this weak , disappointing wreckage of an action film . 
<s>  as a speed clone , it could have benefited from a lot more suspense and perhaps ( god forbid ) even some decent writing . 
<s>  sadly , i walked away from chill factor only wondering how much fun it could have been . 
<s>   * * * warning - the following review contains spoilers * * * 
<s>  cast : gary sinise , don cheadle , connie nielsen , jerry o'connell , kim delaney , tim robbins , elise neal , jill teed , jody thompson , bill timoney written by : jim thomas , john thomas and graham yost directed by : brian depalma running time : 115 minutes 
<s>  the first big event movie of 2000 turns out to be anything but . 
<s>  gary sinise stars as an astronaut who is removed from a mars mission when his astronaut wife , maggie ( kim delaney ) , becomes ill and passes away . 
<s>  don cheadle is then given the mission along with a russian couple and a young hotshot . 
<s>  when a strange whirlwind shot from the top of a mars mountain range attacks the crew of the mission , sinise and robbins convince their superior to let them , neilsen , and o'connell perform a rescue mission for whatever crew might be remaining . 
<s>  what they discover on the surface of the planet will dramatically change their lives forever ( although no one watching the film will come away profoundly affected ) . 
<s>  before i ever saw the film , i was aware of the promotional campaign with dr . pepper . 
<s>  every time i would see a bottle of the soft drink , the mission to mars logo was emblazoned upon it . 
<s>  little did i know that the plot would be taking a back seat to the product placement of the drink and several other products . 
<s>  dr . pepper saves the day at one point , and a dream sequence/flashback features jerry o'connell shoving m&m's in our face . 
<s>  these are but a couple of the ridiculous examples of product placement scattered throughout the film . 
<s>  clich ? s are also the order of the day with mission to mars . 
<s>  dialogue and character motivations are all lifted directly from countless other science fiction films that have all done it better and with more style ( even independence day , which lifted all of it's premises from other sci-fi films was better than this film , and i don't like independence day ) . 
<s>  films like 2001 : a space odyssey , the abyss , and close encounters of the third kind are all blatantly stolen from ( and poorly at that ) . 
<s>  there is even a sequence where a rover is traveling through a canyon , and i couldn't help but whisper " u'tinni " to myself and wait for a jawa to quickly hide in the rocks before the rover could get a glimpse of it . 
<s>  this film also features one of my all-time least favorite movie clich ? s : the " he would have wanted you to have this " moment , where one character gives another a trinket that yet another character is established as constantly having ( and is usually made fun of by the character who ends up getting all sappy over it later on ) . 
<s>  scenes like these always bother me when they come out of nowhere in regular films , but in a film as clich ? ridden as this , it is particularly irritating . 
<s>  ennio morricone's music is usually considered to be some of the best stuff in the projects he works on , but here it is dreadfully overbearing . 
<s>  his music sounds like it came straight out of a vincent price movie in certain scenes . 
<s>  at other times his music is unbearably over-dramatic . 
<s>  one sequence involving a daring spacewalk rescue is given a particularly cheesy sting when it is discovered that the grappling hook device used for the rescue won't reach its intended target . 
<s>  mission to mars is push button filmmaking to the greatest extreme . 
<s>  events are set into motion that are obvious to anyone who has ever seen a movie and seem like they are just there to evoke an emotional response in the audience . 
<s>  we are apparently supposed to be upset that tim robbins character removes his helmet in deep space and kills himself to save his wife , but i felt extreme boredom coupled with a twinge of disinterest . 
<s>  what makes it all worse is that fact that there is no real reason that robbins' character needs to turn himself into a popsicle , except to invoke an emotional response ( i could think of at least one way to save him , and the nasa clowns in this film are supposed to be " smarter " than i am ) . 
<s>  during the finale , when we are finally introduced to the translucent , conehead , kitty-faced aliens that we ostensibly sprung from , we are presented with some of the most ridiculously cartoonish cgi ever put to film ( just slightly worse than the plane crash at the end of air force one or the hell scenes in spawn ) . 
<s>  a brief history lesson about " where we came from " is proffered , then sinise is whisked away to be with " the rest of our people " ( he does this because his late wife proclaims in a video he watches early on that " this is a chance to step foot where no one else has " ) . 
<s>  >from the press i've been seeing this film receive , it is apparent that mission to mars will be dying a quick death at the theater . 
<s>  i'm sure the first weekend or two will be huge , but once word gets out people will stop going . 
<s>  let's just hope the upcoming red planet is better than this and isn't hurt by the negativity this film is generating . 
<s>  i'd venture to say it won't be worse than this waste of time .

<s>  retrospective : city of the living dead ( 1980 ) 
<s>  a film review by mike watson copyright 1997 mike watson 
<s>  i once heard someone describe the films of italian schlock horror director lucio fulci as " dim-witted " . 
<s>  and by golly , just about all other words fail me when confronted with a dog like city of the living dead . 
<s>  although the late fulci managed some rather good thrillers in his career , this is not one of them . 
<s>  two points in the movie's favour - the impressive camerawork of sergio salvati and occasionally evocative score by fabio frizzi - keep things from falling totally into the abyss , but by and large city of the living dead is a failure . 
<s>  and like most cinematic failures , it comes down to bad writing , dumb performances and lousy direction . 
<s>  the story starts in new york when , during a seance , a medium ( katherine mccoll ) sees a vision of a priest hanging himself in the town of dunwich , massachusetts . 
<s>  for reasons we won't go into here , this opens the gates of hell which must be closed by all saints day or the dead will rise and walk the earth . 
<s>  the medium apparently dies of fright during the seance , but awakens in her coffin in the graveyard the next day and is rescued by a crusty old journalist ( christopher george ) . 
<s>  that scene in itself is a howler : why would you bust open a coffin with a large pick axe when you know someone is alive inside ? 
<s>  and don't cadavers have various things stuffed in them and drained out of them before they're buried ? 
<s>  anyway , off the two of them go to dunwich to save the world , where various grisly goings-on are already happening as all saints day approaches . 
<s>  fulci's graphic gore is in evidence once again , but here it only serves to further highlight the film's flimsy script and plodding direction . 
<s>  the dialogue , in all manner of speaking , is unspeakable . 
<s>  not bad in the quotable sense , like an ed wood film , but bad in its sheer dullness or blatantly obvious " lets explain the plot " type approach . 
<s>  mccoll doesn't have a clue who her character is : deadly serious one minute , frivolous the next , she at times is genuinely hard to watch . 
<s>  and the geezer ( the actor's name escapes me ) who plays the town psychiatrist becomes even harder to stomach than mccoll as the film progresses . 
<s>  christopher george's performance is salvageable , but he gets his brains ripped out in the end by a zombie and we don't care . 
<s>  in fact we don't care for anyone in city of the living dead , though in other fulci films that hasn't mattered so much when he was on form as a stylist and an ideas man , as he was in the beyond . 
<s>  as a director , some of fulci' idiosyncrasies are incredibly silly and annoying here . 
<s>  he constantly uses extreme close-ups of people's eyes , a ridiculous technique which suggests an attempt to convey the emotion that his dialogue and actors aren't capable of . 
<s>  and despite some gruesome violence , he barely manages a single scare in the entire film . 
<s>  long-time collaborator fabio frizzi , talented but always erratic , offers a patchy soundtrack that veers between eerie , gothic death marches and woefully inappropriate electro-pop that's quite frankly embarrassing . 
<s>  fulci's other films of this period may be flawed - house by the cemetery , the beyond , the black cat - but they are nonetheless films with more inspiration , atmosphere and better dialogue than this turkey . 
<s>  for completists only . 
<s>  you know the plot : a dimwit with a shady past is seduced into committing a crime only to be double-crossed by a fatal femme . 
<s>  in " palmetto , " the dimwit is harry barber ( woody harrelson ) , a reporter who's just been released from prison ( he was framed by the gangsters and corrupt officials he was investigating ) . 
<s>  enter la femme : rhea malroux ( elisabeth shue ) , the sexy young wife of the richest man in palmetto , florida ( rolf hoppe ) . 
<s>  she and her stepdaughter odette ( chlo ? sevigny ) have a plot to extort 500k from the old man : harry will " kidnap " odette . 
<s>  after groping both women , harry agrees . 
<s>  as everyone except harry can see , he's being set up as a fall guy . 
<s>  sure enough , before long , harry has a dead body in his trunk and the cops on his tail . 
<s>  his brother-in-law ( tom wright ) , an assistant da , has hired harry to be the press liaison for the case , so harry gets a front row seat for his own manhunt ( and we get to watch him sweat-literally ) . 
<s>  there are several plot twists , of course-a couple of them even took me by surprise . 
<s>  apparently every woman in palmetto is a raving horndog , and they're on harry like he's the only bone in the kennel . 
<s>  shue vamps so broadly that i expected tex avery's wolf to show up . 
<s>  her incredible performance in " leaving las vegas " seems to have been a fluke . 
<s>  here , she could easily be mistaken for melanie griffith . 
<s>  shue's character is supposed to be a savvy schemer but she comes off as a brainless bimbo . 
<s>  in addition to shue and sevigny , the kennel includes gina gershon ( who filled the dimwit-with-a-shady-past role in " bound " ) as harry's girlfriend nina ; when harry gets out of jail , she licks his face ( now there's a horndog ) . 
<s>  the parts are so overplayed that with a little push " palmetto " could have been an over-the-top parody of film noir a la " romeo is bleeding . "

<s>  starring milla jovovich , who is predominantly unconvincing as the heavenly messenger accused of being a witch , `the messenger : the story of joan of arc' is a disjointed and overblown historical re-enactment that prevails merely as a bloated mistreatment of the famous legend . 
<s>  besson ( who's previous work includes the hyperactive sci-fi `the fifth element' ) perhaps entrusted a bit too much faith in ex-wife jovovich , because in `the messenger' , the actress is drowning in a pool of her own inexperience .

<s>  a timeless epic it is not . 
<s>  besson is hesitant to abandon his unique and flashy style , and the story behind `the messenger' is not entirely suited to his demands . 
<s>  on the shoulders of besson's choppy and unexciting direction , the film dissipates into an uninspiring hodgepodge of poorly executed battle sequences and bizarre imagery . 
<s>  there is no human exploration into the character of joan ( or jeanne ) . 
<s>  jovovich merely rambles on about the power of god when we have little or no insight into her visionary objective . 
<s>  jovivich's unsatisfying portrayal only helps lead to the realization that besson sees jeanne as a piece of spiritual cardboard . 
<s>  she is just another special effect in this continuous visual feast . 
<s>  jovovich does have a few isolated moments of sheer power , but mainly , she looks lost . 
<s>  quite frankly , i don't know of any actress who could successfully navigate her way through `the messenger' without a major fumble .

<s>  faye dunaway plays charles' overbearing mother-in-law , and dustin hoffman appears over two-hours into the story as a character dubbed ? the conscience' . 
<s>  all three actors juggle limited screen time , although malkovich is uncharacteristically awful . 
<s>  the battle scenes are extremely bloody , but with the presence of such jittery camera work , they capture none of the excitement or finesse of something like `braveheart' . 
<s>  there's a particularly graphic and unsettling scene early on , when jeanne ( as a young girl ) watches in horror from a closet as her older sister is murdered and then savagely raped by a bloodthirsty english soldier . 
<s>  even his fellow troopers are petrified . 
<s>  `the messenger' is also strictly a 90's update on the classic story . 
<s>  almost too 90's , it seems . 
<s>  there's gratuitous use of the f-word and a barrage of slang terms like `she's nuts ! ' 
<s>  sprinkled throughout the screenplay . 
<s>  i was half-expecting jeanne to invite her homeys to come chill in her crib , but it never happened .

<s>  if it was visual excellence that besson was striving for , then he achieves his goal .

<s>  and there isn't much depth to begin with !

<s>  in fact , with the exception of the stark black-and-white credits , snatches of baroque music on the soundtrack , and many , many grainy tracking shots down lavishly-decorated corridors , there's none of kubrick's trademark brilliance in this film . 
<s>  it doesn't help that the story , as delivered , is ridiculous . 
<s>  cruise and kidman , who bring little more than marital torpor to the project , play well-to-do new yorkers bill and alice harford . 
<s>  he's a doctor and she's an unemployed art gallery director and they share a central park west address . 
<s>  at an opulent party hosted by their friend victor ziegler ( pollack ) , alice gets a little tipsy and starts dancing with a jeremy irons-like hungarian , who's singularly determined to get her in the sack . 
<s>  bill , too , is seen arm-in-arm with a couple of models before he's pulled away to deal with an overdoser . 
<s>  back home , bill and alice smoke a little pot before alice's aggressive jealousy kicks in . 
<s>  as retribution , she confesses to her husband that she once had deep feelings for a naval officer she eyeballed at a hotel where she and bill once stayed . 
<s>  this hurtful admission sends bill into a tailspin ; he pounds the streets of the village in his heavy black overcoat struggling with black-and-white images of alice in the grip of a horny midshipman . 
<s>  it's all way too much for him . 
<s>  for revenge , bill almost has sex with a hooker . 
<s>  he almost has feelings for a underage girl he sees in a costume store . 
<s>  then he almost does the hooker's roommate . 
<s>  and he's almost involved in an overblown rococo orgy when an old college chum of his tips him off to a mysterious , password-protected party where everyone wears masks and " the women are incredible " ( i . e . , naked ) . 
<s>  this " erotic " set piece , a cult-ish bacchanal complete with chanting , incense , and lots of strategically-placed partygoers covering up the dirty , might impress the likes of hugh hefner , but it's a lot less shocking than it's intended to be . 
<s>  what's the big deal ? 
<s>  bill doesn't exactly * do * anything ( other than throw his money and credentials around ) , and alice only ever lusted in her heart . 
<s>  whoop-dee-doo . 
<s>  still , they make up at the same agonizingly slow pace--was kubrick , notorious for multiple takes , paying them at an hourly rate ? 
<s>  even geniuses have their bad days . 
<s>   " eyes wide shut " just happens to be kubrick's bad day , an unerotic , disappointing , and altogether pointless end to an otherwise memorable career . 
<s>  by starring in amy heckerling's " clueless " two summers ago , alicia silverstone proved she wasn't just another pretty , pouty ingenue , showing a buoyant comedic craftiness that blew all previous jobs -- namely a stint as the aerosmith girl and a silly turn as the lethal lolita of " the crush " -- out of the water . 
<s>  her only work since that 1995 gem has been in june's " batman & robin , " where she overcame the underwritten role of batgirl . 
<s>  now , she's the star and producer of " excess baggage , " a hopelessly phony film that demonstrates how an ill-composed story can drag an otherwise solid performer down to its level . 
<s>  silverstone's emily t . hope is stuck with a billionaire father ( jack thompson ) who neglects her emotionally . 
<s>  in an outlandish plan to gain his affection , she fakes her own kidnapping -- emily uses an electronically disguised voice to call her dad and set a pricey ransom , ties her legs together and mouth shut with duct tape and locks herself in the trunk of her bmw . 
<s>  but before the police can " rescue " her , professional auto thief vincent roche ( benicio del toro ) jimmies the locks , hot-wires the engine and makes off with both the car and emily , who's still trapped in the back . 
<s>  when vincent discovers emily , the two don't exactly hit it off -- she annoys him , he annoys her , and at the advice of his slimy car salesman partner ( harry connick , jr . ) , he decides to drive her out to the middle of nowhere and leave her there . 
<s>  along the way , of course , they get into a whole heap of trouble , and come to realize that being together is the only way to get out of their sticky , felony-studded situation . 
<s>  it doesn't help matters that emily and vincent are being trailed by cops , crooks and even her shady uncle ray ( christopher walken ) , who's wise to his niece's ploys for attention and has mafia connections . 
<s>  for at least a half-hour , " excess baggage " bounces along fast and efficiently . 
<s>  during this time , emily and vincent sport engaging personalities as well as a nice role-reversal twist -- she's an awfully aggressive , combative victim and he's quite the aloof , seemingly vulnerable captor . 
<s>  but once it's past its set-up , the situation suddenly becomes uninvolving as the story tries to be too many things at once . 
<s>  a road movie , a teen comedy , a mob thriller , a drama about family relationships -- you name the cliche and " excess baggage " likely covers its territory . 
<s>  of course a romance develops between the two leads , but it all seems forced , and thus characterization is manipulated to cause the finally happy outcome . 
<s>   " do you like my tummy ? " 
<s>  emily coos to vincent at one point in the film . 
<s>  huh ? 
<s>  did i miss something ? 
<s>  the hard-edged , foul-mouthed grrrl is suddenly gone and replaced with a pair of batting goo-goo eyes . 
<s>  then again , " excess baggage " becomes so weak in so many areas that the personality transplant is not a complete surprise . 
<s>  a supporting cast attempts to do what they can with colorful but empty secondary roles , but the movie isn't game enough to use them all and therefore seems overcrowded . 
<s>  motivations keep shifting , resulting in an often confusing narrative . 
<s>  scant existing story background confuses matters even worse and adds to the growing list of unanswered questions . 
<s>   " excess baggage " has too many characters , too much plot and juggles with one arm behind its back and a remaining shaky hand . 
<s>  i loved silverstone's turn in " clueless " as an aloof , pampered beverly hills matchmaker inspired by jane austen's " emma . " 
<s>  looking back at the skill she displayed for comedy there , it's simple to justify any high expectation or enthusiasm that i had mustered for " excess baggage . " 
<s>  sadly , however , " excess baggage " is no " clueless . " 
<s>  but , on the other hand , it is clueless . 
<s>   " . . . because i'm a scientist . 
<s>  that's what we do ! " 
<s>  --- dr . alexander mccabe ( bob gunton ) , in response to why he created evil bats . 
<s>  alright folks , stop me if you've heard this one : genetically altered animals wreak havoc on a town and a small band of locals , assisted by a specialist in the particular animal's field , must team up to stop the mutant creatures before they can multiply and spread across the earth . 
<s>  oh yeah , the military is on their way to bomb the town as well , so they are running short on time . 
<s>  sound familiar ? 
<s>  such is the plot of the destination films release of bats . 
<s>  dina meyer stars as the " bat specialist " sheila , who is pulled from her research ( along with her annoying sidekick , played with irritating deftness by leon ) in order to help a small texas town figure out why some local citizens and animals have been chewed to death recently . 
<s>  with the help of the local sheriff ( lou diamond phillips ) , a cdc official ( carlos jacott ) , and a scientist ( bob gunton ) , sheila discovers it is indeed bats ( who have been genetically altered by gunton's character to be more aggressive and omnivorous , in order to be used as a military weapon ! ) . 
<s>  i have to say here that i knew exactly what i was getting into going into this film . 
<s>  there's not a frame of promotional footage i have seen for the film that would have led me to believe it was going to be any good . 
<s>  in this respect , the film never disappointed me . 
<s>  this film reaches a level that transcends the " so bad it's good " level and borders on the downright insane . 
<s>  the effects are awful , the script is contrived , and for most of the feature i was laughing at things that were supposed to be taken seriously ( i think ) . 
<s>  i challenge anyone to sit through the scene , where a bat stalks a baby in a crib while another bat terrorizes a patron eating at a diner , with a straight face . 
<s>  thankfully , the performances are as good as they can be considering the material the actors had to perform with . 
<s>  dina meyer has always been the highlight of any of the films she has been in ( johnny mnemonic , dragonheart , and starship troopers . . . 
<s>  the latter being the only film out of that batch with any actual merit ) , and this one is no exception . 
<s>  while one never really gets the impression that meyer's character could be a bat expert in reality , one never really cares to doubt it either . 
<s>  she gives as good a performance as could be expected , plus she's nice to look at for an hour and a half . 
<s>  lou diamond phillips is also serviceable here , as the small town sheriff turned eventual hero . 
<s>  although when we first meet his character he knows bats are the reason for what's going on in town , for some reason later on he suddenly becomes amazed to learn that the actual cause of the deaths in town are because of bats . 
<s>  the only bad performance in the film is that of leon's . 
<s>  he is relegated to the " i'm not sticking around here ! " 
<s>  character and proceeds to repeat variations of that line for the majority of the film even though he stays . 
<s>  anyone who can't immediately tell that bob gunton ( the bad guy in patch adams and countless other films ) is going to eventually turn on the gang and side with his creations before his eminent death will probably be surprised , but i highly doubt it . 
<s>  even if he hadn't been the villain in just about every film he's ever been in , so many obvious hints are given to indicate the devious act that it holds no shock whatsoever . 
<s>  in fact , his death is welcome , because it finally starts moving the plot towards the finale . 
<s>  if the plot doesn't sound ridiculous to you yet , then check out these little tidbits : a multitude of bats inexplicably disperses when a police officer cocks his pistol . 
<s>  an entire town disregards the sheriff and doctor's orders to stay indoors after a curfew is instigated , causing mass hysteria when the bats come out in full force , killing several townsfolk . 
<s>  a government official blows off shelia's instructions ( to wait until dawn to install a cooling unit in the bats' cave that will kill all of them off ) by pulling a night job , resulting in the death of an entire military unit . 
<s>  a cavern full of bat feces never ignites when a phosphorus flare is lit right in the middle of it . 
<s>  finally , to top it all off , this little texas town is showing nosferatu in it's single screen theater ( for reference , our town has over a million people in it with nearly 150 movie screens , and we're lucky to even get kevin smith's dogma ) . 
<s>  the most laughable part of the movie though comes from the ill-conceived bat puppets . 
<s>  while the actual bat attack scenes are shot with rapid fire editing ( making the scenes nearly impossible to comprehend what's going on ) , the scenes where a bat is called upon to interact with a live actor are usually shot more low-key . 
<s>  therefore we the audience get loving close-ups of the most unrealistic , rubbery bat puppets ever committed to film . 
<s>  being able to see the puppeteer's arms would be the only things that could have made these creations worse . 
<s>  after all of this , if you still decide bats might be the movie for you , don't say you haven't been warned . 
<s>  trust me when i say that it's a lot more fun to trash than it is to sit through . 
<s>  i just wish that dina meyer would be cast in more roles or at least choose better films to appear in . 
<s>  she's definitely a talent that is going to waste in films like these . 
<s>  the word to describe sharon stone is " wonder " . 
<s>  not that she _is_ a wonder , but rather that i wonder how she can be so inconsistent . 
<s>  she has a dynamic screen presence in " basic instinct " , turns in a surprisingly fine acting job in " casino " , but possesses neither of those here . 
<s>  stone teams up with private school headmaster's wife isabelle adjani to kill adjani's thoroughly unlikable husband ( chazz palminteri ) . 
<s>  in a comedy of errors and unexpected twists straight out of hitchcock ( as in `homage to' [read " steal from " ] ) , it turns out that someone saw them or he's not dead or maybe . . . 
<s>  kathy bates turns in a credible , if unspectacular , performance as an investigative police detective . 
<s>  her character is a bit dull but realistic , although her actions at the end are puzzling . 
<s>  adjani is more than satisfactory as the timid beaten spouse driven to desperation . 
<s>  it's stone that is a disappointment among the actors . 
<s>  how can she be the epitome of a femme fatale in previous films and come off as a blank in this one ? 
<s>  costumed in skin-tight clothes and looking down her nose at everyone , she is someone you would want to avoid because she is boring , not enticingly dangerous . 
<s>  even the threat ( or promise ? ) of a lesbian relationship between the conspirators is only half played out . 
<s>  on the positive side , there are enough unexpected plot developments to keep your interest alive . 
<s>  that is if you can put up with stone's cardboard cut-out character and scenes directly lifted from hitch's movies . 
<s>  the tagline on random hearts reads " in a perfect world , they never would have met . " 
<s>  in a perfect world , i never would have seen this movie . 
<s>  the biggest flaw is that 20 minutes into this film , kay chandler ( kristin scott thomas ) and dutch van den broeck ( harrison ford ) are the only two major characters alive ; resulting in little doubt that they will end up together at some point during the laborious two-hours-and-then-some production . 
<s>  dutch is a sergeant in internal affairs at the district of columbia police department . 
<s>  kay is a congresswoman from new hampshire . 
<s>  although they both think they are happily married , their spouses are cheating with each other behind their backs . 
<s>  dutch and kay are soon widowed when a plane goes down carrying their partners ; they subsequently discover the affair . 
<s>  the rest of the film is the pointless , unrealistic and often-times boring story of their researching the sexual relationship that they were blind to , and getting to know each other in the process . 
<s>  two sub plots are of little help to the already problematic film . 
<s>  dutch is trying to arrest a fellow officer , a task that seems rather ordinary for hollywood fare . 
<s>  all the great stereotypes get pulled , including my personal favorite of the key witness that makes bail and is murdered soon thereafter . 
<s>  kay's distraction from the film's primary focus is her campaign for re-election and attempts to shield her 15 year old daughter from the truth about the father she put on a pedestal . 
<s>  these sub plots could have made for semi-interesting points , but the film seems afraid to explore politics or mother-daughter relations in depth , and consequently suffers . 
<s>  random hearts' two primary characters seem to live in shells . 
<s>  although both kay and dutch are given their own sub plots , they seem to never deal with anyone other than themselves or each other . 
<s>  there is plenty of opportunity , dutch having a partner and kay having close friends and her daughter , but the movie shies away from exploring these relationships . 
<s>  veteran actor and director of this film sydney pollack , and critically acclaimed up-and-comer dylan baker both have cameo roles , but be careful not to blink too much or you will miss them both . 
<s>  other than its weak plot , it is hard to criticize random hearts . 
<s>  however , it is also hard to compliment it . 
<s>  had the film taken some small risks and more fully explored its extra characters and plots it may have tasted more like a well frosted cake , rather than the dry one that equates to be . 
<s>  in double jeopardy , the stakes are high . 
<s>  think of the plot as a rehash of sleeping with the enemy , and then rearrange the details and the gender of the stalker . 
<s>  the finished product , although able to maintain the viewer's attention , is a predictable and unexciting thriller with an idiotic script . 
<s>  `alex , i'll take homicide for $400 . . . ' 
<s>  libby parsons ( ashley judd ) is a happily married mom leading a normal life . 
<s>  one night , her husband nick ( bruce greenwood ) takes her out for a romantic escape on a sailboat . 
<s>  libby awakens in the middle of the night to find she is covered in blood and nick has strangely disappeared . 
<s>  she follows a trail of bloody footprints up to the deck , where she handles a fallen knife ( like any stupid character ) and is spotted by the coast guard , who are responding to a distress signal sent earlier in the evening . 
<s>  nick is presumed dead , and although she pleads her innocence , libby is tried and convicted for the murder of her husband . 
<s>  now , please don't think i'm spoiling any vital plot details , because the informative trailer has already spilled most of the beans . 
<s>  if you haven't seen this preview , don't read any further . 
<s>  but seriously , the inane screenplay by douglas weisberg and douglas s . cook is so elementary that the average viewer will be two or three steps ahead of the characters . 
<s>  during the most vital scenes in the movie , i was anticipating every twist or `surprise' that eventually popped up on the screen . 
<s>  i imagine the writers presume their core audience for double jeopardy is a very naive group of individuals . 
<s>  most , unfortunately , will be too distracted by the moronic plot to appreciate the few positive aspects of the production . 
<s>  one is tommy lee jones , who plays travis lehman , a parole officer given the tedious task of watching over libby after she serves her sentence in prison . 
<s>  jones is always wonderful as an authority figure , and he's certainly familiar with this sort of role ( as he played so well in the fugitive and us marshals ) . 
<s>  judd , as a likable heroin with gusto , also has a chance to flex her acting abilities . 
<s>  while emotionally unconvincing , the actress is tremendously fun in her juvenile role , perking up the movie like an injection of anti-depressant . 
<s>  the actors , and their relationship together , present the one-two punch that prevents double jeopardy from derailing itself entirely . 
<s>  and now , back to the plot . 
<s>  while behind bars , libby learns an interesting little bit of information : a person can't be convicted of the same crime twice . 
<s>  this law , called `double jeopardy' , could be her motive for hunting down her husband . . . 
<s>  who may still be alive . 
<s>  yes , you heard right . 
<s>  the movie degenerates into a cross-country chase , where everything you expect to happen . . . 
<s>  does . 
<s>  the final scenes , which could have redeemed the film , are poorly handled by director bruce beresford - whose previous work centers highly around drama ( driving miss daisy , paradise road ) . 
<s>  ironically , it is those elements - like the driving force of libby to reunite with her son - that don't quite work here . 
<s>  at least double jeopardy is paced well enough to satisfy diehard fans of the two stars . 
<s>  unfortunately , jones lacks some of the edge that he had as sam gerard in the fugitive , and the real depth of his character is only skin deep . 
<s>  but he and ashley judd are more than welcome considering the material , and both have some memorable comic moments . 
<s>  judd , in particular , has a hilarious scene in which she wards off an oncoming male by explaining she has to check in with her `parole officer' . 
<s>  hmmm . . . 
<s>  perhaps this would have made a good comedy . 
<s>  it is disappointing , because there are the makings of a competent action film here . 
<s>  it's nicely shot and choreographed in downtown vancouver , and will entertain those who aren't turned off by the woeful story-line . 
<s>   ? tis a shame that double jeopardy is an adult thriller that wouldn't fool most children . 
<s>  synopsis : melissa , a mentally-disturbed woman who likes to smoke , seduces doug , a minor-league baseball player who likes to study anatomy , work on motorcycles , and make out with his girlfriend in a public library . 
<s>  when doug decides to stop seeing her , melissa maliciously takes revenge on those around him , including his girlfriend , his mother , and his cat . 
<s>  comments : malicious , i suppose , is an acceptable moview for what it is : a cheap , b-movie thriller which rips off dozens and dozens of spurned-psycho-lover-who-wants-revenge films ( like fatal attraction , hand that rocks the cradle , etc . etc . ) that have come before it . 
<s>  malicious , however , really doesn't provide very many particularly suspenseful moments . 
<s>  the plot starts off energetically enough , the main characters are introduced and the affair between doug and melissa begins and ends pretty early on in the film . 
<s>  it starts to drag , unfortunately , after this . 
<s>  melissa will obviously try to take her revenge on doug ( as always seems to happen in movies like these ) , but she does so in unimaginative ways that have been done in other , better thrillers before . 
<s>  she drugs someone . 
<s>  she kills a family pet and leaves it in the girlfriend's apartment . 
<s>  and , of course , she stalks , so we see a number of shots , which are supposed to be suspenseful , where she's spying on doug and his girlfriend . 
<s>  i won't reveal the ludicrous ending to this turkey , but i warn you that it's both painfully obvious and a real yawner . 
<s>  john vernon does a remarkably good job at playing the not-so-bright baseball jock who initially gets swept away by melissa ( one of the script's faults is to try to pass off a character like this as a pre-med student ) . 
<s>  the same cannot be said , though , for molly ringwald . 
<s>  at times , she can effectively pull off the obsessed lover routine , especially during her silent , i'm-going-to-stare-you-down scenes . 
<s>  at other times , however , she just seems somehow goofy and out of place . 
<s>  in one particular scene which i guess was supposed to be suspenseful , she screeches " f--k you , you b-----d " and throws a phone . 
<s>  she delivers the line so ridiculously that one can't help but laugh . 
<s>  malicious certainly isn't the worst thriller of its kind out in the video racks ( a number of really fat turkies in this genre are out there ) , but it isn't all that good or original either . 
<s>  feel free to treat this film maliciously , watch something else . 
<s>  warner brothers ; rated pg-13 ( mild violence , sexual situations ) ; 132 minutes 
<s>  director : luis mandoki 
<s>  screenplay : gerald di pego ( from the novel by nicholas sparks ) 
<s>  cast : kevin costner , robin wright-penn , paul newman , illeana douglas , robbie coltrane , jesse james , john savage . 
<s>  review by : geoff berkshire 
<s>  i'm not an overly cynical guy . 
<s>  there have been many glossy hollywood romances that have carried me away with their romanticism over the years . 
<s>  however , i have my limits and i also have standards . 
<s>  this brings us to the subject at hand : message in a bottle , the big ticket romance that warner brothers' unleashed upon the movie going public just in time for valentine's day . 
<s>  the story , what little of it that there is , involves boring chicago tribune reporter theresa osborne ( robin wright-penn ) dealing with her recent divorce and trying to raise her young son jason ( jesse james ) . 
<s>  during a brief stay somewhere in new england she finds the titular message in a bottle while on a morning run by the ocean . 
<s>  the letter , written to a mystery woman named catherine , instantly captivates her . 
<s>  upon her return , theresa shares it with her best friend lina ( illeana douglas ) , her boss charlie ( robbie coltrane ) , and the entire city of chicago ( the newspaper publishes an article about it ) . 
<s>  it turns out that the message was written by grieving widower garret blake ( kevin costner ) and so theresa travels to north carolina and tracks him down . 
<s>  he turns out to have a colorful father ( paul newman ) but is otherwise perfectly dull and overly obsessed with sailing . 
<s>  this is somehow attractive to theresa and the two begin their awkward courtship . 
<s>  of course she doesn't tell him that she found his letter , she wants to but the rules of this type of film require him to find out later ( preferably right after they first make love ) . 
<s>  this way garret can get very angry and the relationship can be threatened . 
<s>  the discovery of the message and garret's discovery that theresa discovered the message are really the only two noteworthy events that happen during the nearly two and a quarter hour running time of this film . 
<s>  there's a truly lame subplot about garret's relationship with his dead wife's family ( he gets into a bar fight with her brother , played by john savage ) and then the necessary tear-jerking ending . 
<s>  a fun way to pass the time is to take bets on exactly who will die , although it becomes pretty clear by the second reel . 
<s>  the actual death sequence is one of the most ridiculously forced , and unintentionally humorous , sequences filmed since . . . 
<s>  well , since costner's the postman ( 1997 ) . 
<s>  message in a bottle is one slow moving film . 
<s>  last year audiences were offered endurance tests such as the horse whisperer and meet joe black but both of those films resemble jerry bruckheimer productions next to this . 
<s>  they also had redeeming qualities in the form of quality performances and some stand out technical work . 
<s>  message in a bottle has a decent enough cast but they're fighting the material all the way , and losing badly . 
<s>  costner and , especially , wright-penn are both likable and attractive enough to cheer for but their characters are simply too boring . 
<s>  they also fail to generate any kind of real romantic chemistry . 
<s>  the supporting players are given very little to do . 
<s>  the reliable douglas is particularly wasted . 
<s>  old pro newman gives his all and occasionally threatens to kick some life into this dead horse of a film . 
<s>  a confrontational scene he has with costner near the end is especially well played . 
<s>  however , too frequently he just reminds us how unexciting our lead characters are . 
<s>  the film is very polished on the technical side to be sure but it only works to undercut the story . 
<s>  gabriel yared , who previously set the romantic moods of the english patient ( 1996 ) and city of angels ( 1998 ) with his scores , overdoes it a bit here . 
<s>  caleb deschanel's camera makes everything look a little too beautiful . 
<s>  do the offices of the chicago tribune really need to look heavenly ? 
<s>  the editing by steven weisberg is troubling not only considering all that could have been cut out but is also simply messy at times . 
<s>  the real offender here is screenwriter gerald di pego . 
<s>  working from a best- selling novel by nicholas sparks ( which i have not read but have been told is on the same literary level as the bridges of madison county ) , di pego creates one of the most uninspired scripts of recent times . 
<s>  its strict adherence to clich ? s brings to mind such disasters as i still know what you did last summer ( 1998 ) . 
<s>  there simply isn't an original scene in this film . 
<s>  the dialogue is rarely better than laughable and this is only accentuated by the excessively long pauses every character takes while speaking . 
<s>  this is director mandoki's first film since when a man loves a woman ( 1994 ) , the solid meg ryan/andy garcia romance . 
<s>  he's simply going through the motions with this . 
<s>  message in a bottle is easily the worst of the several romantic offerings available in theaters at the moment and vies with what dreams may come ( 1998 ) as one of the most misguided romances of the decade . 
<s>  disconnect the phone line . 
<s>  don't accept the charges . 
<s>  do anything you can to avoid the wretched , melodramatic sisterhood dramedy `hanging up' . 
<s>  i figured i needed to get in touch with my feminine side , and `hanging up' seemed like an ideal opportunity to do so . 
<s>  the film features an incredible palate of female talent , and the capability behind the camera brought to mind such sparkling gems as `sleepless in seattle' and `unsung heroes' . 
<s>  meg ryan , diane keaton and lisa kudrow play a trio of sisters who , once separated by career judgments over family ties , must reunite when their father ( walter matthau ) is admitted into the hospital with alzheimer's disease . 
<s>  while this may read like an optimum opportunity to rekindle their relationship and reflect with poignancy on the past , the script by sisters delia and nora ephron is exasperating , shapeless dreck teeming with emotional fakery . 
<s>  `hanging up' has the overall effect of a tele-marketer pestering you for two hours , while you don't have the option of doing as the title suggests . 
<s>  for the first half-hour , the ephron sisters use telephone conversations for a basis of character development . 
<s>  this is an annoying and ineffective device . 
<s>  cell-phones ring every five minutes , and everyone hurriedly rushes along , leaving marginal time for the frustrated viewer to relate to the sisters' issues and problems . 
<s>  if `hanging up' was an apple pie , then i felt as if we were getting the mere crust of the story . 
<s>  granted , there are a few genuine and sincere moments in the film . 
<s>  but they only help to establish that the remainder of the strained emotions are nothing but inferior dramatic muck . 
<s>  the most outrageous strategy in `hanging up' is that , after a series of largely unrealized attempts at character development , we are expected to exhibit compassion and courtesy toward the sisters as they join for a melodramatic finale . 
<s>  we are able to identify with eve ( ryan ) , the most open and caring daughter , because she is the one who stayed by her father's side as everyone else moved forward to pursue a impending career . 
<s>  georgia ( keaton ) , the eldest daughter , is celebrating the fifth year anniversary of her magazine called . . . .
